News about potential "cashless casinos" on the Chinese resort island of Hainan appears to be pressuring Macau-exposed casino stocks like Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and MGM Resorts International (MGM).At least five Chinese-owned companies are developing "entertainment bars" in Hainan, according to Bloomberg, in which visitors can play games with money but reap the rewards through a points system at restaurants and hotels in the area.The resorts' owners have had informal talks with officials in Hainan and contacted baccarat table suppliers, the report said. That follows earlier reports that China is considering making gambling legal in Hainan. Currently, casinos are only allowed in the special administrative region of Macau.Shares of Wynn are down 1.5% at 172.42 on the stock market today, scraping the low end of a flat base. Las Vegas Sands fell 2.4% to 79.34, dipping back below a 79.94 buy point. MGM, which is focused more on the U.S. than Macau, dropped 4.5%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown (MLCO) was down 1.7%, near the bottom of a flat base.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseBut those concerns may be overblown. Union Gaming analyst Grant Govertsen reportedly said that any steps toward gambling in Hainan would be "met with an immediate and harsh reaction from the authorities," according to industry publication Inside Asian Gaming, which acquired the note.Govertsen believes that legal gambling in Hainan, should it happen, would have a "negligible" impact on Macau's major casino operators, given that Macau is a more convenient location for mass customers to reach."The government has made it clear that they have no plans to allow full-fledged casino gambling in Hainan as casinos remain forbidden per the constitution," he wrote, asserting that government officials would react quickly to any activity beyond "low-stakes prize-oriented games."On the Hong Kong exchange, casino stocks Wynn Macau fell about 4% and Galaxy Entertainment Group lost 3.5%. China-based stocks are down across the board amid fears of a trade war with the U.S.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: These Casino Stocks Test Key Levels On Weak Macau NumbersWhy This Merger May Threaten Casino Stocks Eyeing Sports Betting BonanzaMGM Resorts Buys New York 'Empire,' But Watch These Casino StocksOut Of The Gate: Kentucky Derby Operator Churchill Downs Gets In On Sports Betting

That would put specialist bookmakers such as U.K.-based William Hill, which is Nevada's sports betting market leader, in pole position to seize the lion's share of the business. And back in April online gambling giant Stars Group (TSG) bet big on online sports betting after agreeing to a $4.7 billion deal to acquire U.K. firm Sky Betting & Gaming.Stars Group stock rallied 9% Monday.The Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act Of 1992 had effectively outlawed sports betting nationwide, except for sports lotteries conducted in Oregon, Delaware and Montana, as well as the licensed sports pools in Nevada. In Murphy v. NCAA, New Jersey appealed the law and the Supreme Court on Monday found in the state's favor.This could have massive implications, as sports betting bills exist in some form in roughly half the 50 states. However analysts believe there may be less gold at the end of the rainbow than is believed.'We think the time to play the impact of sports betting in the U.S. is sooner than later, as we believe the 10,000-foot-view of what the opportunity could mean, is likely to be better than the reality of what it ultimately does mean," Deutsche Bank analyst Carlo Santarelli said in a research note.He cited the case of online gaming legalization in New Jersey in 2013, where estimates of market size far outpaced the ultimate reality of the market. Then Governor Chris Christie claimed the market could be worth $1.2 billion, however, first-year revenue in 2014 ended up coming in at $123 million."While we don't want to be overly dismissive, we believe; 1) market size is likely to be lower than expectations as player conversion to legal markets could be lower than perceived, 2) a state by state rollout will take time, as will the ramp periods, & 3) EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization) margins will be thin," Santarelli said.On the other hand ease of use and trust of payment, and the ability to attract those who would like to bet but do not want to break the law will attract customers.The American Gaming Association has estimated that $150 billion is bet annually on sports. However analysts don't think that those who bet illegally will become legal bettors en masse."Issues which could possibly curb market size include: 1) there will be no float in legal sports betting, meaning you can't bet what you don't have, and yes, that happens, 2) tradition and relationships with "your guy," and 3) an unwillingness to allow governments to see further into an individual's financials," Santarelli said.Jefferies analysts estimates a legal sports betting handle, excluding Nevada and Delaware, of between $1.2 and $57.6 billion, and has used $23.9 billion as its base case. Deutsche Bank estimates a total market size of around $4 billion in sports book revenue across 13 states in 2023.There may be an opportunity for a nimble competitor to outmaneuver the bigger companies and run a sports book across a number of regional casinos, who would cash in buy leasing space out to the bookies."Other than the largest operators in (Nevada), most should outsource bookmaking which bears a cost against profits, while the operating platform also bears a cost," Jefferies analyst David Katz said in a research note. "The issue of negotiating and establishing regulations and issuing licenses has historically been time-consuming, which pushes the earnings opportunities further out."The most lucrative, but also the most risky, aspect of sports betting is running the sports book itself. While industry giant Caesars could operate its own book, analysts believe both Penn and Boyd's are more likely to outsource. They will profit by leasing floor space and taking a cut of the profits.Due to the outsourcing dimension, British bookmaker William Hill could be a big winner, with Canter Gaming and another U.K. firm Ladbrokes also seen as being well-placed. William Hill is currently Nevada's sports betting leader with a 55% market share. The company operates 108 of Nevada's 192 sports books and is the risk manager for sports betting within the Delaware lottery.Last week its U.S. operations enjoyed the biggest growth of all divisions across its whole group during Q1, with revenue rising by 45%. It would have the vital expertise needed to operate a sports book on a large scale.The big casino companies are keeping their cards close to their chest on the issue, with many declining to comment. However there is one firm that seems eager to take advantage if the chips fall the right way."Boyd Gaming views expanded sports betting as an intriguing growth opportunity. We have more than 40 years of experience in sports betting, we operate one of the largest sports book networks in the state of Nevada, and we currently have operations in seven different states (expanding to 10 by the end of the year)," a spokesman said. "Should the Supreme Court repeal PAPSA, Boyd Gaming is in an excellent position to become a leading player in the growth and expansion of sports betting in the U.S."Meanwhile the NBA has been criticized for seeking an "integrity fee," which would levy a proposed 1% of every placed wager if legalization is approved. The league argues the money-spinning move is necessary."Our games would serve as the foundation for legalized sports betting, providing casinos the ability to earn revenue off our games while we bear all of the risk, and would incur additional expenses for compliance and enforcement," NBA spokesman Mike Bass said. "As a result, we believe it is reasonable for casinos to compensate the NBA with a small percentage of the total amount bet on our games."However Santarelli said the idea is a "nonstarter" as it and that it acts as an effective 20% revenue tax. He said the levy would "essentially wipe out the potential for reasonable profits."When it comes to the Supreme Court decision itself, the NBA would still prefer for a federal solution."Our preference is a comprehensive federal approach rather than state-by-state regulation, but we will continue to work with all states seeking our input on a regulated framework that protects the integrity of our game and fairly compensates the NBA's teams and players."The NFL has maintained public opposition to sports betting, and last year Commissioner Roger Goodell said the league is also against individual states regulating their own gambling industries, despite the league's Raiders franchise moving to gambling mecca Las Vegas.MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred has previously advocated the league change its opposition, though the league has yet to officially change its stance."While we have no position on whether states should allow sports betting, we are talking to stakeholders in every state considering the issue," an MLB spokesman said. "We have an obligation to our fans and our sport to help ensure the integrity of our games is protected, which can be done through a strong law requiring airtight coordination between the state, the casino operators and the sports leagues to closely monitor wagers."The NHL has yet to take a public position on the subject, however it allows bets to be placed on its Vegas Golden Knights games in Nevada.The players associations from the four big leagues have banded together and seem keen to secure their own slice of the pie."Betting on sports may become widely legal, but we cannot allow those who have lobbied the hardest for sports gambling to be the only ones controlling how it would be ushered into our businesses," they said in a joint statement. "The athletes must also have a seat at the table to ensure that players' rights and the integrity of our games are protected."YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Which States Have Legalized Sports Betting?NBA Backs Nationwide Sports Betting — For This Price Online Poker Giant Makes Sports Betting Gamble With $4.7 Billion DealThese Dow Giants Jump As They Team Up On Credit CardWhich Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?How To Invest In The Stock Market: Start With A Simple Routine

After retaking its 50-day line this week, Sands is moving toward a 79.94 buy point.MGM Resorts International advanced 0.8% to 36.41, working on a consolidation with a 38.51 entry. Morgan Stanley's Allen raised his price target on MGM earlier in the week.Melco Resorts & Entertainment rose 1% to 31.71, still in buy range. The Hong Kong-domiciled company cleared a 30.59 entry on April 12 in heavy volume.Wynn leads the Leisure-Gaming/Equipment Group, and has an excellent IBD Composite Rating of 95. Morgan Stanley's Allen said Wynn is in a good position to benefit from China's gaming boom due to its Macau casinos.He said this is important given uncertainties regarding its new property in Massachusetts and the ongoing managerial issues following Steve Wynn's February resignation."We are warming up to WYNN again given it has the most exposure in our coverage to the attractive Macau market and likely continues to have the opportunity to outperform through its ramping Cotai property," he said in a research note.He also said the company has done a very good job diminishing legal and regulatory overhangs. However he believes regulatory risk remains, particularly in Massachusetts, where construction of a $2.5 billion casino is ongoing.Meanwhile, Las Vegas Sands was given a one dollar target price increase by Morgan Stanley's Allen, to 83. He said it looks like the best bet when it comes to penetrating the Chinese market."We see LVS as best positioned for the longer term Macau " 'China penetration'/mass market story,"Allen said in a research note. "(We) believe the company should be an outsized beneficiary of increasing infrastructure tailwinds."Allen also said it is well positioned to operate in new gaming locations such as Japan and Korea.Sands has a Composite Rating of 89 and ranks third in the group.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:MGM Resorts International May Bet Big On Bid For Wynn Resorts Top Casino Stock Nears Buy Point Amid Strong Macau Growth Bullish Chart Patterns: Do You Know The Basics Of A Cup With Handle?Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

U.S. stock futures indicated higher opens at Monday's market open after the S&P 500 and Nasdaq both hit record highs on Friday.Several stocks in the elite IBD 50 list are in buy range. MGM (MGM), which is more Vegas exposed than Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS), fell 4% in premarket trading.Japan's Nikkei climbed 0.2% on Monday as many Asian markets were closed. But Spain's main index slid 1.45% as Catalan leaders signaled they would move toward declaring independence this week. But two days later, Nvidia moved back above the 174.66 entry, finishing the week at 178.67. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) broke out Friday as casino stocks rallied on news that Macau gaming revenue rose 20% in August, despite the city getting hit by a typhoon during the month.Macau's casinos brought in $2.82 billion, or 22.7 billion patacas, in revenue for the month, according to Reuters. That marks the 13th straight month of growth, but a sequential slowdown from the July's year-over-year gain of 29.2%. Macau's gaming revenue has been recovering after slipping in recent years due to crackdowns on money laundering and corruption. Macau is the only place in China where gambling is legal.Shares of Wynn Resorts closed 3.2% higher at 143.42 on the stock market today, hitting the highest level since March 2015. That cleared a 139.77 entry point out of a two-month flat base.Several other Macau-exposed casino giants enjoyed more-modest gains Friday as they begin building the right side of their own flat-base consolidations.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rose 1.1% to finish at 62.87, closing on a 66.32 buy point. The stock cleared its 50-day moving average on Thursday. Last month Sands fell to around the June 1 breakout buy point of the prior consolidation.MGM Resorts International (MGM) rose 0.8% to 33.21 after definitively moving above its 50-day line on Thursday. MGM has a 34.63 buy point in a consolidation going back to July 25.  MGM is less exposed to Macau than Wynn and Sands, though it's opening a new resort in the Chinese gaming enclave soon.Melco Resorts & Entertainment (MLCO) advanced 1.1% to 22.20, also after retaking its 50-day in the prior session. The Hong Kong-domiciled casino operator has a 24.04 buy point.According to the Guardian, Typhoon Hato killed eight people in Macau, hitting southern China late in the month and cutting power in Macau's casinos. The storm was reportedly the strongest to hit the area in over half a century.The Leisure-Gaming/Equipment group is No. 8 out of the 197 industries that IBD tracks. MGM Resorts is rated No. 1 in the gaming group, boasting a 96 Composite Rating. Sands has a CR of 92 while Wynn is at 91. All-time winning stocks often have Composite Ratings of 95 to a best-possible 99 near the start of big price moves.Several U.S.-focused casino operators also faring well, including Boyd Gaming (BYD), Eldorado Resorts (ERI), Churchill Downs (CHDN) and Monarch Casino & Resort (MCRI).RELATED:As Macau Rebounds, Casinos Eye This Next Possible Gaming Hot SpotMacau July Gaming Revenue Booms, But It's A Push On Wall Street

Amid a grinding-higher market, Apple (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT), Biogen (BIIB), Electronic Arts (EA), Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) are highly rated big-cap stocks holding in buy zones after breaking out several days or weeks ago.XIdeally, stocks will blast out of bases and then rapidly add to gains, and there are some breakouts like that. But in the current market environment many stocks just edge past entry points, with shares soon pulling back below them, at least temporarily. Apple chipmaker Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and chip-gear maker Teradyne (TER) both fell back below entry areas on Monday after breaking out Friday. While their breakouts aren't failures, their high-volume retreats aren't encouraging.Apple broke out of a flat base with a 156.75 buy point on Aug. 2, the day after reporting strong earnings and guidance. The iPhone giant did dip below that entry point a few times over the next few weeks, but since Aug. 21 the stock has stayed in a buy zone.Apple has trended lower since unveiling its new iPhones, with the high-end iPhone X not set for release until Nov. 2. Microsoft has been breaking out, then pulling back below the entry area before finally moving higher, sometimes after forming a new consolidation.Microsoft cleared a base-on-base formation with a 74.52 entry back on Aug. 31. True to form, Microsoft pulled back the following day and didn't hold above the entry until Sept. 11. Shares hit a record-high 75.97 intraday Monday, but reversed to close down 0.2% at 75.16.Biogen soared 4.2% on Aug. 30, blowing past a 312.50 buy point from a 13-month consolidation. Celgene rose 0.6% to 142.84 on Monday, setting a record 143.40 intraday.The video game publisher cleared a 116.14 buy point on July 26, just before the Nasdaq hit a short-term high. Electronics Arts tested that entry point several times, closing below it on Aug. 10-11. But since then EA has generally stayed within the 5% buy zone. Shares edged up 0.45% to 119.96 on Monday.EA's 50-day line has risen to just above the entry level, offering a possible backstop for the stock.Alexion, the last of three biotechs highlighted here, sold off from July 2015 to May 2017. A week later, Alexion closed just below that entry, but hasn't done that since.Alexion will cut 20% of staff, the biotech said last week, to spend more on research.Alexion fell 2.1% to 143.64 on Monday.The casino giant rose strongly past a 139.77 flat-base buy point on Sept. 1. Stocks rattled off solid gains at Wednesday's open as the market hauled in a large dose of positive early earnings news and oil prices continued their recent rebound.XThe Dow Jones industrial average jumped 0.4%, the S&P 500 futures climbed 0.1% and the Nasdaq composite scaled up 0.2%, enough to knock out a new high.Investor attention will be spread thin Wednesday, a powerhouse session for big-name earnings reports ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy announcement and an after-hours session in which quarterly results are due from Facebook (FB), PayPal (PYPL) and Edwards Lifesciences (EW), among others.The Federal Open Market Committee wraps up its two-day meeting today in Washington, D.C., with a policy announcement this afternoon at 2 p.m. ET. Expectations are low for any sort of material change in policy following last month's rate hike, but the release will be closely scanned for any hint of future hikes, and particularly for any clue as to Fed action on beginning to reduce its $4.5 trillion bond debt amassed during its 2008-14 quantitative easing period.Other economic news for the day is light, with the release of June new home sales figures set for 10 a.m. ET from the Commerce Department. At 10:30 a.m. ET, the Energy Information Administration delivers its weekly oil inventories report.Oil prices climbed 1%, looking to add a third day to their recent bounce and lifting West Texas Intermediate back above $48 a barrel.The premarket session was buzzing on earnings news: AT&T (T) opened 4% higher, U.S. Steel (X) vaulted 10% and Akamai Technologies (AKAM) dropped 11%; Ford (F) fell 2%, following quarterly reports.Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) gapped up to an 11% gain after earnings accelerated into triple-digit growth and a 19% jump in revenue topped expectations. The strong volume move left shares extended above a 14.77 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) took a 7% stumble a the starting bell, after reporting second-quarter results late Tuesday. A 10% earnings gain and a 45% surge in revenue topped analyst estimates. The loss sent shares below their 10-week moving average in heavy trade, a sell signal.Boeing (BA) hauled the Dow higher, surging 6% after reporting earnings of $2.89 per share, up from a 44 cents per share loss a year ago. The stock is extended, and up 22% since clearing a flat base in early June.Dow peer Verizon (VZ) swung up up more than 1% ahead of its second-quarter report scheduled for early Thursday.Apple (AAPL) and all four of the FANG stocks traded higher in early action. Amazon.com (AMZN) and Netflix (NFLX) each rose more than 1%. Facebook opened with a 0.2% gain heading toward its second-quarter report after the close.Electronic components manufacturer Amphenol (APH) popped 2% in powerful trade, marking a breakout past a 76.77 buy point in a six-week flat base. The Wallingford, Conn.-based operation turned in a strong second-quarter earnings win, revenue also topped expectations and management ratcheted its third-quarter revenue and earnings guidance to above consensus views. Share remained in a buy range.Triumph Group (TGI) dived 15% at the open, after its second-quarter revenue and earnings missed forecasts. The stock had been advancing since May, attempting to climb out of a 27-month correction.RELATED:Futures: These 4 IBD 50 Stocks Report Earnings As Apple Nears BuyThe Big Picture: New Breakouts EmergeMcDonald's, TI And AMD Get Price Target Hikes; Electronic Arts Is A Buy

Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Hawaiian Airlines' parent Hawaiian Holdings (HA) and U.S. Steel (X) reported better-than-expected earnings after the close. Wynn Resorts and U.S. Steel also topped on sales. Chipotle and Hawaiian Holdings missed on revenue.XEstimates: Second-quarter earnings per share of $1.09, up 2%. Revenue is seen jumping 37% to $1.452 billion.Results: EPS climbed 10% to $1.18 as revenue rose 44.5% to $1.53 billion.

Stock: Shares fell 3.4% in late trade. Wynn closed up 0.3% in the stock market today.Wynn has been seen as among the biggest beneficiaries of the rebound in the VIP gaming business in Macau, the world's largest gaming hub and the only place in China where gambling is legal. The company has also tried to draw more mass-market gamblers.Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts (MGM), Melco Resorts (MLCO) and Vegas-based Boyd Gaming (BYD) report this week.Estimates: Second-quarter earnings per share more than doubling to $2.16, with revenue climbing to $1.184 billion, as Chipotle faced easy comparisons from a food-borne illness scare that damaged the top and bottom lines last year. Same-store sales were expected to climb 9.5%.Results: EPS leapt 167% to $2.32 as sales rose 17.1% to $1.17 billion. Comparable-store sales up 8.1%.

Stock: Chipotle rose 3.5% in after-hours trading. Shares closed 2.5% higher after hitting a fresh four-year low on Monday.The stock slid last week following a report that customers got sick after eating at a Chipotle restaurant in Virginia, likely refreshing concerns about food safety at the fast-casual chain even despite its efforts to put new safety measures in place. A video last week showing mice inside a Chipotle restaurant in Dallas didn't help.The company has said the illnesses were restricted to the one location in Virginia. It also said that the mice snuck in "due to a small structural gap in the building," according to CNN."Recent events, however, have shown that we still have a lot of opportunity to improve our operations and deliver the outstanding experience that our customers expect," CEO Steve Ells said in the earnings statement.Chipotle also said it is aiming for full-year comps growth "in the high single digits."Estimates: A 26% jump in Q2 EPS to $1.53, with revenue surging 30% to $677 million.Results: EPS advanced nearly 31% to $1.58, with revenue of $675.34 million.

Outlook: Hawaiian expects Q3 operating unit revenue up 4.5%-7.5% with capacity up 0.5%-2.5%.Stock: Hawaiian fell 4% late. Shares closed the regular session down 1.3%, hitting a 52-week low intraday.While the carrier has enjoyed minimal competition from flights coming into Hawaii, shares tumbled last month after United Airlines (UAL) said it would expand service into the state next year.Hawaiian on Monday also announced three new routes linking it to the West Coast, raising the likelihood of increased competition and weaker financials.Estimates: Q2 EPS of 40 cents, up from a 31-cent per-share loss a year ago. Revenue is expected to rise 15% to $2.975 billion. Results: EPS of $1.07 adjusted, with revenue of $3.14 billion, up 22%.

Stock: U.S. Steel leapt 9% in after-hours action. Shares closed up 2.7% as steel and mining stocks rallied Tuesday.Steel stocks jumped earlier this month after President Trump said he was considering tariffs and quotas on foreign steel.RELATED:McDonald's Touts Digital Progress; Domino's Falls HardThese 3 Casino Stocks Are Near Buy Zones Ahead Of EarningsUnited's Aggressive Growth Plan Assumes This About RivalsDelta's Guidance: 'Good Enough' Falls Short Of 'Whisper Number'

Boyd Gaming (BYD) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) beat on earnings but missed on revenue, while Melco Resorts & Entertainment (MLCO) and Penn National Gaming (PENN) missed earnings views but beat on revenue.Estimates: EPS is seen nearly doubling to 30 cents. Revenue is expected to climb 10% to $598 million.Results: EPS of 26 cents on revenue after promotions of $600 million."Our Las Vegas Locals business achieved its best second-quarter results in nearly 10 years, driven by ongoing improvements to our operations and a strong regional economy," said CEO Keith Smith in a statement.Stock: Shares lost 1.75% to end at 25.77, dropping further below a 26.30 buy point.Estimates: EPS to fall 35% to 24 cents, with revenue up 2% to $783 million.Results: EPS of 18 cents on revenue of $796.5 million.Outlook: Q3 EPS of 20 cents on revenue of $790.9 million vs. consensus views for EPS of 24 cents on revenue of $783 million. Full-year EPS is now seen at 59 cents, down from a prior view of 60 cents, on revenue of $3.12 billion, up from a prior view of $3.07 billion. Analysts see EPS of 68 cents on revenue of $3.12 billion.Stock: Shares retreated 2.7% to 20.74 as they work their way through a flat base with a 22.29 buy point.In addition to casinos, U.S.-focused Penn National also operates race tracks and off-track wagering locations.Estimates: EPS up 8% to 28 cents on revenue of $2.659 billion, up 17%, according to Zacks Investment Research.Results: Adjusted EPS of 30 cents on revenue after promotional allowances of $2.64 billion. Domestic resort revenue jumped 22% to $2.07 billion, helped by the recent openings of new properties, while MGM China revenue dipped 0.7% to $448.7 million.Outlook: Q3 revenue to increase "slightly," amid tougher year-ago comparisons and "higher-than-anticipated disruption at Monte Carlo as the property undergoes its transformation to Park MGM."Stock: Shares closed down 1.4% at 33.39 on the stock market today. MGM is extended above buy range.MGM is more focused on the domestic market than Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), which are more exposed to Macau.Late Wednesday, Las Vegas Sands topped forecasts, and on Tuesday, Wynn also topped, as it is seen being among the biggest beneficiaries of the rebound in the VIP gaming business in Macau.Estimates: Earnings per share quadrupling to 20 cents, as revenue rises 13% to $1.21 billion.Results: Adjusted EPS of 16 cents on revenue of $1.3 billionStock: Shares finished 2% lower at 20.89 as they form a flat base with a 24.04 entry.The Hong Kong-base casino operator is focused heavily on the Macau market and other parts of Asia.RELATED:Whole Foods, Las Vegas Sands, Nutrisystem Earnings TopChipotle, Wynn Resorts, U.S. Steel, Hawaiian Earnings TopThese 3 Casino Stocks Are Near Buy Zones Ahead Of EarningsHot Mutual Fund Hedges Its Trump-Bump Plays With Stocks Like MGM Resorts

Amazon (AMZN) grocery takeover target Whole Foods Market (WFM) reported better-than-expected earnings Wednesday afternoon, ahead of the expected after-hours release. Las Vegas Sands (LVS), and Nutrisystem (NTRI) reported better-than-expected earnings late Wednesday.

XEstimates: Second-quarter earnings per share of 61 cents, up 17%, on revenue up 14% to $3.019 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research.Results: EPS rose 38% to 73 cents. Revenue climbed nearly 19% to $3.14 billion.Stock: Sands stock initially rose modestly in late trade but reversed lower for a 1.3% drop to 60.85. Shares dipped 1.55% to 61.65 in the stock market today, closing just below their rising 50-day line. Shares are making their way through a flat base above a cup-with-handle pattern. The new buy point is 66.32.Las Vegas Sands' results come as gaming revenue rebounds in Macau, the world's biggest gambling hot spot and the only place in China where it is legal, after restrictions in recent years raised concerns that high-rolling VIPs would be scared away.Barclays believes Las Vegas Sands is poised for long-term growth as mass-market gaming gets bigger in Macau. The company also has the most hotel rooms and Macau and solid potential to do more nongaming business, the investment firm said.Wynn Resorts (WYNN), whose second-quarter results topped estimates late Tuesday, fell 5% to 132, closing just below its 50-day moving average. Wynn sank as low as 128.44 intraday. The opening of Wynn Palace in Macau last year led to a surge in revenue, but concerns about mass-market gaming in the region weighed on the stock.Macau's smoking ban in casinos hurt mass-market results, Wynn management said on its earnings call, adding that the segment seemed likely to improve following the completion of construction projects that have hindered people's access to Wynn Palace.MGM Resorts International (MGM) fell 1.2%. Melco Resorts & Entertainment (MLCO) slid 1.7% while U.S.-focused Boyd Gaming (BYD) was flat. MGM, Melco and Boyd all report earnings on Thursday.MGM is extended from a breakout while Melco is in a flat base but below its 50-day. Boyd Gaming has been flirting with a buy point.Estimates: Wall Street expects Nutrisystem, which offers meal plans and other services to help people lose weight, to report second-quarter EPS of 61 cents, up 13%, as sales jump 21% to $181 million.Results: EPS was 80 cents, up 48%. Revenue rose 30% to $194.9 million.Outlook: Nutrisystem sees Q3 revenue of $153 million to $158 million vs. the consensus for $143 million. It sees Q3 EPS of 42 cents, in line with views. Nutrisystem raised its full-year revenue target $684 million to $694 million vs. analysts' estimate of $661 million. It raised its full-year EPS target by a dime to $1.94.  Analysts had expected $1.69.Stock: Nutrisystem shot up 7% to 67.50 in late trade after a brief halt. Shares rose 2.1% to 62.95. The stock is extended after clearing a 55.10 buy point in late trade.Estimates: Fiscal third-quarter earnings per share down 8% to 34 cents, as revenue ticks up 0.5% to $3.721 billion.Results: EPS of 36 cents, down 3%, as sales edged up 0.6% to $3.725 billion. Same-store sales fell 1.9%, a smaller decline than forecast.Stock: Shares rose 0.1% to 41.81, little changed after the earnings report and just below the 42 takeover price from Amazon. Whole Foods traded above 42 for a few weeks on speculation that there might be another bid.Whole Foods will not hold a post-earnings conference call, citing the Amazon deal.Amazon said last month said it would buy the upscale grocery chain for $13.7 billion. The deal upended retail and grocery stocks and raised questions about what the e-commerce giant, with its huge data-gathering arsenal and broad fulfillment infrastructure, might do with Whole Foods."The possible scenarios range from the very disruptive — Amazon running Whole Foods at margin neutral, offering one hour delivery, and focusing more on prepared offerings," Jefferies said in a research note this month, "to the more incremental — testing price elasticity, optimizing data, selling Amazon devices and offering the ability to pick up online orders at the stores."McDonald's (MCD) CEO Steve Easterbrook, during the burger chain's second-quarter earnings call on Tuesday, would not comment on that deal or its implications for home-meal kits.But he did say that McDonald's efforts in delivery were "a great example of how we're responding to the rapidly-changing tastes and expectations of consumers."More broadly, Whole Foods, known for its lush expanses of produce and long aisles of Belgian-influenced beer, has struggled to compete with more traditional grocery-store companies that have begun stocking their shelves with more organic fare.RELATED:McDonald's Touts Digital Progress; Domino's Falls HardThese 3 Casino Stocks Are Near Buy Zones Ahead Of Earnings

MGM Resorts (MGM) reported third-quarter earnings following a mass shooting in Las Vegas that took place near one of its hotels. MGM Resorts said post-shooting cancellations have largely ended and bookings are near "normal levels."XEstimates: Earnings per share to sink 43% to 33 cents while revenue grows 10% to $2.77 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research. Some other consensus forecasts expected EPS of 34-35 cents.Results: EPS was 33 cents a share excluding a 7-cent charge. Revenue rose to $2.823 billion. MGM China's net revenue fell 6% to $471 million.Stock: Shares rose 5.1% to 33.06 on the stock market today, rebounding over their 50-day moving average. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rose 0.8% while China-based casino giant Melco Resorts and Entertainment (MLCO) gained 0.8%. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) added 0.4%.U.S.-focused Caesars Entertainment (CZR) climbed 0.8%.IBD'S TAKE: Ready to invest but don't know where to start? An easy to follow routine from IBD can help you grow and protect your money over the long term.Last month, a shooter killed nearly 60 and wounded more than 500 after opening fire on the Route 91 Harvest country music festival, via a room at the Mandalay Bay Casino, which is operated by MGM."As a result of the October 1 incident, our business in Las Vegas will be impacted in the near term primarily due to a short-lived uptick in cancellations and a temporary suspension of marketing efforts," CEO Jim Murrent said. "Since restarting such efforts, our booking pace has largely rebounded to normal levels. We are also making significant progress on the transformation of Monte Carlo to Park MGM, and as expected, will continue to experience disruption at the property. As a result, in the fourth quarter, we expect our Las Vegas Strip revenue to decrease by a low to mid-single digit percentage, with nonhotel elements partially offsetting a 5%-7% (revenue per available room) decline."Also last month, MGM China Holdings said it would delay the opening of its new casino on the Cotai strip section of Macau to early next year from the second half of 2017 due to damage from Typhoon Hato in August.Strong revenue on Macau during a key holiday period as well as China's Communist Party Congress, which drove a spike in tourism, have boosted shares of more Macau-focused casinos.Gross gaming revenue in the world's biggest gambling market surged 22.1% in October vs. a year earlier. That was the 15th straight monthly gain and much better than the 15.9% rise expected, according to Consensus Metrix forecasts.Las Vegas Sands and Wynn reported strong quarterly results last month, and Melco also beat forecasts earlier this month.RELATED:Melco Resorts Beats Q3 Earnings Estimates On Strong Growth In Macau, PhilippinesCasino Stocks Keep Winning As Macau Gaming Revenue Exceeds Bullish BetsLas Vegas Sands Earnings Unexpectedly Rise In Good Start For Casinos

Melco Resorts and Entertainment (MLCO) reported third-quarter earnings and revenue above expectations on strong growth from Macau and the Philippines. But shares plunged.The Chinese gambling giant reported earnings of 24 cents per American depositary share and a 19% increase in revenue to $1.38 billion. Analysts expected a 46% earnings 19 cents per ADS with revenue up 11.6% to $1.29 billion.Revenue gains were led by Melco's City of Dreams and Studio City resorts.Melco shares fell 3.7% to 25.54 on the stock market today, briefly falling back into buy range with its intraday low of 24.05. It's not clear what spurred the selling, but Melco had rebounded nearly 14% in the prior three sessions.Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rose 0.8%, while Wynn Resorts (WYNN) sank 1% and MGM Resorts[ticker symb=MGM] 0.4%.IBD'S TAKE: Buying or holding a stock can be risky heading into an earnings report. Here's an earnings options strategy that can help you cash in on post-earnings stock gains, while minimizing the risk from a weak quarter.Melco said gaming revenue growth in Macau remained strong and sees strength in the fast- growing Philippines market.Macau, the world's largest gambling market, is a major driver of Melco's revenue."We believe there are multiple drivers of long term growth for Macau, powered by ongoing expansion of the increasingly consumption driven middle-to-upper class in China, improving accessibility into and mobility around Macau, and the continuing buildout of nongaming amenities, which we believe support an increase in the number of tourists and length of stay," CEO Lawrence Ho said in the earnings release.On Wednesday, Macau said gambling revenue jumped 22.1% in October vs. a year ago, beating analyst estimates.Last month, Las Vegas Sands and Wynn Resorts reported third-quarter results above Wall Street estimates.Sands said in gains in Macau and Singapore helped boost results and that it would invest more than $1.1 billion in new projects in Macau over the next three years.RELATED:Casinos Fall As 'Super Golden Week' Looks Not So Super; U.S. Casinos In Talks

The Trump administration's chances of pushing through tax reform legislation are improving and will pressure so-called FANG stocks — Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) — and other momentum stocks with high hedge fund ownership, says JPMorgan.X "For managers overweight growth/momentum, taking a defensive approach to tax reform appears prudent," said the JPMorgan report published Thursday. "While passage of tax reform may provide mid-single digit upside to the S&P 500, we also estimate that equity allocations for most investor types are near historical highs, potentially leaving them less willing to increase allocations to U.S. equities further. Thus, passage of tax reform is likely to result in style implications for equities (i.e. value vs. growth)."JPMorgan recommends "protective strategies" for high growth/momentum stocks with high hedge fund ownership. They include: Facebook, Salesforce.com (CRM), Applied Materials (AMAT), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Qorvo (QRVO), Marriott International (MAR), Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX) and Autodesk (ADSK).Also on the list are: Micron (MU), Align Technology (ALGN), Netflix, JD.com (JD), Activision-Blizzard (ATVI), Red Hat (RHT), Lam Research (LRCX), Mercadolibre (MELI,) PayPal Holdings (PYPL) and Adobe Systems (ADBE).IBD'S TAKE: Read IBD's The Big Picture column each day to stay on top of the market direction, a key indicator that lets you know when you can be aggressive and when you should move to the sidelines.Stocks rose early Thursday as investors eyed a pending tax reform vote in the U.S. Senate. After a technology sector sell-off on Wednesday, all of the FANG stocks traded higher, led by Netflix. Goldman Sachs led the Dow, continuing a rally in banks and financial stocks."Passage of tax reform, or increasing speculation thereof, could cause a continued rotation out of growth/momentum," said JPMorgan. "Our analysis suggests strong active manager performance is being driven by record-high stock dispersion, high exposure to growth/momentum, and a (skewing) of stock returns favoring a few select stocks (FANGs)."RELATED:Is This Trump-Bump Sector Gearing Up For Another Rally?Five Reasons Why JPMorgan, Citigroup, Other Financials Are Seizing Market LeadershipIn AI Technology Race, U.S. Chips May Be Ace-In-The-Hole Vs. China

Extreme Networks (EXTR), the one-time highflier from the dot-com era that crashed and disappeared from radar screens for more than a decade, is now one of the top stocks in one of the market's strongest-performing industry groups.X After a second attempt at reinventing itself in 2015, Extreme is now ranked No. 2 by IBD Stock Checkup — based on earnings, sales, margins and stock performance trends — in the Computer-Networking group, which is ranked No. 6 among 197 industry groups.Extreme's resurgence began after it installed board member Ed Meyercord as chief executive. Meyercord pared down the company, narrowing its focus and stabilizing its finances, before beginning to build it up piece by piece."They decided the acquisition strategy was the right strategy," said D.A. Davidson Co. analyst Mark Kelleher, even after high hopes for its $180 million acquisition of Enterasys Networks in 2013 were largely dashed.Now, Extreme has shown that it has the right team in place to execute on its vision. It's pushing past the $1 billion annual revenue threshold and is throwing off enough cash to make key technology acquisitions that have broadened out its product set.Extreme bills itself as the only pure play end-to-end enterprise networking company with software-driven solutions that go from the wireless edge to the data center. It's the clear No. 3 in the enterprise network market, behind the dominant leader Cisco Systems (CSCO), and No. 2 Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), and growing faster than the mature market in which it competes.That position doesn't just reflect its third-place revenue share, still only about 4% of the market, but also its ranking by Gartner, which puts Extreme a close third behind Cisco and HP — and well ahead of the rest — both in its ability to execute and the completeness of its product vision.Gartner's September report also highlighted Extreme's "strong customer service through a 100% insourced service and support team."Meyercord said on a Nov. 7 fiscal first-quarter earnings call that Extreme is leveraging its recognition from Gartner, which he called "one of the most relied-upon resources for enterprise customers" and "the best marketing we have," according to a Seeking Alpha transcript.Extreme is "taking share from our larger competitors," Chief Financial Officer Drew Davies told a Needham networking and security conference on Nov. 14. He highlighted business wins in the past couple of weeks, including the Wynn Boston Harbor resort and a competitive bidding win at Raytheon.In its latest acquisition, which closed in October, Extreme bought Brocade's data center switching, routing and analytics assets for $55 million in cash. The deal is on track to add $230 million in revenue for Extreme in the first year.Broadcom (AVGO), which acquired the rest of Brocade, was willing to part with that portion of its business so as not to compete against the networking vendors such as Extreme that use Broadcom chipsets to power their switches, D.A. Davidson's Kelleher told Investor's Business Daily.IBD'S TAKE: Shares of Extreme Networks were whipsawed in a volatile week for technology stocks. The upshot from a technical perspective is that the stock will have to work on a new base with a 14.44 buy point, the point at which an investor has the best opportunity for significant near-term gains. A leading stock in a leading industry group can be a recipe for a winning stock if bought at the right time.Kelleher said Extreme's strategy to build a complete enterprise networking offering by putting together pieces such as Brocade's data center business makes a lot of sense.Because of various mergers — and, in the case of Avaya, a bankruptcy — Extreme has been able to pick up "all of these embedded assets that weren't being optimized," Kelleher said.Kelleher expects there will be more such acquisition opportunities ahead, though he expects Extreme to take about six months to digest its latest purchase.In July, Extreme strengthened its competitive position when it closed on its purchase of Avaya's networking assets, which it won with a $100-million bid. Extreme said the deal would add to earnings and produce $200 million in annual revenue.In October 2016, Extreme finalized its purchase of the wireless local area network business of Zebra Technologies (ZBRA), which is expected to generate more than $115 million in fiscal 2018 revenue.Those three acquisitions have essentially doubled the total addressable market opportunity for Extreme from $8 billion to $16 billion."(Extreme's) strong (first) quarter was driven by the better than expected results of the Zebra and Avaya transactions," wrote Needham analyst Alex Henderson. "The new employees are delivering better-than-expected productivity."Henderson said Extreme's staff is now unencumbered by the constraints of their prior company structures. In Henderson's view, the new Extreme is proving through the "exceptionally smooth integration of the Zebra acquisition" that the company can execute on its acquisition strategy.On the fiscal first-quarter earnings call, Meyercord called the Brocade deal an "important piece of the puzzle that helps us complete our enterprise networking solutions portfolio," enabling it to meet the large-scale data-center needs of Fortune 500 customers.Extreme now has 30,000 customers, after a picking up a large base of blue-chip clients via acquisitions, and one of its keys to growth will be cross-selling opportunities. Gartner says government and education have been Extreme's main vertical markets, but that customers in retail, hospitality, manufacturing and healthcare also "should consider Extreme."Henderson noted that Extreme more than doubled the number of $1 million-plus deals in its past two quarters.Outside of acquisitions, Extreme has been generating positive organic revenue growth in the low-single digits in recent quarters, an improvement after the retrenchment in 2015, and analysts see some potential for further improvement. Yet, Extreme's target market is only expected to grow an annualized 2% in coming years, so acquisitions and market-share gains will have to be growth drivers.For the December quarter, Extreme offered revenue guidance of $236 million to $246 million, well above the $224 million consensus. The guidance for EPS of 10 cents-14 cents was below the 18-cent estimate, but analysts have downplayed that as a function of timing of the Brocade deal.The quarterly results won't include October, always a relatively big month for the Brocade data-center business. That means Extreme will get more of a cost bump than a revenue bump for this one quarter.Shares of Extreme were down Friday by 0.9% to 12.74.RELATED:Extreme Networks In Buy Range, With NFL Wi-Fi Season In Full-SwingWhy This Networking Firm's Shares Jumped To A Two-Month HighEarnings Beat, Buying Spree Are Driving This 'Extreme' BreakoutStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

Shares of casino operators Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MLCO) rose Wednesday as Macau reported even-stronger-than-expected gaming revenue in October. MGM Resorts International (MGM) rose early but reversed.XGross gaming revenue in the world's biggest gambling market surged 22.1% vs. a year earlier. That was the 15th straight monthly gain and much better than the 15.9% rise expected, according to Consensus Metrix forecasts. Nomura had forecast an increase of 19% to 21%, accelerating from September's 16%."Our latest consultant checks point to a noticeable pickup in demand following the 19th Party Congress in China, with VIP and mass revenue up about 30% and 9% year-over-year, respectively," noted analyst Harry Curtis in a report acquired by CNBC.That optimism triggered a big gain in global casino stocks on Tuesday, and they kept rising early Wednesday after the reality exceeded those bullish bets.Shares of Melco and Wynn, which have more exposure to Macau, led the rally in casino stocks for a second straight session. Melco rose 4.9% to 26.52 on the stock market today, ahead of its quarterly earnings on Thursday morning. Melco jumped 6.9% on Tuesday, becoming extending above buying territory. Wynn climbed 2.75% Wednesday after its 4.45% Tuesday gain pushed it beyond the 5% chase zone from the breakout point.Las Vegas Sands rose 1.5% after retaking its 50-day line on Tuesday. MGM Resorts reversed to close down 1.7% after rising 2.55% on Tuesday.IBD'S TAKE: With thousands of publicly traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? A good starting point is to regularly review screens that highlight the top-rated equities.Also affecting casino stocks Tuesday was the release of September numbers from the Nevada Gaming Control Board, which said revenue rose 3.25% statewide and 4.67% on the Las Vegas Strip.And on Monday, Pennsylvania, the No. 2 U.S. commercial casino state, OK'd online gambling and gaming at airports, bars and truck stops.Among U.S.-centric casino stocks, Caesars Entertainment (CZR) gained 2.8% on Tuesday, Penn National Gaming (PENN) rose 2.5%, Boyd Gaming (BYD) added 2.1% and Pinnacle Entertainment (PNK) climbed 1%.All four stocks were little changed Wednesday.RELATED:Las Vegas Sands Earnings Unexpectedly Rise In Good Start For CasinosCasino Stocks Pressured On Mass Shooting; MGM Delays Opening Macau HotelCasinos Fall As 'Super Golden Week' Looks Not So Super; U.S. Casinos In Talks

Analysts had expected an EPS drop to 67 cents on revenue of $3.12 billion.Gains in Macau and Singapore lifted the results, Las Vegas Sands said. The casino giant said it would invest more than $1.1 billion in new projects in Macau over the next three years. The S&P 500 index and other major averages rose modestly to record highs. Apple (AAPL) reported strong earnings and guidance as the iPhone X launched. Facebook (FB) crushed views but warned of soaring operating costs. Tesla (TSLA) missed badly and tempered its Model 3 goals as production "hell" continued. Alibaba (BABA) delivered huge growth. Symantec (SYMC) and several security stocks tumbled, while Oclaro (OCLR) spurred a big fiber-optic retreat. President Trump nominated a new Federal Reserve chairman while the House GOP finally unveiled a big tax-cut plan. Job growth did not rebound as much as expected last month.The S&P 500 index, Dow industrials and Nasdaq extended their weekly win streaks with modest gains and new highs amid a new wave of earnings, President Trump's Fed pick and the GOP's tax plan. Megacap Apple gave a nice Friday lift following its strong results. Facebook crushed views, but warned that it'll hike security spending after Russia-tied political content reached nearly half of Americans. Tesla reported a big loss, burned $1.4 billion in cash, pushed back its Model 3 production path and will cut Model S and Model X output. Alibaba had stellar results. Fiber-optic and several cybersecurity stocks were hammered. Home Depot (HD) and homebuilders sold off Thursday as House Republicans included a measure to slash the mortgage interest deduction in their tax plan.RELATED:Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksApple sold more iPhones, iPads and Mac computers than expected in its fiscal fourth quarter. Apple earned $2.07 a share, up 24%, on sales of $52.6 billion, up 12%. Analysts expected $1.87 and $50.79 billion. China sales rose for the first time in seven quarters. For the December quarter, the typically conservative Apple guided revenue to slightly above the consensus. CEO Tim Cook said he is "bullish" on Apple's prospects and expects "the best holiday season yet" thanks to the iPhone 8 and iPhone X handsets, with the iPhone X going on sale Friday.Shares jumped to a record high Friday, closing up 2.6% to 172.50.RELATED:Apple Beats Earnings, Sales Targets, Guides Sales HigherApple Gives Rare Bullish Outlook As iPhone X Hits StoresFacebook reported blowout earnings and snapped a four-quarter string of decelerating revenue growth. But the social media giant said it sees faster growth in expenses. Facebook committed to step up spending to improve security on its platform, following two days of congressional hearings about the role Facebook, Google (GOOGL) and Twitter (TWTR) played in Russia's misinformation campaign during the U.S. presidential campaign. Facebook shares fell 2% on Thursday but closed the week with fractional gains and still in a buy zone.RELATED:Analysts Hail Blowout Earnings, But This Is Why Facebook Is DownChina e-commerce leader Alibaba reported better-than-expected fiscal second-quarter results. Annual active consumers on Alibaba's retail marketplaces reached 488 million, up 22% from a year ago. It ended the quarter with 549 million mobile monthly active users, up 20 million from the previous quarter. But shares, which had run for several days to record highs heading into earnings, dipped following the report.Alibaba Earnings, Revenue Beat Estimates On Strong E-CommerceThe third-quarter adjusted loss and cash burn were much worse than expected and Tesla revealed continued Model 3 rollout woes. Tesla now expects to hit a production rate of 5,000 Model 3 vehicles per week by late in the first quarter of 2018, pushing back plans by about four months. Tesla shares fell 6.8% on Thursday, hitting a six-month low.RELATED:Tesla Third-Quarter Results Show A Big Miss As Model 3 Woes PersistThe U.S. economy added 261,000 jobs in October, less than expected, but there were notable upward revisions to their prior two months affected by hurricanes. The unemployment rate dipped to a new cycle-low of 4.1%. Average hourly wages were flat vs. September. Meanwhile, the ISM manufacturing index pulled back from a longtime high but still showed factory activity is expanding rapidly.RELATED:Jobless Rate Sinks To 4.1% But Wages Slip In October; Payrolls Up 261,000President Trump tapped Federal Reserve Gov. Jerome "Jay" Powell to succeed Janet Yellen as chair of the U.S. central bank when her term expires in February. Wall Street breathed a bit easier when it became clear that Powell would get the nod, because he is expected to follow Yellen's low-interest-rate path. Powell, a Republican and former investment banker who served in the George H.W. Bush Treasury Department, may be somewhat more amenable than Yellen to easing post-crisis bank regulations, a Trump priority. The Yellen-led Fed kept rates steady on Wednesday, but all signs point to a December hike.RELATED:Federal Reserve Holds Rates Steady, But December Hike ComingNeurocrine Biosciences (NBIX), Exelixis (EXEL) and Juno Therapeutics (JUNO) rose after demolishing views, but Clovis Oncology (CLVS) dove as it widely missed. Incyte (INCY) reported better-than-expected metrics and an expanded cancer deal with AstraZeneca (AZN). But the Dow's Pfizer (PFE) and Allergan (AGN) were both soft on revenue and narrowed their full-year sales outlooks. Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) earnings missed and the drugmaker cut full-year forecasts citing challenges facing Copaxone and generic drugs, adding to industry concerns about pricing. On Tuesday, a sweeping antitrust lawsuit vs. generic drugmakers was expanded to include a total of 18 companies and the president of Mylan (MYL). Meanwhile, Bluebird Bio (BLUE) and Juno popped on preliminary data in, respectively, sickle cell disease and aggressive lymphoma.RELATED:Teva Dives On 'Long Road Ahead' After Earnings Miss, Guidance CutHow Blood-Disease Data Sent These 2 Biotech Stocks FlyingDow's Pfizer Falls As Legacy Medicines ChallengedNeurocrine, Exelixis, Juno Stocks Rocket After Crushing ViewsShale operators generally showed spending discipline in the third quarter as investors shift their focus from production growth to cash growth and spending within cash flow. But Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) boosted its capital spending outlook. Concho Resources (CXO), Devon Energy (DVN) beat on the bottom line while Anadarko Petroleum (APC) missed. But guidance may not have been strong enough, as Activision reversed lower from record highs on Friday. Nintendo (NTDOY) nearly doubled its profit outlook for the current fiscal year thanks to its Switch console and exclusive games like "Super Mario Odyssey." Nintendo now expects to ship 14 million Switch consoles in its financial year ending in March, up from its previous prediction of 10 million. EA (EA) stock fell after the publisher forecast lower-than-expected sales for the holiday quarter. Sprint's valuation and management control seemed to be the stumbling blocks. But by late in the week the talks were said to be back on.Ford Motor (F) grew new car sales 6% in October as consumer demand for utility vehicles and trucks continued to intensify. Its F-series trucks were especially brisk sellers. General Motors (GM) saw sales slide 2%, but did better than expected. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) sales dropped 13%, worse than estimates, as it slashes low-margin fleet sales The annualized pace of U.S. auto sales last month was 18.09 million, according to Autodata. That was down from 18.6 million in September, which saw strong post-hurricane demand for replacement vehicles. Shares of Melco Resorts & Entertainment (MLCO), Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and other casino operators that do business in Macau dropped Friday on weak tourism trends reported so far during China's National Day "Golden Week" holiday, which is typically a massive week for travel in the nation.XThe figures, if they hold, would run against more bullish expectations for casinos during the holiday, which this year runs from Oct. 1 through Oct. 8 — a day longer than in years past.That extra day had prompted some observers to dub this year's holiday "Super Golden Week," and hopes were further lifted earlier this month, when Macau reported better-than-expected September gaming revenue.According to Bloomberg, tourist arrivals from mainland China were down 1.1% in the holiday's first five days. Over that time a year earlier, arrivals from China tourists were up 7.3%.The Macau Government Tourism Office had expected a 5% increase in visits during the holiday this year, according to a Barclays research note published this week. That note said that a "majority of 3- to 5-star hotels in Macau are fully booked for the holiday."Melco Resorts & Entertainment closed down 1.75% at 23.56 in the stock market today, although it was still in buy range from a cup with handle base with a 23.35 buy point. Las Vegas Sands fell 1.2% to 64.26. That stock is forming a base with a 66.32 buy point and tried to break out past a 65.01 entry from a handle in the pattern.Wynn Resorts dropped 2% to 143.94, still in buying territory, while MGM Resorts International (MGM) dipped 0.3% as it is less exposed to Macau.IBD'S TAKE: As an investor, you may wonder why buy points are important. The chart action of these top stocks offers an answer.Meanwhile, among more U.S.-exposed casino operators, shares of Penn National Gaming (PENN) eased 0.2%, after jumping 5% Thursday on a Wall Street Journal report that it has been in merger talks with Pinnacle Entertainment (PNK).The discussions were described as intermittent with both sides unable to agree on any terms, but Penn National is still interesting in buying its smaller rival.Pinnacle climbed 3.2% Friday, adding to Thursday's 8.4% surge. Both stocks are extended above buy range.RELATED:Casino Stocks Pressured On Mass Shooting; MGM Delays Opening Macau HotelWhy This Macau-Centric Casino Operator Is Breaking Out TodayStocks At Record Highs: MGM Down; This Top Bank Attempts Breakout

Stocks stepped higher at Monday's open, with the Nasdaq easily outpacing its peers just after the starting bell.X The Nasdaq Composite popped 0.2%, despite Apple (AAPL) posting an early decline and as all four of the FANG stocks moved higher.The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%, the S&P 500 opened up less than 0.1%.The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.1% for the month of September, while the S&P 500 climbed 1.9% and the Nasdaq notched a 1.1% gain. For the third quarter, the three indexes knocked out gains of 5.1%, 4% and 5.8%, respectively.Monthly housekeeping data should begin to roll in Monday as airlines turn in September passenger traffic numbers, ahead of monthly sales figures due out from automakers Tuesday. This week's market will have a keen eye on the Labor Department's September payrolls report, due out early Friday.Researcher Markit releases its October manufacturing purchasing managers index at 9:45 a.m. ET. The Institute for Supply Management follows up with its manufacturing index, and the Commerce Department reports August construction spending estimates, both at 10 a.m. ET.Dallas Federal Reserve Bank President Robert Kaplan speaks at 2 p.m. ET.The Las Vegas strip was largely shut down Monday morning after a 64-year-0ld gunman opened fire on a crowd of visitors to an outdoor concert Sunday night, reportedly killing at least 50 people and injuring more than 400. The gunman, identified by police as local resident Stephen Paddock, was killed by officers, according to the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department.Casino stocks were under some early pressure, with Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dipped 0.6%, Las Vegas Sands (LVS) traded 1% lower. MGM Resorts International (MGM), which owns the Mandalay Bay Hotel from which the shooting reportedly took place and where the shooter was killed, fell 3% in opening trade.More than half of the Dow Jones industrial stocks gained ground a the open.Walt DisneyDIS staked out an early lead, rising 1%.  Visa (V) gained 0.4% after Buckingham Research initiated coverage on the stock with a buy rating and a 129 price target. Chevron (CVX) was the early laggard, down 1%.Apple dipped 0.2%, while the FANG stocks posted narrow gains ahead at the open. Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google will hit the spotlight today as it rolls out new products expected to include a Pixel 2 smartphone and a high-end Chromebook. Alphabet was up 0.2% at the opening bell, trading 3% below a 1006.29 buy point.On the S&P 500, Nordstrom (JWN) and Dentsply Sirona (XRAY) each opened down 0.6%. Dentsply announced that its chairman, chief executive and chief operating officer had all unexpectedly resigned.IBD's TAKE:  The two keys to success in growth stock investing is disciplined research and protecting capital. Drugmaker Dynavax (DVAX) vaulted 7% in early trade.New issue Roku (ROKU) dived 4%, as the volatile, two-day old stock continued to feel for equilibrium. The Nasdaq-traded IPO launched Thursday, ending Friday 89% above its IPO price.Railcar and guard-rail maker Trinity Industries (TRN) rumbled ahead 11% after a New Orleans appeals court judge on Friday overturned a $663 million fraud verdict against the company. The stock ended Friday just out of buy range, more than 5% above a 30.23 buy point in an eight-month saucer base.A number of IBD 50 stocks were showing premarket strength.China-based YY (YY) jumped 1.4%, moving shares of the social-networking site ended Friday beyond buy range, above a cup-base buy point at 83.10.Chip developer Nvidia (NVDA) tacked on an early 0.8% advance. The IBD 50 stock remains in a buy range, 3% above a 174.66 buy point in a five-week flat base.RELATED: Tesla, Ford, Google Pixel, Jobs Lead Weekly Investing PlanNvidia Leads These 5 IBD 50 Stocks In Buy Range Follow The Market: Stock Market TodayUnderstand The Market: The Big Picture

Casino stocks initially fell Monday but ended mixed as markets reacted to a mass shooting at a music festival in Las Vegas and MGM Resorts' (MGM) announcement that its China unit would delay opening its newest casino in Macau.XLas Vegas Metropolitan Police Department Sheriff Joseph Lombardo said 58 were killed and 515 were injured, after a gunman opened fire outside the Route 91 Harvest country music festival, via a room at the Mandalay Bay Casino, which is operated by MGM.The suspected shooter has been identified as Stephen Paddock, who reportedly committed suicide before police entered his hotel room. The incident is seen as the worst mass shooting in modern U.S. history.MGM shares sank 5.6% to close at 30.77 on the stock market today. The casino operator's shares had been hovering around their 50-day line after a breakout on Sept. 7 failed. Despite a big push into China, MGM is still the most U.S.-exposed casino operator.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell 1.2% to 147.07, but still above buy range after breaking out of a flat base on Sept. 1 with a 139.77 buy point, while Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rose 1.3% to 64.97, just below its 65.01 buy point as it tries to break out of a cup with handle base.American Outdoor Brands (AOBC), formerly known as gunmaker Smith & Wesson, rose 3.2%, and Sturm Ruger (RGR) climbed 3.5%. Gun stocks typically have rallied immediately after mass shootings on expectations that demand will spike amid talk of new laws curbing gun sales.IBD'S TAKE: As an investor, you may wonder why buy points are important. The chart action of these top stocks offers an answer.Also Monday, MGM China Holdings said it would delay the opening of its new casino on the Cotai strip section of Macau to early next year from the second half of 2017 due to damage from Typhoon Hato in August. Casino stocks typically see their biggest bumps around new openings.September gambling revenue from Macau, China's only legal gambling district, jumped 16% to $2.7 billion, according to its Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau Sunday. Revenue has now risen for 14 straight months in the region.Melco Resorts & Entertainment (MLCO), a Hong Kong-domiciled firm with Macau casinos, dipped 0.1%.RELATED: Why This Macau-Centric Casino Operator Is Breaking Out TodayMGM Resorts International Shows Rising Relative Strength; Still Shy Of Key Threshold

Your stocks to watch this week are five hotels and casinos that are trading in buy range: Hilton Worldwide (HLT), Marriott International (MAR), Hyatt Hotels (H), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco Resorts (MLCO). But just because they are in buy zones, doesn't mean you shouldn't keep an eye on other key factors, like volume, as well as the major averages and leading stocks.Hilton Worldwide on Friday cleared a 67.89 buy point from a three-month long cup base. Though Hilton gained 1.3% to 68.19, volume on the breakout was below average.Marriott International is flirting with a 107.73 buy point from a double-bottom base. Heavy volume on Wednesday, when Marriott first cleared the entry, has been followed by light turnover. Marriott rose 0.3% to 107.88 on Friday, back above the entry, but in light trade.IBD'S TAKE: Looking for more actionable stocks? Make sure to check out MarketSmith's screener tools. You can filter recent breakouts, stocks hitting new highs, tight trading action and more. Take a risk-free trial of MarketSmith.Hyatt Hotels has been on a steady climb since coming off the Aug. 18 bottom of its cup base, and shares are now trading within the buy zone from a 61.17 entry, closing the week at 61.29. Ready to yawn? Volume has been well below average for Hyatt, too.Among casinos, Wynn Resorts remains in buy range after breaking out of a flat base with a 139.77 buy point on Sept. 1. Wynn has been trading more or less sideways at the top of the buy zone since, and volume has dried up. Wynn fell 0.3% to 144.91 on Friday.Melco Resorts broke out of a base last Tuesday, edged above the 5% buy zone intraday Wednesday and is now trading just above the 23.35 buy point, finishing the week at 23.53. Melco's volume was above average for the initial breakout, but the action has cooled.We've been seeing stalling action for many breakouts as of late, with the Nasdaq moving more or less sideways for the month of September. Ideally, you want to see strong volume on a breakout with the stock extending its gains, rather than sluggish, low-volume action within the buy zone.RELATED:Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksS&P 500, Nasdaq Are Trading At Highs, But Big Winners LackingLeaderboard: Daily Updates On Stocks With Potential For Big Gains

Shares of Wynn Resorts (WYNN) continued to dive on Monday following sexual-misconduct allegations last week against CEO Steve Wynn, as analysts began to parse out the possible fate of the CEO and his company, with one suggesting it could ultimately be sold.X The stock tumbled 9.3% to 163.48 in the stock market today in extremely high volume following a 10% plunge on Friday when a Wall Street Journal report detailed allegations from women who said Wynn pressured them into sexual activity. Wynn Resorts closed below its 50-day moving average, a sell signal given the heavy trading.Wynn has said the notion that he "ever assaulted any woman is preposterous."Wynn Resorts' board of directors has formed a committee to investigate the allegations. Regulators from Massachusetts and Nevada are examining the matter. Wynn resigned as the Republican National Committee's finance chairman.The growing scrutiny from regulators has raised questions about how much investors would stand by the company, and how the company might move past the potential loss of one of the industry's biggest innovators. Annual reports from the company cite "our dependence on Stephen A. Wynn" as among its risk factors, Barclays noted.And the moves out of Nevada and Massachusetts have raised questions over whether the axis of gambling in the east, Macau — where Wynn Resorts gets most of its sales — might do the same. The company is also seeking a license for a resort in Japan.The research firm Union Gaming and Morgan Stanley both downgraded Wynn Macau in the wake of the allegations. Bloomberg noted that gaming laws in Macau, a Chinese administrative region, factor in the operator's reputation during the bidding for licenses.Barclays analyst Felicia Hendrix, in a research note, said business and leisure customers in Las Vegas, where Wynn's sales have slipped recently, could stay away in the near-term as the allegations damage the company's reputation. But she said sales in Macau were less likely to be affected.However, she said that a sale of the company, as opposed to just Wynn's shares, could be the most likely result from those allegations. The move, she argued, would help preserve the company's value overall, she said."The quality of WYNN's resorts globally is unprecedented, in our view, and there are a number of public companies (and likely private equity firms) that would be more than willing to acquire these assets if they were to come to the market," she wrote. "Further, there are a number of public companies which do not operate in Macau that would see this as a great opportunity.""So," she added, "demand could be high for this company if it were to be sold, which could limit the potential downside."The region — the only place in China where gambling is legal and the world's biggest market for gaming — did the heavy lifting for Wynn's results in the fourth quarter.Gaming sales in Macau jumped around 19% last year, as more VIPs overcame worries over regulator crackdowns in years past and returned more often to gamble there. But, as one analyst told IBD last year, "You can never relax about Macau," and fears of stiffer gambling rules in the region are never far from investors' minds.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) jumped 4.7%, while MGM Resorts International (MGM) added 2.65%. Melco Resorts & Entertainment (MLCO) dipped 0.25%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:NBA Backs Nationwide Sports Betting — For This PriceFord Mixed, Las Vegas Sands Beats, United Rental Profit Meets
