Amazon stock has struggled to regain its 50-day line for the past two months.Amazon this month got a big boost for its Echo device from Wynn Resorts (WYNN), which said it plans to equip each of the 4,748 guest rooms at the Wynn Las Vegas hotel with an Echo.The Echo-Wynn announcement came as Microsoft gave a sneak peek at a new hardware device that will rival Echo."We're at the beginning of a technological revolution in artificial intelligence," said a blog post by the Windows Apps Team. "The personal digital assistant is the interface where all the powers of that intelligence can become an extension of each one of us."Alphabet in October followed Amazon with the introduction of Google Home, a voice-activated speaker powered by the Google Assistant, which sells for $129.Apple is also in the game with its voice-activated Siri program on Apple iPhones, but has not yet signaled when it might introduce an in-home digital assistant. RELATED: Amazon Spreads Its Tentacles Far Beyond 'World's Biggest Bookstore'Amazon In Talks For Live Sports Package Available To Prime MembersAmazon Set To Disrupt Retailers In Apparel, Groceries, ServicesAmazon's Next Big Growth Opportunity Could Be Apparel

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and MGM Resorts (MGM) were initiated with buy ratings Thursday, Nike (NKE) was added to a "Best Ideas" list, and Micron Technology (MU) was upgraded after strong quarterly earnings.Las Vegas Sands was started with a buy rating and 60 price target at Aegis Capital. The firm also started MGM Resorts International with a buy rating and a 35 price target and started Wynn Resorts (WYNN) with a neutral rating and 87 price target.Last week, casino shares fell after China cracked down on cash withdrawals from its gambling enclave, Macau. Under the new ruling visitors can only withdraw 5,000 patacas ($646) at a time but shares rebounded after the Macau Monetary Authority said ATM users still have a daily withdrawal limit of 10,000 patacas.Las Vegas shares fell 0.6% to 54.22 on the stock market today. Wynn shares retreated 1.1% to 88.25. MGM climbed 0.2% at 29.33.The athletic gear giant was added to Guggenheim's "Best Idea" list as analysts are bullish on Nike's global brand appeal and expect revenue and margins to expand next year.Late Tuesday, Nike reported Q2 earnings above analyst views and said it sees "incredible momentum" in its basketball business and "tremendous potential" for sales growth in North America. But, despite downplaying the importance of "futures orders," analysts and investors took note when they came in weaker than expected.Nike shares fell 0.3% to 52.14 after gaining 1% on Wednesday.Micron was upgraded to buy from underperform at Needham with a 33 price target. Cowen raised its price target on the memory chipmaker to 26 from 23 and kept a buy rating on the stock.Late Wednesday, Micron reported Q1 earnings that easily topped Wall Street's estimates but sales fell short of expectations.Shares jumped  12.7% to 23.19.Red Hat (RHT) was downgraded to market perform from outperform at BMO Capital Markets and had its price target cut to 75 from 85.Mizuho kept a buy rating on the open-source Linux software provider but cut its price target to 80 from 88.Late Wednesday, Red Hat reported Q3 revenue that fell short of Wall Street views and issued Q4 sales guidance below analyst expectations.Red Hat share tumbled 13.9% to 68.71.Finish Line (FINL) was downgraded to neutral from buy at Monness Crespi & Hardt and was downgraded to neutral from outperform by Wedbush, which also lowered the shoe retailer's price target to 20 from 25.Late Wednesday, Finish Line reported a Q3 loss worse than analysts predicted and sales well below estimates as apparel and accessories sales fell sharply. Looking ahead to Q4, the company only sees earnings per share of 68-73 cents vs. analyst views of 95 cents.Shares fell 5.3% to 19.89 after tumbling 8.7% on Wednesday.RELATED:Nvidia Hailed As 'Unique Growth Story'; MGM Is A Buy, Ciena OverweightAnalysts Bullish On Netflix, Alphabet; Nike Price Target Cut Despite EarningsUnited Technologies, Costco Upgraded; Shale Producers Mixed

Japan's parliament passed a bill legalizing casinos early on Thursday, paving the way for billions of dollars of potential investment after years of political wrangling.The revised casino bill was passed in both houses, Kyodo News reported, after hours of delaying tactics by the opposition. Details of the so-called integrated resorts must be laid out in a separate implementation bill before any casinos can be built — meaning none is likely to open its doors in time for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.International gaming companies have been mulling investments in Japan amid a boom in tourism, particularly from China. Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) are among the operators that have expressed interest. Opening two integrated resorts in major population centers could bring in $10 billion in revenue, with potential for $30 billion if they spread across the country, according to a report by CLSA this month."This is a landmark occasion and should be a shot in the arm as it relates to investor sentiment in all gaming names that could be players in Japan," Grant Govertsen, an analyst at Union Gaming, said in a research note.Some members of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's junior coalition partner Komeito, which is backed by a Buddhist group, have been reluctant to accept legalization because of concerns over gambling addiction and money laundering. A duty to tackle addiction is included in the revised bill, as is a requirement to review legalization within five years."We have to pay close attention to the implementation bill," said Satoshi Sakamoto, who has been tapped by Konami Holdings Corp. to head a new company in Japan to invest in casinos after the legislation passes. "If we are going to have casinos in Japan, we will establish the best regulations in the world, along with the personnel and systems to enforce them. It's important that we create facilities where guests have a safe and pleasant experience."Japan already allows gambling on horse, boat and bicycle racing, while the pinball-like game of pachinko has spawned its own addicts. A survey published by public broadcaster NHK this week found only 12% of respondents were in favor of lifting the casino ban, with 44% opposed and the remainder unsure.The bill was previously abandoned after being submitted to Parliament in 2013 and debate was delayed after a second submission last year. It was rushed through this session after discussion was reopened on Nov. 30.Komeito leader Natsuo Yamaguchi was quoted by Kyodo News as saying earlier this month many people felt the discussion period had been too short. With a majority in both houses, Abe's LDP no longer needs Komeito to help it pass legislation, although it does rely on its ally for electoral support.Yokohama and Osaka have been touted as potential venues for the first casino resorts, while Tokyo Gov. Yuriko Koike has not come out clearly in favor of a venue in the capital.

Amazon (AMZN) got a big boost for its Echo device from Wynn Las Vegas, which Wednesday announced plans to equip all 4,748 rooms at the hotel with the voice-controlled speaker system that's infused with artificial intelligence — and that could evolve into the next major disruption in computing.The announcement by Wynn Resorts (WYNN) comes as Microsoft (MSFT) gave a sneak peek at a new hardware device that looks similar to Echo. The device has the Harman (HAR) label but is voice-controlled through Cortana, Microsoft's artificial intelligence platform. Harman is a developer of high-quality speakers, which Samsung Electronics is spending $8 billion to acquire. Microsoft said the device will ship in 2017.Google-owner Alphabet (GOOGL) is also in on the game for personal digital assistants in the home. Alphabet in October followed Amazon with the introduction of Google Home, a voice-activated speaker powered by the Google Assistant, which sells for $129.But Amazon was first to market with Echo — an in-home, voice-activated digital butler that plays music, reads books and provides traffic and weather, among other things. Teamed with Alexa, its voice and brains, the Echo smart speaker has grabbed a post position in the race to give the world the best and smartest digital assistant.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon, Apple, Alphabet and Microsoft are strengthening their connection to customers with mobile and in-home devices infused with advanced speech recognition and artificial intelligence. The devices could evolve into the next major disruption in computing and put the smart home on a fast track.Amazon won't say, but analysts estimate it's already sold about 5 million Echo speakers, at prices ranging from about $100 to $200. It's a product that further cements a user's attachment to Amazon.Echo will be added to every guest room at Wynn Las Vegas hotel, starting this month. Guests can control various hotel room features with a series of voice commands.Wynn Resorts CEO Steve Wynn heaped praise on Alexa."As we have moved through the years, technology has always played an important part in our resorts," Wynn said in a press release. "The thing that Amazon has done with Alexa is quite perfect. If I have ever seen anything in my 49 years of developing resorts that has made our job of delivering a perfect experience to our guests easier and help us get to another level, it is Alexa."While Microsoft did not announce a personal digital assistant it gave a partial view of the device, which looks similar to Echo. In the video a person addresses the device as "Cortana"before asking questions. The Cortana platform is currently available on mobile devices and PCs. Microsoft said there are 145 million Cortana users."We're at the beginning of a technological revolution in artificial intelligence," said a blog post by Windows app team. "The personal digital assistant is the interface where all the powers of that intelligence can become an extension of each one of us."Microsoft also announced a software developer's kit for the advancement of Cortana skills.Apple (AAPL) is also in the game with its voice-activated Siri program, but has not yet signaled when it might introduce an in-home digital assistant.Amazon stock ended trading down 0.7% to 768.82 on the stock market today, just below its 50-day moving average. The stock is consolidating, with an 847.31 buy point.Microsoft stock stayed on a roll Wednesday, touching a record high for the sixth consecutive trading day. Wednesday afternoon, shares were flat, near 63. The stock is extended from its last buy point of 58.80, touched on Oct. 21.RELATED:Amazon Prime Video Global Launch Includes India, Threatens Netflix Amazon Spreads Its Tentacles Far Beyond 'World's Biggest Bookstore'No Need To Ask Jeeves When You Can Ask Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Google

Shares of casino operators with big Macau operations rebounded Friday after the Chinese gambling enclave limited ATM withdrawals by less than a media report.The Macau Monetary Authority limited ATM withdrawals for China UnionPay cardholders to 5,000 patacas ($646) at a time, but the daily withdrawal limit of 10,000 patacas remains. The South China Morning Post had reported Thursday that the daily cap would be halved to 5,000 patacas as of Saturday.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rose 1.2% in the stock market today, but well off morning highs. MGM Resorts (MGM) climbed 2.1%, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) 1.3% and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) about 1%.Those gains recouped only a fraction of casino stocks' big Thursday losses.Cash withdrawals via UnionPay fuel much of the spending on casinos in Macau. UnionPay ATM withdrawals are used by nearly half the Chinese customers in Macau to obtain money for gambling, Bloomberg said, citing research from Bernstein.The withdrawal cap has been seen as an attempt by Chinese authorities to curb the outflow of yuan from China.RELATED:Macau Gaming Is Stabilizing, But Investors Already Made That BetTime To Bet On Casino Stocks As Macau Nears Turnaround?

Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) tumbled Thursday after the South China Morning Post reported China will slash China UnionPay users' ATM withdrawals in Macau, the world's No. 1 gambling market.The daily withdrawal limit will fall in half to 5,000 pacatas ($626), effective Saturday, the newspaper said.The move to cut the daily withdrawal limit from 10,000 to 5,000 patacas is expected to take effect from Saturday and follows the discovery that as much as 10 billion patacas in China UnionPay ATM withdrawals were made in one month alone.The Monetary Authority of Macau move is seen as a reaction to efforts to sidestep Beijing's 100,000 yuan annual withdrawal limit for UnionPay card holders as authorities seek to halt illegal outflows from the country.Macau's gaming revenue had finally been rising in recent months following a two-year slump spurred in part on corruption and money laundering crackdowns.Wynn Resorts opened the $4.2 billion Wynn Palace in August, followed by Sands' $2.9 billion Parisian Macau in September. MGM, which has been the least Macau-exposed of the big U.S. casino operators, will open the $3.1 billion MGM Cotai in 2017.Wynn Resorts fell 11% on the stock market today. Las Vegas Sands tumbled nearly 13%, MGM 4.3% and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment 13.7%. All but MGM, which reversed from an 8-year high, crashed through their 50-day moving averages.After the closing bell, Sands, Wynn, MGM and Melco all rose about 1%.RELATED:Macau Chief Has Conservative Outlook For Gaming Industry

Stocks opened higher Friday as investors looked to close out a solid week of trade.The S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the Nasdaq nearly 0.6%, both hitting fresh all-time highs. The Dow industrials climbed nearly 0.2%, just below Thursday's intraday record best.The market rolled into Friday's session with the Nasdaq up 3.1%, the S&P 500 ahead 2.5% and the Dow industrials sporting a 2.3% gain for the week. All three indexes are at new highs. Small caps once again outpaced the overall market, sending the Russell 2000 up 5.5% through Thursday, also to a new high, and nearly 20% above an early November low.Tech stocks appeared set for a strong start as Singapore-based Broadcom (AVGO) rolled ahead 4%. The diversified chipmaker topped analysts' fiscal fourth-quarter sales and earnings targets and doubled its quarterly dividend. The stock broke out of a base with a 178.12 buy point of a flat base.Finisar (FNSR) soared at the open, but then reversed to trade down slightly. The maker of fiber optic networking gear's fiscal second-quarter results, reported late Thursday, cleared expectations, driven primarily by demand for the company's 100-gigabit network transceivers.  The stock is extended above a flat base buy point of 31.52.Sibanye Gold (SBGL) tanked 15% and Stillwater Mining (SWC) surged 18% after the companies announced Sibanye would acquire Stillwater for $2.2 billion. The third acquisition of a platinum miner in the past year would make South Africa-based Sibanye the world's largest platinum producer. Stillwater is based in a Denver suburb.Casino owners were rebounding with gusto: Wynn Resorts (WYNN) jumped 3.4%, Las Vegas Sands (LVS) climbed 4.1%, Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) spun up 6.3% and MGM Resorts International (MGM) added 3.6%. The group sold off Thursday on reports that Chinese regulators had moved to limit ATM withdrawals in the country's gambling haven of Macau. Casino stocks rose after the ATM curbs were less than feared.Drug maker Biogen (BIIB) popped nearly 5%. Biogen's once-monthly multiple sclerosis treatment Zinbryta had received approval from federal health regulators in Canada. Also, Eli Lilly (LLY) gave detailed results on its failed Alzheimer's drug, following promising data Thursday on Biogen's own treatment. Biogen has been trying since July to climb out of a long-term consolidation, but has been stymied by resistance near 330.Among down-bound stocks, Restoration Hardware (RH) plunged 16% as investors focused on weak fourth-quarter guidance, rather than strong third-quarter results in the company's report after Thursday's close. The stock has been trying since June to start up the right side of what is now a deep, 13-month correction.Economic news is limited on the stock market today, with the University of Michigan reporting its November consumer confidence numbers and the Commerce Department releasing October wholesale inventories data, both at 10 a.m. ET. Baker Hughes (BHI) delivers its weekly rig count at 1 p.m. ET.Oil futures traded modestly higher as West Texas Intermediate held above $51 per barrel, down less than 1% for the week, which would be the first price decline in four weeks.Gold traded down 0.5% to $1,167 an ounce. The dollar rose, and was sharply higher vs. the yen. Bonds flattened, leaving the 10-year yield at 2.41%.In China, indexes in Shanghai and Hong Kong again ended mixed Friday, leaving the Shanghai Composite down 0.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 0.8% for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 pounded out a second straight rally Friday, rising 1.2% to take a 3% gain in a fifth straight weekly advance.Stocks in Europe extended their gains in afternoon trade: the CAC 40 in Paris was up 0.5%, the FTSE 100 in London rose 0.2%, while Frankfurt's DAX held to a 0.2% gain.RELATED:Broadcom, Finisar Price Targets Hiked Las Vegas Sands, Wynn, MGM Dive As China Halves Macau ATM WithdrawalsLockheed, Northrup, Raytheon Get Trumped: Investing Action Plan

Amazon (AMZN) has launched Amazon Prime Video in 200 countries, including India but not China, ratcheting up the competition with Netflix (NFLX) in online streaming.Amazon Prime Video had been in just five countries. Netflix airs in some 190 countries, with China the only major holdout. Amazon focused on India with its announcement."India has one of the richest and most vibrant entertainment industries in the world," Roy Price, head of Amazon Studios, said in the company's press release. "It's no secret that Amazon is making a big investment in India and is happy to take original content, created by Indian talent, to audiences worldwide."Amazon — which originally billed itself as "the world's biggest bookstore" — is moving full throttle into video services, as well as delivery services, online video and music services, tablets, personal digital assistants, and no doubt more arenas besides e-commerce and cloud services. Even physical stores are now part of the plan.Just on Wednesday alone, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos tweeted out the company's first delivery via drone, and Wynn Las Vegas announced it would equip each of its rooms with an Amazon Echo smart speaker.IBD'S TAKE: For much of 2016, you would have found Amazon on the IBD Leaderboard. Only the best stocks at or near buy points make this exclusive list. See which of the FANG stocks currently makes the list.Amazon stock fell 0.69% to 768.96 in the stock market today, and has been trading below its 50-day moving average for nearly six weeks. The stock is consolidating, with an 847.31 buy point.Amazon Prime Video will be bundled with Amazon Prime subscribers in 19 countries and is available at no additional cost to subscribers in India, France, Canada, Belgium and Italy and Spain. Customers in the other new Prime Video territories can sign up at an introductory price of $2.99 per month for the first six months, starting with a free seven-day trial at PrimeVideo.com, the company said.Amazon does not say how many customers it has to Amazon Prime, which is available in the U.S. for $99 per year and gets them access to Amazon Prime Video, as well as streaming music, free delivery of goods ordered on Amazon, access to special deals and more. Analysts estimate there are currently about 55 million Amazon Prime customers.Netflix reported having 86.7 million customers worldwide in its third quarter earnings statement, of which 36 million are outside the U.S. Netflix, in addition to the increased competition from Amazon is confronting a more aggressive Hulu, which plans to launch a live streaming TV service in 2017, in addition to its original and third-party content. Hulu is co-owned by Walt Disney (DIS) NBCUniversal parent Comcast (CMCSA) 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner (TWC)Also, this month, Amazon announced it added HBO and Cinemax to Amazon Channels for a monthly fee, upping its battle with Disney, AT&T (T) and other providers of video streaming services, in addition to Netflix.Amazon's new offerings follow AT&T's launch of DirecTV Now, the latest contender to enter the over-the-top streaming service arena.RELATED:Amazon's Threat To Netflix Grows As Video Content Spending Booms Amazon In Talks For Live Sports Package Available To Prime MembersAmazon Set To Disrupt Retailers In Apparel, Groceries, ServicesAmazon's Next Big Growth Opportunity Could Be ApparelBoost In Technology Budgets Benefits Amazon, Microsoft, SalesforceAmazon Stock Hits Another High As Amazon Prime Users Keep 'Ramping'

The leading indexes ended higher after a back-and-forth session Thursday, as stocks climbed after the opening bell for about half the day, then began to trim gains.The Nasdaq rose 0.6% to an early afternoon peak, then settled to close 0.4% higher. The S&P 500 pitched up and down for an hour after the open, and closed 0.2% higher. The Dow industrials added 0.3%.Small caps had a good day. The S&P Smallcap 600 jumped 1.5%. The index's 21st gain in the past 25 sessions left it comfortably at a record high.Investors had mixed opinions on the European Central Bank's decision to extended its quantitative easing stimulus through December 2017, although it said it would trim its monthly bond-buying efforts to near $64 billion, from $86 billion, beginning in April. Eurozone markets rallied, with led by a 1.8% gain from the DAX in Frankfurt.Stock s also received mixed input from U.S. weekly jobless claims data, which were positive, but not down as much as economists had expected.Goldman Sachs (GS) led the Dow by a broad stride, ending up 2.4% in heavy volume. The stock is extended after clearing a 17-month consolidation.The rebounding Edwards Lifesciences (EW) outpaced all other S&P 500 stocks with a 7% gain. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) took the index's hardest hit, down 11% as regulators in China moved to limit ATM withdrawals in the country's gambling haven of Macau.Consumer lenders were among the day's clear winners, outpacing all other industry groups. China-based Yirendai (YRD) popped more than 5%. That lifted the IBD Global Leaders Stock back above its 50-day line within a four-month base-building effort.In the same group, Michigan's Credit Acceptance (CACC) rumbled up 7%, clearing a 210.09 buy point. The stock is thinly traded.Fiber-optic stocks also figured into Thursday's upside, with Ciena (CIEN) storming up 14% after its mixed fiscal fourth-quarter results included an order backlog of $1.15 billion, which management claimed was the company's "highest ever."  The gain left the stock extended past a couple of alternative buy points. The standard buy point was at 23.19 in a double-bottom base.Also in the fiber optics group, Lumentum Holdings (LITE) bolted 10% higher, clearing the 42.60 buy point of a cup with a deep handle.Finisar (FNSR) charged ahead 5% in heavy trade, putting it 7% above a 31.52 buy point from a flat base. After the close, shares rallied as the company reported quarterly adjusted profit of 58 cents a share, an increase of 132%.RELATED:Finisar Earnings, Outlook Top Views As Optical Party Continues LateCiena Surges On Order Backlog

The head of Macau's government gave a conservative forecast Tuesday for gambling revenue next year that's 13% below analyst estimates amid a nascent recovery in the world's biggest casino hub.Macau's government is confident the economy will recover to grow in the low single-digits in 2017, Chief Executive Fernando Chui said at a briefing Tuesday. Chui's gambling revenue target is unchanged from his  forecast for 2016, as the government seeks to limit the growth of its casino industry and pushed operators such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Galaxy Entertainment Group to focus on tourists instead of hard-core gamblers."We didn't set a higher target than this year because we think there are still uncertain factors," Chui said, referring to his gaming revenue forecast of $25 billion for 2017. That compares with the median estimate of $28.8 billion from five analysts surveyed by Bloomberg.Shares of Las Vegas Sands, which opened a new Macau resort in September and reported a 19% increase in visitors to its properties there that month, gained 1.6% to $57.93 in midday trades Tuesday. Wynn Resorts (WYNN), which also recently opened an additional resort in Macau, climbed 3%, while MGM Resorts (MGM) rose 0.8%.Macau's casino industry has been recovering since August from 26 straight months of revenue declines as operators open family-friendly resorts, while a two-year slump in its gross domestic product has also eased. The city's shift from high-stakes Chinese bettors comes amid President Xi Jinping's efforts to curb official corruption and limit capital outflow, ordering Macau to diversify from gambling during his visit two years ago.Macau's recovery comes as China signals a crackdown on foreign casinos that woo its citizens to gamble overseas, detaining 18 employees of Australia's Crown Resorts involved in marketing to high-rollers. Macau's gaming regulator chief Paulo Chan met with the city's six casino operators after the incident, reminding them to obey local laws when working outside the gambling hub and adding that Macau gaming won't be affected by the arrests.Speaking at a casino industry event in Macau on Tuesday, Chan said the government will continue strengthening its laws to regulate the city's gaming industry. The gaming regulator also has had several discussions on raising entry barriers for junket operators, middlemen who bring in mainland Chinese players and lend them money to play with, he said.Analysts expect gambling revenue for 2016 will comfortably exceed Chui's forecast, with the median of four estimates for $27.6 billion, a decline of 4.5% from 2015. Macau already has reported $23.1 billion in gambling receipts in the first 10 months of this year."The government has historically, and rightly, presented a conservative forecast as it relates to gross gaming revenue," Grant Govertsen, a Macau-based gaming analyst at Union Gaming Group LLC, said by email. "Based on trends we're seeing today, we remain comfortable with our expectations for mid-single digit growth next year."

MGM Resorts' (MGM) third-quarter results topped estimates, and management is upbeat on the Las Vegas market, while rivals have seen disappointing results from Macau.On Monday, MGM said earnings soared 675% to 93 cents per share, including items related to the Borgata acquisition and a charge related to the NV Energy exit. Adjusted EPS was 53 cents. Wall Street analysts were expecting 9 cents. Total revenue rose 20% to $2.73 billion, above views for $2.39 billion.MGM shares ended 2.9% higher at 27.18 on the stock market today, rising above buy range after breaking out from a 25.39 buy point in September.MGM, which has a smaller footprint on Macau than Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) do, said domestic net revenue rose 16% to $1.9 billion, while same-store revenue was up 8%. Domestic casino revenue climbed 23% on the Borgata acquisition in Atlantic City and an increase in both table games and slots revenue. Room revenue rose 14%."We continue to see strength in the Las Vegas market and believe that the company can drive growth across all room segments in the fourth quarter, despite a challenging comparison," said CEO Jim Murren in a release. "Based on these current trends, we remain confident in our ability to further increase room revenues in 2017."In China, net revenue fell 6% to $500 million but revenue from main floor table games increased 21% year-over-year.MGM China, which is majority owned by MGM Resorts, said Q3 revenue rose 11% from Q2, and Macau's gross gaming revenue was up 7% sequentially.IBD'S TAKE: Macau appears poised for a rebound as gambling revenue in the administrative district's gaming industry rose 1.1% in August. But not all analysts are ready to be on it. Last week, Wynn Resorts reported Q3 earnings under analyst views, and revenue from its Wynn Palace resort in Macau's Cotai district fell short of exceptions.Wynn shares dipped 0.2% to 87.86 Monday.Also last week, Las Vegas Sands reported better-than-expected quarterly results, but revenue from its Macau resorts missed Wall Street exceptions.Shares lost 0.3% to finish at 58.89.RELATED: Casino Stocks: A Good Bet In A Dicey Market?

With Wynn Resorts (WYNN) expected to capture more Macau market share when its new $4.1 billion Wynn Palace opens in the next few months, at least one analyst is wagering on the company right now.Shares of the Las Vegas-based casino company rose 2.4% to 95 in the stock market today, rising as high as 96.60 intraday, after Morgan Stanley analyst Thomas Allen upgraded its stock to overweight from neutral, with a $120 price target.The 28-story, 1,700-room Wynn Palace hotel and casino will be the second resort that the company owns in Macau, the former Portuguese colony on China's southern coast that's grown into the world's top gambling destination. Wynn competes there with MGM Resorts International (MGM), Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) and others.Macau entered its worst-ever recession in mid-2014 amid slowing economic growth in China, a crackdown on corruption by the Chinese government and a partial smoking ban in Macau. Casino executives and many analysts have said that the region shows signs of stabilizing and could begin growing again as early as this year.Allen said in a report that there's still too much market risk in Macau to recommend both Wynn and Sands, the top two Macau casino operators, but he thinks that Wynn's expanding market share as it opens the new facility makes it "a good bet.""With Macau at least stabilizing, and Wynn going from a double-digit EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) decliner to double-digit grower in the next six months, we believe stock momentum can continue, given Wynn's long-term potential," Allen said in the report.After plunging 80% from its all-time intraday high of 249.31 in March 2014, Wynn stock bottomed at 49.95 on Jan. 15 of this year before turning up. It's nearly doubled in the last two months.  Its stock has an IBD Relative Strength Rating of 93.As expected, MGM Resorts International on Tuesday filed for an initial public offering of its real estate investment trust, MGM Growth Properties. The company announced the IPO, which is projected to be valued at about $1 billion, on its third quarter 2015 earnings call.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Tuesday, "Any multiple uplift from the IPO is largely in the stock." McKnight has an outperform rating on MGM, which rose fractionally to 20.96.Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino company, was flat at 53.27. Melco Crown Entertainment fell 1.35% to 16.85.

Stocks opened marginally lower Wednesday on the heels of Tuesday's resilient performance in light of the terror attacks in Belgium.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average all fell around 0.3%.Overseas action was quiet, with China's markets ending narrowly mixed and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 taking a 0.4% gain. In Europe, benchmark indexes in Paris and London showed modest gains while Frankfurt's DAX gained 0.7%.On the economic calendar, new-home sales numbers for February are expected from the Commerce Department at 10 a.m. ET. At 10:30, the Energy Information Administration releases its weekly oil inventories report.Oil prices declined 1% in the early going. West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude both traded between $41 and $42 per barrel. Gold slumped more than 1%, trading around $1,233 an ounce, down a bit less than 2% so far this week. The dollar rose vs. the euro and the yen, and bonds edged higher, pressuring the 10-year yield 1 basis point lower to 1.93%.Most Dow stocks were flat, but the index was busy at either extreme.Nike (NKE) dived 5% in early trading after a mixed fiscal Q3 report late Tuesday. Merck (MRK) gave back early premarket gains but still rose 0.4%. A California jury in a decade-long case found that two of Gilead Sciences' (GILD) blockbuster Hepatitis C drugs infringe on a Merck patent. Gilead's shares dropped more than 2%.Among Nasdaq 100 stocks, Applied Materials (AMAT) lost close to 1%. The chip equipment maker has gained in the past five sessions and is working on its sixth straight weekly advance as it scales up the right side of a 15-month pattern.Among IBD 50 stocks, Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) gave up 0.4%. The stock is struggling to regain its 10-week moving average and climb the right side of a five-month consolidation.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Prospects are improving for Macau-centric casinos like Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM), but they're not out of the woods yet, said Macquarie analyst Chad Beynon.He expects total Macau gambling revenue to shrink 6% this year, after sinking 24% in 2015, then go flat next year, and grow 3% in 2018.Macau went into recession in mid-2014 because gamblers and tourists stayed away in droves as China's economic growth began to cool, Chinese officials launched a nationwide crackdown on corruption, and Macau enacted a partial smoking ban.In a report on Friday, Beynon said that, based on a forecast model and channel checks, he has "positively adjusted" Macau market estimates, as well as company estimates. He maintained an outperform rating on his top pick, Sands, and raised his price target to 54 up from 48.He remains neutral on Wynn and lifted his price target to 70 from 63, saying Wynn "historically generates the highest EBITDA per table among gaming companies."He noted that both Wynn and MGM have delayed planned new Macau casinos. That's lowered total Macau gambling revenue but "will help overall industry margins."Beynon has an outperform rating on MGM and maintained a price target of 30.Shares of the big three Las Vegas casinos, which all depend in large part on Macau for growth, plus Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another top Macau casino operator, have collectively risen an average of about 57% since mid-January.Other analysts have projected a return to revenue growth for Macau, on a quarterly basis, could come as early as the second half of this year. In February, revenue was virtually flat.In a report on Friday, Deutsche Bank analyst Carlo Santarelli maintained a buy rating on Wynn and raised his price target to 94 from 82, saying, "we remain longer term bullish, given our favorable view of the Cotai (Macau) project, for which our current forecasts leave meaningful room for upward revisions."On March 7, UBS analyst Robin Farley said in a report about Macau-centric casino stocks, "Step up and pay today, or be constructive on a pullback." She added that "investors may have to pay more on entry now that the fundamentals are more clearly improving." Farley raised her rating on Wynn to buy from neutral, and lifted her price target to 95 from 73.Shares of Las Vegas Sands closed up 0.5% in the stock market today, up more than 50% from a Jan. 20 intraday low of 34.88. Wynn Resorts gapped up 5.9%, MGM rose 2.2%, and Melco Crown Entertainment added 4%.

Stocks climbed to comfortable gains Friday morning, with company news powering many of the most influential early moves.The Dow swung up 0.6%. The S&P 500 tacked on 0.4%, and the Nasdaq hung onto a 0.2% gain. Small caps were also in the running, with the Russell 2000 up 0.6%.Volume on the stock market today got a boost from options expirations, sending trade soaring 300% on the NYSE and 124% on the Nasdaq, compared with the number of shares trading at the same time Thursday.Consumer outlooks dimmed slightly in March, according to the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index. It slipped to a reading of 90 for the month, down from 91.7 in February and below consensus projections for a tally of 92.2.Oil prices added to their early gains. West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude both climbed nearly 2%, with WTI just below $41 a barrel and Brent above $42. Baker Hughes (BHI) reports its weekly rig count at 1 p.m. ET.JPMorgan (JPM) stepped off a 3% gain to lead the Dow. The investment banker announced late Thursday that the Federal Reserve had approved $1.88 billion in stock buybacks through the remainder of the second quarter, in addition to the bank's existing $6.4 billion buyback initiative.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rolled a 7% gain, leading the Nasdaq 100. The entire hotel/casino sector was in motion after Starwood Hotels (HOT) dumped a $12.2 billion merger deal with Marriott (MAR), in favor of a sweetened, $13.2 billion counter offer from Chinese insurance giant Anbang. Starwood was up 5% early Friday. Marriott added almost 2%.Adobe Systems (ADBE) pared its early gains to 5% after surging at the open. The cloud-based imaging and design software provider reported fiscal first-quarter results above consensus expectations late Thursday.  The stock is now extended nearly 7% above an 88.65 cup-with-handle buy point.Leading stocks kicked into action at the starting bell, with the IBD 50 list trading about half up half down.Stamps.com (STMP) posted a 4% advance, sending the stock back above a 114.36 buy point in heavy trade.Nvidia (NVDA) chipped up 3%, boost by Argus Research,which initiated coverage as a buy and with a 39 price target. The heavy-volume jump put shares just above a 33.16 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Shares of Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and other Macau-centric casino companies have rallied recently, but Sterne Agee CRT says the upward move may be too much, too soon.Sterne Agree CRT analyst David Bain downgraded Wynn on Friday to a neutral rating from buy, with an 85 price target. Bain said its stock may be rising too fast, given conditions in Macau. Investors ignored the report and Wynn stock continued its weeks-long climb.Bain noted that at the time he wrote the report, Las Vegas-based Wynn's shares had risen 46% since Feb. 10 (Wynn was up 49% from that point as of Friday afternoon).Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) also have large casino resorts in Macau and have seen their stocks rise at a rapid rate this month on an increasing number of upbeat indicators from the Chinese special administrative district.Bain sounded a note of caution about Wynn's Macau casinos, saying, "We believe upside is limited, especially with the backdrop of still continuing struggles in the VIP segment, which Wynn is more levered to versus peers."Wynn plans to open the Wynn Palace in Macau in the back half of 2016, but Bain said benefits from that new casino are already priced in and "the bear case may be underappreciated, given initial relatively soft results" of competitors' recent expansions.UBS on March 7 upgraded Wynn Resorts to buy from neutral, with a 95 price target. UBS analyst Robin Farley said in a report that conditions in Macau are stabilizing and this might be a good time for investors to consider getting back into casinos with Macau exposure.Macau's slump began in mid-2014 amid a weakening of China's economy, partial smoking ban on casinos and a crackdown by the Chinese government on corruption, which made some VIP category high rollers nervous.Wynn shares closed up 2.4% in the stock market today. After five straight quarters in which its earning per share growth shrank at a double-digit rate, year over year, analyst consensus is for Wynn's EPS to climb 9% this quarter.Las Vegas Sands rose 1.9% Friday. MGM Resorts International added 2.3%. Wynn, Sands and MGM were all trading above both their 50-day moving averages and their 200-day lines. Melco Crown Entertainment climbed 3.2%, above its 50-day, but still below the 200-day.Image provided by Shutterstock.

MGM Resorts International (MGM) got a pair of good reviews from Morgan Stanley and from activist investor Land and Buildings, pushing its stock price higher.In an open letter to MGM investors, Land and Buildings CEO Jonathan Litt chastised Wall Street for what he sees as the "distressingly low level" of MGM's stock price relative to its peers.A separate Morgan Stanley report said that MGM is the most-efficient operator in Macau, besting Las Vegas peers Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), as well as Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL).Land and Buildings severely criticized MGM early last year and successfully pushed the casino operator to separate its land holdings and free shareholder value. In a turnaround from last year, Litt in the letter praised MGM's recent performance, saying there are "multiple catalysts that should lead to substantial upside from current levels.""MGM is many analysts' top pick with 40% upside to target price of $28.50," Litt said, adding that "Fourth-quarter results and the outlook for 2016 are unambiguously robust." He added, however: "We will continue to watch the results of MGM very carefully to see if their actions back up their words."After losing 44% of its stock value in the last two years, MGM bottomed at 16.18 on Feb. 9 before turning up. It has climbed about 24% from that point and closed 3.7% higher in the stock market today.On Oct. 29, MGM complied with Land and Buildings' request and agreed to place 10 of its properties, including seven on the Las Vegas Strip, into a real estate investment trust that's 70% owned by the casino giant.As reported earlier, recent numbers in Macau, the former Portuguese colony turned gambling hot spot on China's southern coast, have pointed to an upturn there after the special administrative district, beginning in mid-2014 went through its worst-ever economic downturn.Morgan Stanley analyst Praveen Choudhary said in a report Wednesday that staff is the largest fixed cost item for Macau casinos, contributing up to 70% of operating expenses. Choudhary said on that basis, "MGM China generates higher EBITDA per person employed when compared to Wynn Macau," which traditionally had the best staff costs.In a comparison of all Macau operators, MGM China scored an 88 on employee efficiency costs in the Morgan Stanley report, vs. an 82 for Sands China, a 75 for Wynn Macau and 73 for Melco Crown Entertainment.Las Vegas Sands rose 2.25% and Wynn Resorts added 1.6%. Melco Crown climbed nearly 3.5%.

The stock market opened solidly higher Friday, helped by strength in global markets and rising oil prices.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average all rose around 1%.The stock market today sets out with the Nasdaq down 1.2% for the week and the S&P 500 off 0.5% in a well-deserved break after a three-week rally. The S&P 500 ended Thursday's session about 2% below its 200-day moving average after meeting resistance near that line several times throughout the week.  It had also tried and failed to retake support at the psychologically important level several times in December before diving to a deeper correction.The Nasdaq picked up a distribution day Thursday,  but its 0.3% decline didn't indicate heavy institutional selling. Still, the higher-volume decline raised the index's overall count to three distribution days -- not a danger sign, but also not what you'd like to see in a young uptrend and a reminder that defensive trading represents a large share of the market's recent action.Oil stocks packed the top of the S&P 500 in early trade, as oil prices bobbed more than 2% higher. West Texas Intermediate traded just below $39 a barrel, up almost 8% for the week. Brent crude traded near $41, with a weekly gain of more than 9%. Prices may see some effect from Baker Hughes' (BHI) weekly rig count data, due out at 1 p.m. ET.Dow stocks all had green lights, with half the components showing gains of 1% or better at the open. Caterpillar (CAT) and Chevron (CVX) were the early leaders, up about 2% each.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) soared 15% after reporting a strong Q4 performance late Thursday. E-commerce sales rose 44% during the quarter, and management announced a $200 million share buyback initiative. It's trying to clear a 188.58 in a 12-week consolidationHertz Global (HTZ) snapped 8% higher after a big upgrade, to overweight from underweight, from Morgan Stanley. The note reportedly said Hertz management was adopting a new strategic plan.  Hertz shares ended Thursday back above their 10-week moving average and 38% off a mid-February low. They remain deep in a nearly two-year correction.On the IBD 50 list, stocks traded flat to higher before the open.Ligand Pharmaceuticals (LGND) topped the group, rising more than 4.5%. The stock has been wrestling to clear its converged 10- and 40-week moving averages, trading just below a 106.08 buy point in a double-bottom base.Overseas, China's markets closed higher Friday, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index up 1.1% and essentially flat for the week. The Shanghai Composite added 0.2% Friday, taking a 2.2% loss for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 took a 0.5% gain on Friday, leaving it down 0.4% for the week.Europe's markets batted out solid advances near midday, with the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC 40 in Paris approaching 3% gains. Both indexes were tracing toward modest losses for the week.

Evidence continues to mount that Macau casinos are poised for recovery, which could give a boost to Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM).During the critical Chinese New Year holiday, gambling revenue on Macau was flat vs. a year earlier -- a sign of stabilization, as Macau's collective casino revenue has collapsed since mid-2014. UBS sees other signs of improvement."We have three quarters of sequential stabilization in mass (tourists and middle-class gamblers) revenues and now two quarters of sequential stabilization in VIP revenues," according to a Monday report, which also noted that gaming stocks with Macau exposure have risen 20% year to date.UBS upgraded Wynn to buy from neutral and lifted its price target to 95 from 73, citing "improved outlook and mitigating risk factors." UBS raised its price target on Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino company, to 52 from 45 and maintained a neutral rating.Wynn, Sands, MGM and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) all relied on Macau for the bulk of their growth until 2014, when the Chinese special administrative district across the strait from Hong Kong went into recession.The slump came amid slowing economic growth in China, a crackdown by the Chinese government on corruption, and a partial smoking ban that drove some gamblers away.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight in a March 4 report said that he, too, is seeing improvement in Macau, but he wasn't ready to call a bottom, noting that March is a better gauge of real demand, "free of Chinese New Year volatility and other noise."Wynn Resorts shares closed down 1.7% in the stock market today. Wynn has outperformed its peers recently. It's risen 69% since hitting a 17-year intraday low at 49.95 on Jan. 14 of this year. It's now trading above both its 50-day average and 10-week line.Las Vegas Sands fell 1.9%, but is up 47% from a Jan. 20 low at 34.88. MGM Resorts International ended flat, up about 23% from a Feb. 9 low. Melco Crown Entertainment skidded 3.55%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Terrorist bombings in Brussels set a grim tone early Tuesday, pressuring markets in both Europe and the U.S.The S&P 500 lost 0.4%, while the Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average gave back 0.3% each.Europe's markets dived immediately following the explosions in Brussels, then began paring losses. Travel and leisure issues remained under pressure, but healthy March German consumer sentiment data helped lift automaker stocks. Benchmark indexes in Paris, Frankfurt and London narrowed their declines to less than 0.5% near midday.The stock market today receives the January Housing Price Index from the Federal Housing Finance Agency at 9 a.m. ET.  At 9:45, researcher Markit reports its preliminary manufacturing sector estimate for March. Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans is scheduled to speak in Chicago at 1:30 p.m.Oil prices ebbed slightly after a 5% jump on Monday. West Texas Intermediate held above $41 per barrel. Gold rose almost 1% to near $1,253 an ounce. The dollar was up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds were effectively flat, with the 10-year yield down 1 basis point to 1.90%.Dow component Nike (NKE) edged higher ahead of its fiscal Q3 report due out after today's close. American Express (AXP) lagged on the Dow, falling 1.5%.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was an early gainer on the S&P 500, up nearly 4%, after Morgan Stanley upgraded the company to overweight with a PT of 120.At the bottom of the index, Transocean (RIG) sank 5% after its management and top brass at Schlumberger (SLB) said the recovery in oil field service and equipment demand will take even longer than previously expected.Travel-related stocks were clearly under pressure following events in Brussels. Priceline Group (PCLN) and Expedia (EXPE) slumped 3% each.  International air carriers including United Continental (UAL), Delta Air Lines (DAL) and American Airlines Group (AAL) were all down nearly 3%.Real estate date website Zillow (Z) surged 6% after RBC Capital Markets upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform and hoisted its price target to 34 from 21.

Odds are the Macau recession is nearing an end, and good times may soon be rolling again for Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN).Macau Gaming Inspection and Coordination officials said gambling revenue dipped 0.1% last month to 19.5 billion patacas ($2.4 billion), the smallest decline in 20 months and well above analyst consensus for a 2%-10% drop.Macau went into a deep slump, starting in mid-2014. A broad crackdown on corruption by the Chinese government kept some gamblers away from casinos, and a smoking ban and the slowdown of China's economy all combined to knock Macau's economy down.Union Gaming analyst Grant Govertsen said in a report Tuesday that "February was shaping up well and it delivered."Govertsen sees light at the end of the tunnel, but still in the distance. "We would then look to June as the most likely month to see a return to year-over-year growth, which would be exactly two years after the first y/y decline in June 2014."Last month, which included the Lunar New Year holiday and an extra leap year day, he noted that "revenue per day was 4% higher than the month that included the most recent major holiday period (October Golden Week)."Shares of Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino company by revenue, shot up 5% on the stock market today and have risen 37% from a Jan. 20 low.MGM Resorts climbed 5.3% and Wynn rose 2.5%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another Macau casino operator, rose 5.7%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Insiders at Facebook (FB), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) are among those who made notable trades during the week. The transactions came during a tumultuous week for the stock market, which was whipsawed by huge swings in oil prices and global growth fears. Facebook Jan Koum, a Facebook board member and the CEO of WhatsApp, filed on Wednesday with the…

Oil prices and earnings news aided a soft-volume rebound Friday, but the gains appeared fragile. The Dow industrials sprung from the starting gate Friday with 28 of 30 stocks trading higher, while more than half of the Nasdaq 100 issues declined.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were up 1.1% apiece, and the Nasdaq had gained 0.7% about one hour into the session.Early data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq tracking well below Thursday's levels.The stock market today had some positive economic news, with the Commerce Department reporting a sequential 0.2% rise in January retail sales. Sales rose 3.4% vs. the year-earlier period. The 0.2% rise was better than the 0.1% gain expected by economists. The Commerce Department also revised December's sales to a 0.2% gain, up from a 0.1% decline.Less positive was the University of Michigan's preliminary Consumer Sentiment Index for February. It dropped to 90.7 from 92, disappointing economists' expectations for an uptick to 92.5.Oil prices added to early gains, with West Texas Intermediate up nearly 8% to $28.20 a barrel. Brent crude was up 5% near $32. Gold stuck to its early losses, down 1% at $1,237 an ounce.But despite oil's strong influence, non-energy sector stocks led both the Dow and the S&P 500.JPMorgan (JPM) spiked more than 5% in heavy volume at the start of trade, retaking all of its loss from Thursday. News reports said Chairman and Chief Executive Jamie Dimon bought 500,000 shares of the stock as a show of confidence.Boeing (BA) dropped 1.4% as a JPMorgan analyst downgraded the stock to neutral, citing news of a Securities and Exchange Commission accounting probe that had sent shares down 7% Thursday. The note also trimmed Boeing's price target to 120, from 142.Activision-Blizzard (ATVI) dropped more than 10%, marking the worst loss on the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100. Chesapeake Energy (CHK) fell second furthest on the S&P 500, reversing its premarket gains and diving 7%.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) grabbed the top slot on both indexes, up more than 10% as Wall Street cheered its Q4 report.Among IBD 50 stocks, almost 4 in 5 stocks shifted higher in early trade.Online mortgage services provider Ellie Mae (ELLI) spiked 15% in huge trade. The Calif.-based outfit reported fourth-quarter earnings up 16%, far above consensus views. Sales rose 39% to $64.9 million. Management's full-year EPS and revenue guidance were also well above consensus expectations.Other advances on the list were more down to earth. A.O. Smith (AOS) posted the next-best gain, up nearly 3% in powerful volume. The heating and cooling equipment manufacturer recovered from a steep dive on Thursday, ending with a narrow advance. The stock is now trading up more than 1% for the week and fighting to climb the right side of a  seven-week consolidation.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Loading the player... After a week filled with declines, the stock market finally got a relief rally of sorts amid solid retail sales data, upside earnings reports and rebounding oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each rose 1.9% while the Nasdaq gained 1.7%. Volume was lighter across the board vs. Thursday, according to preliminary figures. Winners…

Stocks rolled out a fast start Tuesday, boosted by a surprise jump in January construction spending.The Nasdaq popped 1%, the S&P 500 jumped 0.8%, and the Dow industrials climbed 0.7%.Early trading volume on the stock market today swept higher, up 20% on the Nasdaq and up 33% on the NYSE vs. trade at the same time Monday.Early economic news was fair to middling, with researcher Markit reporting its final February manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index at 51.3.  That was down from January's 52.4 tally but even with economists' consensus. The report said production volumes rose at their slowest pace in 28 months, and job growth moderated to a five-month low.Construction spending jumped 1.5% in January, the Commerce Department said, well above expectations for a 0.5% improvement. The department also revised December spending upward to a 0.6% gain.The Institute for Supply Management's February manufacturing index edged up to 49.5 for February. The below-50 number still denoted contraction in the sector but was above January's 48.2 reading.Of the Dow stocks, 29 of 30 rose at the start of trade. Stocks with gains of more than 1% included DuPont (DD), IBM (IBM), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Apple (AAPL).  United Technologies (UTX) reversed its premarket gain and dropped 3% as Honeywell International (HON) announced it had dropped its merger efforts after being straight-armed by UTX.Garmin (GRMN), Qorvo (QRVO), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Ford (F) duked it out at the head of the S&P 500, all up around 3% apiece. Ford reported sales surged 20% year-over-year in February. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) said February sales rose 12%. General Motors (GM) turned in a 7% increase.Among IBD 50 stocks, New Oriental Education & Technology (EDU) popped 3% in powerful trade. The stock is trading 3% below a 33.01 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Fax and voicemail provider J2 Global (JCOM) also added nearly 3% in strong trade, rising to test resistance at its 50-day moving average. The stock is working to climb the right side of a possible two-month cup base.At the bottom of the list, Prestige Brand Holdings (PBH), Five Below (FIVE) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) all fell more than 1%.

Stocks futures were positive and ticking higher ahead of Friday's open as a number of stocks and commodities sought to rebound from Thursday's tough day of trade.Dow futures nosed 1.1% above fair market value. S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 futures pushed up 1.2%. Russell 2000 futures showed a 1% gain.The stock market today rolls into Friday's session with the Nasdaq down 2.2%, the S&P 500 down 2.7% and the Russell 2000 toting a 3.2% loss for the week.Early economic news showed retail sales up 0.2% in January, up 0.1% minus autos, the Commerce Department said. Both numbers were in line with expectations. The department also revised December's sales growth upward to 0.2%.The Labor Department reported January export prices slipped 0.8%, import prices dipped 0.2%, vs. December drops of 0.8% and 1,1%, respectively. Economists projected a 1.4% decline in import prices and a 0.6% drop for exports.At 10 a.m. ET, the Commerce Department reports December business inventories, and the University of Michigan delivers its initial estimate on consumer sentiment.Bonds eased. The dollar rose. Crude oil bounced 5% off Thursday's 13-year low. That put West Texas Intermediate near $28 a barrel -- down 11% for the week -- but Friday's early rebound sent energy stocks to many of the top premarket gains among S&P 500 issues.  Baker Hughes (BHI) reports its weekly rig count at 1 p.m.Gold eased 1% to below $1,238 an ounce, about 7% above its week-ago settle. As a group, gold and silver mining stocks were up more than 10% for the week, although Yamana Gold (AUY) and Newmont Mining (NEM) pulled back slightly before Friday's open.Overseas market action was mixed. Europe's markets traded up between 1.5% and 2% near midday. For the week, London's FTSE 100 tacked toward a 3.6% loss. Frankfurt's DAX was down 4.2% and the CAC 40 in Paris swung toward a 5.9% decline.In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 crumbled 4.8% Friday, leaving it down 11.1% for the week. In Hong Kong, which reopened Thursday, the Hang Seng index slipped 1.2% Friday for a 5% drop in its short week. Markets in Shanghai and Shenzhen reopen Monday.Many influential U.S. stocks were bucking for rebounds. JPMorgan (JPM) bounced nearly 4%, Goldman Sachs (GS) jumped 2% to lead the Dow in premarket action. Both banks dived 4%  in heavy trade Thursday.Apple (AAPL) traded a fraction higher after ending Thursday's session with a 0.3% loss this week.  Boeing (BA) marked the Dow's only premarket decline, down 0.4% following its 7% flameout in massive trade on Thursday.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rolled a 4% gain as its fourth-quarter earnings, reported late Thursday, contracted less than expected by analysts. Revenue fell slightly more than expectations that followed the company's preannounced results. Revenue from Macau declined 27% and from Las Vegas increased 3.8% for the year.Video game leader Activision-Blizzard (ATVI) caved 10% after its late-Thursday report showed Q4 earnings and revenue below consensus projections, as well as weak Q1 guidance. Shares ended Thursday in a test of resistance at their 200-day moving average, 24% below their Dec. 29 high.Four-in-five stocks on the IBD 50 list held flat before the starting bell. Starbucks (SBUX) notched the group's biggest advance, up 1.4%. The stock had narrowed a 3% loss to less than 1% on Thursday, ending the session up 0.8% for the week. Shares are feeling for the bottom of a shallow, four-month consolidation.Ireland-based budget airline Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) ruddered down 2.5% to the bottom of the list.  The stock ended Thursday up more than 4% for the week, vying for its first weekly gain since December. In the process, it retook its 200-day moving average, but in weak trade, hinting at the start of the right side of a seven-week consolidation.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Stocks trended lower Wednesday morning as weak housing and services sector data added to early pressure from oil and overseas markets.The Nasdaq fell hardest, down 1.5%. The Dow and S&P 500 dropped 1.4% each. The Russell 2000 also fell 1.4%.Volume rose firmly, up 10% on the NYSE and 18% higher on the Nasdaq, relative to trade at the same time on Tuesday. Volume helps gauge the degree of participation by institutional investors.Oil prices remained down about 3%. Markets in Europe dug deeper into their losses in afternoon trade. In the U.S., early economic news was an emphatic negative for the stock market today.New home sales slipped to an annualized pace of 494,000 in January, according to the Commerce Department, down from a pace of 544,000 in December. Economist consensus projected a slowdown to a sales rate of 520,000.The U.S. services sector slipped into contraction this month, according to research outfit Markit, which put its preliminary services Purchasing Managers' Index at 49.8 for February, a sharp drop from 53.7 and well below consensus views for no change.Most Dow stocks veered lower at the open. Home Depot (HD) rose 0.6%. United Technologies (UTX) managed a 1% gain. At the low end, Boeing (BA), Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) all fell more than 2%.Four of the top five decliners on the S&P 500 were from mining and energy plays. Ford (F) was number five, down 6% at the start of trade.Electrical utility Edison International (EIX) surged 4%, climbing beyond buy range above a 64.17 buy point after clearing that mark in rising trade on Tuesday. Edison reported a slight earnings decline, to 88 cents per shares, in its fourth quarter vs. expectations for 84 cents, and raised its full-year EPS guidance to above analyst consensus.Chesapeake Energy (CHK) soared 12% after reporting its fourth quarter revenue and earnings fell less than expected. Utility grade solar facilities installer First Solar (FSLR) screamed 9% higher after a solid Q4 beat reported late Tuesday.On the Nasdaq 100, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dropped 5% and Seagate Technology (STX) shed 4%. Verisk Analytics (VRSK) notched a 5% advance. It reported after Tuesday's close its fourth quarter EPS topped consensus views by a comfortable margin, although a 20% gain in revenue ended shy of projections.On the IBD 50 list, WebMD (WBMD) doctored up a 3% gain in healthy trade. Fourth quarter earnings and revenue cleared consensus expectations, according to the New York-based outfit's late Tuesday report.  The site's web traffic increased 6%, page views rose 7% during the quarter. Management raised Q1 revenue and full year EPS guidance to above consensus targets. Shares are 19% above a 45.01 buy point after an early December breakout.

Stocks slumped into early losses Wednesday, feeling pressure from oil and overseas markets.The Nasdaq pulled down hardest, off 1.3%. The Dow and S&P 500 slipped 1.1% apiece.The stock market today expects a modest shot of economic news and will have ears on speeches from a pair of Federal Reserve officials.Researcher Markit reports its preliminary services purchasing managers' index for February at 9:45 a.m. ET. Markit's manufacturing index came in far below expectations on Monday.January new-home sales data from the Commerce Department are expected at 10 a.m.January existing-home sales, reported Tuesday, showed a surprise increase.Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Jeffrey Lacker was scheduled to speak in Baltimore before markets opened this morning. Dallas Federal Reserve President Rob Kaplan speaks at 1:15 p.m.Oil slipped about 3%, with West Texas Intermediate holding just above $30 a barrel -- still up 4% for the week and 18% above a Feb. 11 low.The drop in oil, concerns about demand from China and rising fear of a British exit from the European Union sent energy and mining stocks reeling in Europe. Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC 40 in Paris were both off more than 2% near midday. London's FTSE 100 slumped 1.5%.Benchmark indexes in Tokyo and Hong Kong fell about 1% Wednesday. China's Shanghai Composite gained 0.8%.Just before the open, Dow stocks were flat to lower, with the big losses going to Chevron (CVX), down 1.6%, and JPMorgan (JPM) with a 1.2% loss.Nasdaq 100 were stocks were also flat to lower. Tesla Motors (TSLA) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) shed about 2% each.Volatile energy and commodity plays topped the S&P 500: Chesapeake Energy (CHK), First Solar (FSLR) and Newmont Mining (NEM).TJX (TJX) swatted out a 2% premarket gain ahead of its Q4 results. Target (TGT) dropped a bit more than 1% after its Q4 earnings stopped short of analyst consensus. Revenue met expectations, and full-year EPS guidance was better than expected.Lowe's (LOW) dropped nearly 4% before the open. The home improvement center reported EPS growth of 28%, meeting analyst forecasts. Revenue growth of 6% topped estimates. Management's full-year revenue and earnings guidance were above consensus targets. Unadjusted Q4 earnings included a $530 million charge for the sale of Lowe's share in an Australian retail chain.Leading stocks were quiet, with stocks on the IBD 50 list flat to lower, but generally holding losses to less than 1%.Nvdia (NVDA) was the leading exception, down 1.8% before the start of regular trade. The stock is working on its second straight weekly advance, ending Tuesday 28% above a Feb. 12 low and above the midpoint in a developing cup base.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Recovery for casinos may be just around the corner, but it's not in sight yet. Battered MGM Resorts International (MGM) missed Q4 estimates, and shares fell hard. Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), a Hong Kong-based company that owns has casino resorts in Macau, the gambling hub on China's southern coast, also reported worse-than-expected results and saw its stock punished. MGM Resorts lost…

Stocks stumbled out of the starting gate in mixed trade Monday, as economic data, oil prices and overseas pressure all weighed on early action. The Dow industrials and S&P 500 dipped 0.6% each. The Nasdaq backed down 0.5%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, up 14% on the NYSE but 4% lower on the Nasdaq, relative to action at…

Stock futures were down but steady in premarket action Monday after a bland reading on December consumer spending and income. Dow futures hung 0.7% below fair market value. S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq 100 futures slipped 0.8% and 0.7%, respectively. The stock market today appears poised to continue its recent back and forth action after a strong session Friday ended…
Stocks ground lower in early trade Friday as faltering oil prices and overseas markets snuffed investors' confidence ahead of the three-day weekend.
The Nasdaq tanked 2.6% at the open. The Dow traded down 2.1%, and the S&P 500 showed a 2% decline. Small caps were taking a beating, with the Russell 2000 opening to a 2.7% loss.
Options expirations helped boost volume, with trade up 29% on the Nasdaq and 77% higher on the NYSE vs. action at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today opened with the deck stacked against it. China's mainland markets fell hard, sending the Shanghai composite down 3.6% and into bear market territory. China's currency, the yuan, on Thursday and Friday staged its largest two-day decline since 1986. The weakness carried over into oil prices, sending West Texas Intermediate down 5% and Brent crude 4% lower, both to below $30 a barrel. The sell-off worsened in Europe after BHP Billion (BHP) said it would book a $4.9 billion write-down on its U.S. onshore oil and gas assets. London's FTSE 100 dived 2.3%, the CAC-40 in Paris dropped 2.7%, and Frankfurt's DAX swooned 3.2% in afternoon trade.
On the U.S. market, BHP Billiton shares dumped 8% at the start of trade.

Economic news did little to quell concerns, with the New York Federal Reserve's December Empire State Manufacturing survey indicating that "business activity declined for New York manufacturers at the fastest pace since the Great Recession." Retail sales fell in December despite the holiday shopping season.

Declines in national industrial production slowed to minus 0.4% in December, the Federal Reserve reported. That was less than half of November's downwardly revised 0.9% drop, but still worse than the consensus forecast for a 0.2% slip. Capacity utilization continued to slip, to 76.5%, from November's revised 76.9% and below views for 76.9% utilization.

Consumer outlooks were somewhat more positive, with the University of Michigan placing its preliminary January Consumer Sentiment Index reading at 93.3, up from 92.6 and besting views for a reading of 93.

All 30 Dow stocks dropped into the red at the starting bell. Intel (INTC) fell hardest, dropping more than 7% after its late Thursday report followed up decent Q4 results with weak revenue guidance for the first quarter. Goldman Sachs (GS), Walt Disney (DIS) and Microsoft (MSFT) fell more than 3% each.
Most of the S&P 500's hardest-hit issues were oil-related stocks.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) led the half dozen S&P 500 names managing to make early gains, rising nearly 6% after providing a preliminary look at Q4 revenue from its Macau and Las Vegas properties.
IBD 50 stocks were unanimously lower shortly after the open.
Integrated Device Technology (IDTI) shed nearly 6%. Tesoro (TSO) and Icon (ICLR) fell more than 4% each.

Cal-Maine Foods (CALM), Constellation Brands (STZ) and WebMD (WBMD) saw some of the lightest declines, slipping less than 1% apiece.Stocks ground lower in early trade Friday as faltering oil prices and overseas markets snuffed investors' confidence ahead of the three-day weekend.The Nasdaq tanked 2.6% at the open. Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.
Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.
December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.

The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.
Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.
Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.

Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.

On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.

Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.

Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Huntington is trading below a 136.55 buy point in a long cup-with-handle base.Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Huntington is trading below a 136.55 buy point in a long cup-with-handle base.
Stocks fell hard out of the starting gates again Thursday as a global pullback tripped by volatility in China continued. The Nasdaq retreated more than 2%.
The S&P 500 was down 1.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average clocked a 1.4% loss. Volume climbed 28% on the Nasdaq and 16% on the NYSE relative to trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today opened to the Nasdaq dropping 8.5% below its Dec. 2 high and the S&P 500 7.5% off its high from early November. There seemed to be little question regarding the impact of a shutdown on China's mainland markets, pushed past a circuit breaker 7% loss limit after a slide in China's currency triggered a stock sell-off. Markets in Japan and Europe picked up on the skittishness. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended down 2.3%. Europe's top indexes showed losses of 2% to 3% in afternoon trade.

U.S. investors received positive economic news from Challenger, Gray & Christmas, which reported that layoffs by U.S. employers decreased to a 15-year low in December. Weekly unemployment claims data from the labor department was mixed, decreasing vs. the prior week but not as much as forecast by analysts.
On the Dow, only Wal-Mart (WMT) opened higher, rising 1%. Microsoft (MSFT) took the heaviest loss, down nearly 3%.

Macy's (M) jumped 6%. The department store reported late Wednesday its November-December same-store-sales slipped 4.7% year over year. Warm weather cutting into sales of coats, sweaters, boots, hats was a key factor, the company said. Management reduced its 2016 EPS and revenue guidance and announced a series of cost-cutting measures aimed at trimming $400 million from annual costs.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dropped 6% to the bottom of the S&P 500. Yahoo (YHOO) skidded nearly 5% lower.

Finish Line (FINL) flopped 10%, after reporting fiscal Q3 sales and earnings below analyst views and lowering its Q4 sales and earnings guidance. The company acknowledged a long list of operational problems and announced Glenn Lyon will step down as CEO on Feb. 28. Lyon will keep his chairman title through the end of the year.
Among leaders, Constellation Brands (STZ) surged 5% higher after reporting fiscal Q3 revenue and earnings above analyst expectations and raising full-year EPS guidance above consensus views.
Alibaba (BABA) crumbled 5%, putting the stock 9% lower for the week and ending, for now, a bid to retake support at its 200-day moving average.

Fiber optic laser specialist IPG Photonics (IPGP) dived 5% in mild trade. The stock's sixth straight decline put shares down 12% for the week and killed the stock's basing effort.Stocks fell hard out of the starting gates again Thursday as a global pullback tripped by volatility in China continued. The Nasdaq retreated more than 2%. The S&P 500 was down 1.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average clocked a 1.4% loss.
