Stock futures knocked out healthy gains ahead of Monday's open after a probationary deal from the eurozone opened the door to possible bailout funds for Greece.

Dow futures were 122.6 points above fair market value and ticking higher. Nasdaq 100 futures were up a solid 33.5 points. S&P 500 futures jumped 13.3 points. Small caps were less impressed, with Russell 2000 futures edging up 3.5 points.

Greece was (again) the leading early influence on the stock market today. An accord fashioned between eurozone creditors and Greece's leaders following an all-night session cleared the path for the struggling country to receive as much as $96 billion, to be released as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras proves his government able to implement so-called austerity measures.

The plan is enough to keep Greece, for now, within the euro currency bloc. Tsipras must enact tax hikes and pension changes by Wednesday. Both steps were refused by Greek voters in a referendum just a week ago.

Global markets were positive, with China's top indexes blocking out solid gains — Shanghai Composite up 2.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng up 1.3%. In Europe, the CAC-40 in Paris surged 2%. Frankfurt's DAX climbed 1.4%. London's FTSE 100 added 0.8%.

U.S. markets open the day with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 staring at the underside of their 50-day moving averages. Moves above those lines would be positive, but would still leave the market within the range that has contained trade since March. The Nasdaq starts Monday's session 3.3% below its June 24 high. The S&P 500 starts 2.8% below its high, from May 20.

The Treasury Department serves up its June budget numbers at 2 p.m. ET. The earnings calendar gets a slow start Monday. IBD 50 stock Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) reports after the close. The pace picks up on Tuesday, with reports due out from JPMorgan (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).
In stocks, United Continental (UAL) climbed 2%. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) tacked up a 5% gain.
Medical sector stocks small and large were hammering out big premarket moves.

Anacor Pharmaceuticals (ANAC) spiked 48% after announcing its eczema skin rash lotion Crisaborole met endpoints in two late-stage clinical trials. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based biotech said it would submit a new drug application to the Food and Drug Administration early in 2016. Anacor ended Friday at a new high, up 9% in July and with a 162% gain this year.
ConforMis (CFMS) leapt 9%. The market of surgical knee implants, a July 2 new issue, ended Friday 17% below its high and 49% above its IPO price.

Edwards Lifesciences (EW) notched up 3% after RBC Capital upgraded the stock to outperform from sector perform. The Irvine, Calif.-based company announced Friday it would pay $400 million to acquire privately held heart device maker CardiAQ Valve Technologies. Edwards ended Friday just below a 147.40 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

In other trading, the dollar gained vs. the euro and the yen while the yen rose vs. the euro. Oil prices slipped a bit less than 1%. Gold was down a fraction.Stock futures knocked out healthy gains ahead of Monday's open after a probationary deal from the eurozone opened the door to possible bailout funds for Greece.Dow futures were 122.6 points above fair market value and ticking higher. Nasdaq 100 futures were up a solid 33.5 points. S&P 500 futures jumped 13.3 points. Small caps were less impressed, with Russell 2000 futures edging up 3.5 points.Greece was (again) the leading early influence on the stock market today. An accord fashioned between eurozone creditors and Greece's leaders following an all-night session cleared the path for the struggling country to receive as much as $96 billion, to be released as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras proves his government able to implement so-called austerity measures.The plan is enough to keep Greece, for now, within the euro currency bloc. Tsipras must enact tax hikes and pension changes by Wednesday. Both steps were refused by Greek voters in a referendum just a week ago.Global markets were positive, with China's top indexes blocking out solid gains — Shanghai Composite up 2.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng up 1.3%. In Europe, the CAC-40 in Paris surged 2%. Frankfurt's DAX climbed 1.4%. London's FTSE 100 added 0.8%.U.S. markets open the day with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 staring at the underside of their 50-day moving averages. Moves above those lines would be positive, but would still leave the market within the range that has contained trade since March. The Nasdaq starts Monday's session 3.3% below its June 24 high. The S&P 500 starts 2.8% below its high, from May 20.The Treasury Department serves up its June budget numbers at 2 p.m. ET. The earnings calendar gets a slow start Monday. IBD 50 stock Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) reports after the close. The pace picks up on Tuesday, with reports due out from JPMorgan (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).In stocks, United Continental (UAL) climbed 2%. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) tacked up a 5% gain.Medical sector stocks small and large were hammering out big premarket moves.Anacor Pharmaceuticals (ANAC) spiked 48% after announcing its eczema skin rash lotion Crisaborole met endpoints in two late-stage clinical trials. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based biotech said it would submit a new drug application to the Food and Drug Administration early in 2016. Anacor ended Friday at a new high, up 9% in July and with a 162% gain this year.ConforMis (CFMS) leapt 9%. The market of surgical knee implants, a July 2 new issue, ended Friday 17% below its high and 49% above its IPO price.Edwards Lifesciences (EW) notched up 3% after RBC Capital upgraded the stock to outperform from sector perform. The Irvine, Calif.-based company announced Friday it would pay $400 million to acquire privately held heart device maker CardiAQ Valve Technologies. Edwards ended Friday just below a 147.40 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.In other trading, the dollar gained vs. the euro and the yen while the yen rose vs. the euro. Oil prices slipped a bit less than 1%. Gold was down a fraction.
Stocks jumped out of the starting gates Monday, after an accord of sorts between the eurozone and Greece brushed global markets with a bit of optimism.

The Nasdaq pulled up 1.3% in early action. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.1% and the S&P 500 rose 1%. Volume was mixed, with early readings showing trade up 10% on the Nasdaq and down 2% on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Friday.

The stock market today opened on an up note after eurozone creditors struck a deal with Greece that may or may not open the door to bailout funds. The deal requires Greece's government to put in place by Wednesday pension reforms and tax increases, both of which were refused by Greek voters in a July 5 referendum. The deal also makes $10 billion available immediately to shore up Greece's faltering banks, but requires the government to privatize a $55 billion portfolio of assets — most of the proceeds from which will go to repay debt and recapitalize weakened banks. Greece's banks and stock market remain closed as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras goes home to attempt to convince his government to go along with the plan in order to hang in the euro currency bloc. Greece faces a $4.6 billion debt deadline to the European Central Bank on July 20.
Europe's top indexes had eased slightly from their early highs, with the CAC-40 in Paris up 1.8% and Frankfurt's DAX holding a 1% gain. The dollar climbed vs. the euro.

In U.S. stocks, airlines swept out to an early lead among industries, possibly owing to a 2% dive in oil prices. American Airlines Group (AAL) leapt 3%. Delta Air Lines (DAL), United Continental Holdings (UAL) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) gained 2% apiece.
GPS device leader Garmin (GRMN) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) each climbed 4%, running at the head of the Nasdaq 100.

At the head of the S&P 500, Marathon Petroleum (MPC) turned in a 9% gain at the start of the trade. Marathon's pipeline master limited partnership MPLX (MPLX) announced it would acquire another MLP, MarkWest Energy Partners (MWE), in a deal valued at $15.8 billion. MPLX shares dived 13%. MarkWest jumped 10%.
NewLink Genetics (NLNK) popped 4.6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The stock is 37% above a May 14 low and 19% below its April high, climbing the right side of a three-month consolidation.

Among the very few IBD 50 stocks to post early declines, Ambarella (AMBA) and Taser International (TASR) were down about 1% each.Stocks jumped out of the starting gates Monday, after an accord of sorts between the eurozone and Greece brushed global markets with a bit of optimism.The Nasdaq pulled up 1.3% in early action. Stocks drove higher out of the starting gate Thursday, bolstered by positive stock action in Europe and China.
The Nasdaq grabbed a 1.3% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.1% and the S&P 500 added 1%. Volume was higher on both exchanges.

The stock market today surged, despite the Labor Department's disappointing tally of weekly jobless claims. A 5% increase in claims, to 297,000 for the week ended July 4, ran counter to expectations for a slight decrease and drove up the four-week moving average for a second straight week.

But stocks rallying in Europe, possibly set off by an overnight rebound in China's sold-off markets, signaled a willingness among investors to abandon Grexit fears. Bonds slipped, the dollar rose and oil-price gains accelerated after the open, with the West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude benchmarks both up about 3%. Chesapeake Energy (CHK) popped 3.5% to the top of the S&P 500. Russia-based telecom service provider VimpelCom (VIP) jumped 4% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Two-thirds of the Dow stocks rose more than 1%, led by Travelers (TRV) and JPMorgan (JPM).

Chip stocks were rebounding from what has been a tough week, led by European Union-based issues leading the Philadelphia semiconductor index. Netherlands-based ASML (ASML) jumped more than 4%. U.K.-based ARM (ARMH) climbed 3.9%.

Alcoa (AA) climbed nearly 4% after reporting mixed second-quarter results late Wednesday. Earnings missed analyst projections, but revenue topped expectations as the company's increasing focus on aerospace and automotive markets helped offset losses driven by a global aluminum glut.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) jumped 3.7%, possible due to its links to China's casino and gambling district, Macau. The stock is working on a second week of gains following 15 months of steep declines.
The IBD 50 list opened almost unanimously higher, with China-based issues leading the gains.
NetEase (NTES) leapt 5% in heavy trade, fighting to retake support at its 50-day moving average. The gain narrowed the stock's loss for the week to 3%.
Autohome (ATHM) was up 3% after backing away from its early high. The stock is engaged in a test of support at its 200-day moving average.

Israel-based CyberArk Software (CYBR) climbed 3%, rising for a second straight session in strong trade. The security software developer has narrowed its loss for the week to 3%, but remains 23% below its mid-June high and well below its 10-week moving average.

At the low end of the list, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) slipped a fraction after UBS downgraded the stock to sell from neutral.Stocks drove higher out of the starting gate Thursday, bolstered by positive stock action in Europe and China.The Nasdaq grabbed a 1.3% gain. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other casino stocks staged a rare, brief rally after Chinese officials eased restrictions on travel to the gambling mecca, only to reverse Thursday on a fresh report of further tightening of restrictions. In a surprise move on Wednesday, Macau's regional government said starting on July 1 mainland China passports will enable Chinese visitors to stay…
Stocks took back some ground early Tuesday as investors took in mixed economic news and markets appeared to have steadied concerns about Greece.
The Nasdaq popped 0.5%. The S&P 500 climbed 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on a 0.2% gain.
Volume dipped, down about 10% each on the NYSE and Nasdaq exchanges compared with trade at the same time Monday.

Negotiations between eurozone creditors and Greece continued to dominate investors' attention in the stock market today. Greek leaders were reportedly considering a last-ditch proposal from the European Commission, ahead of Tuesday night's deadline that will mark and end of bailout support for the country and its banks, and send the country into official default status. Greece's banks and stock market remain closed. European markets were steady, holding only mild losses in afternoon trade.

In the U.S., home price growth slowed to 4.9% in April, according to the Case-Shiller 20-City Composite Home Price Index. The index had climbed 5% in March, and economists had projected a 5.4% increase in April. Denver and San Francisco led the list, with prices up more than 10% in each city. Average home prices with the 20 cities surveyed had returned to their late 2004 levels, and 14% to 16% below their June/July 2006 peaks.

Contraction in the Midwest manufacturing sector slowed in June, with Kingsbury International's Chicago Purchasing Managers Index improving to 49.4 vs. a 46.2 reading in May. Economists had projected the index would rise to 50.3. Readings below 50 indicate contraction.

The outlook among consumers was more positive, with the Conference Board reporting its Consumer Confidence Index jumping to 101.4 in June, up from May's 95.4 tally. Consensus estimates called for an increase to 97.4.
Stock action showed Wynn Resorts (WYNN) surging 5% to lead the Nasdaq 100. General Electric (GE) topped the Dow with a 1% gain.

U.K.-based insurance and reinsurance firm Willis Group (WSH) popped 6% after announcing it would merge with Arlington, Va.-based Towers Watson (TW) in an all-stock deal valued at $18 billion. Shares of Towers, a human resource and financial management consultant, fell 3%.

For-profit educator Apollo Education (APOL) tanked 14% at the starting bell. The Phoenix-based company reported late Monday its fiscal third-quarter earnings beat, but revenue missed analyst consensus expectations. On Tuesday, Bank of America downgraded the stock to underperform, from neutral, and pared its price target to 14 from 20. The stock has been in a steep correction since December.
Among IBD 50 stocks, China-based issues led the early action.
Autohome (ATHM) nosed up more than 4%. The gain put shares back above 10-week support as it climbs the right side of a possible nine-week cup base.

Despite predictions that a recovery in Macau's casinos could begin this year, there still appears to be no end in sight for the gambling mecca's losing streak. In fact, Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight on Tuesday said that June gambling revenue for Macau could fall 30% to 40% annually to about $2 billion, which would be the lowest result for…

Stocks powered out of the starting gate Wednesday as mixed economic news took a back seat to optimism over potential developments in the eurozone.The Dow Jones Industrial average and the Nasdaq were up 0.9% each. The S&P 500 climbed 0.8%.Volume rose, up about 5% each on the Nasdaq and NYSE exchanges.The stock market today continued to carefully watch the ongoing Greece/eurozone crisis. A letter from Greek leaders Tuesday night conceded to more of the creditors' austerity demands than before, but requested an extension for the now-expired bailout support and additional funds. Reuters reported that German officials were skeptical of the proposal, but said the "door was still open for negotiations."Early U.S. economic news was mixed, with new jobs and layoffs increasing in June.June manufacturing softened. The Purchasing Managers Index eased to 53.6, down from 54 in May and a tad shy of views for 53.7.The ISM Index from the Institute of Supply Management was more positive, rising to 53.3. That was above May's 52.8 tally and narrowly above consensus estimates for 53.2.Construction spending slowed sharply in May, the Commerce Department said, rising 0.8% vs. April's downwardly revised 2.1% increase. Still, the number was better than the 0.5% increase forecast by economists.Among automakers reporting June sales, Nissan Motor (NSANY) led with a 13.3% increase. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) reported an 8.2% gain for the month. Ford (F) sales gained 1.6%. General Motors (GM) sales fell 3%.In stocks, insurer Travelers (TRV) popped 3.6% to lead the Dow. The stock was possibly boosted by this morning's news that Switzerland-based Ace (ACE) would buy New Jersey-based insurer Chubb (CB) in a deal valued at $28.3 billion. Chubb shares spiked 33% at the open. Ace climbed 7%.On the Nasdaq 100, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) spiked 7%, stretching its legs for a second day after regulators in China eased travel restrictions for visitors from mainland China to Macau, where Wynn and competitors operate a hive of casinos. Wynn has been in a correction for 15 months.Among IBD 50 stocks,France's Criteo (CRTO) sparked up 5% out of the starting gate. The move lifted the stock out of buying range, 7% above a 46.60 buy point.Epam Systems (EPAM) leapt nearly 4%, moving to the top of buying range — almost 5% past a 70.59 buy point.Among the group's few early declines, Taser International (TASR) slipped a bit less than 2%. The stock remained just above its 50-day moving average after retaking that support in light trade Tuesday.

Pinnacle Entertainment (PNK) stock climbed 6% early Tuesday after the company confirmed that it received a sweetened offer from Gaming and Leisure Properties (GLPI) for its land holdings and said that the two are negotiating.
The combination would create the third largest publicly traded triple-net real estate investment trust in the country, the companies said.

Smaller Gaming and Leisure Properties, with about $640 million in annual revenue vs. Pinnacle Entertainment's roughly $2.25 billion, raised its offer to $47.50 per share, or $5 billion, from $4.1 billion earlier.
Gaming and Leisure Properties originally approached Pinnacle in January about a possible land deal.

In March, Gaming and Leisure, itself a spinoff of Penn National Gaming (PENN), said its offer to discuss a deal was rebuffed and it then made a hostile $4.1 billion bid and said it planned to take the offer to the company's shareholders if Pinnacle refused to talk. Pinnacle said at the time it was willing to talk "under appropriate terms."

Pinnacle Entertainment owns and operates 16 casinos and race tracks in Nevada, Colorado, Indiana and five other states. The company said Tuesday that it will continue working through plans to separate its properties in a REIT.
The move comes amid a trend by casinos to leverage properties to create shareholder value by forming a REIT, often as a result of pressure from an activist investor.

MGM Resorts International (MGM) shares, for example, jumped early this year after shareholder Land & Buildings bid to put four people on MGM's board to force it to split the company in two and spin off its massive land holdings, possibly in a REIT. That effort failed and in late May Land & Buildings dropped its bid to gain board seats.

Pinnacle Entertainment stock climbed 95% from a Jan. 30 low to a 40.42 all-time high on April 14. The stock has traded in a narrow range since then and was near the high at 39.73, up 6% by early afternoon in the stock market today, Tuesday.
The company's stock has a near-best 96 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it has outperformed 96% of all stocks on key metrics in recent quarters.
Gaming and Leisure Properties shares were down 4%. Penn National was off less than 1%.

MGM Resorts International, the nation's second largest casino company behind global leader Las Vegas Sands (LVS), was down 1%. Like Las Vegas peers Sands and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM has been hurt by a slump in Macau, where it has extensive holdings.

Isle of Capri Casinos (ISLE) stock climbed more than 20% in two days of trading since the St. Louis-based riverboat casino and racetrack company reported outstanding quarterly results.
Penn National Gaming (PENN), another casino company that operates in the U.S. but doesn't own properties in the global gambling mecca Macau, climbed nearly 5%.
Domestic casinos are outpacing their larger global peers.

The world's largest casino operator Las Vegas Sands (LVS), as well as MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) all get the bulk of their growth from Macau, which generates annual gambling revenue about six times that of Las Vegas.

Macau, on China's southern coast, has been in a recession the past year amid tighter government regulations and shrinking economic growth in China. As a result, Sands and its peers have seen revenue growth shrink.

Isle of Capri Casinos, which operates a racetrack in Pompano Beach, Fla., and 15 casinos in the Midwest, South and East Coast, said Tuesday that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings jumped 71% to 58 cents a share, beating analyst estimates by 17 cents a share.
Revenue grew 5.3% to $274.6 million, topping views for $266.7 million.
Isle of Capri Casinos President and CEO Virginia McDowell said the company continues to invest in properties by renovating hotel rooms, restaurants and casinos.

"We broke ground on our land-based development at Bettendorf (Iowa) which we expect to open in early fiscal 2017," McDowell said. "We continue to optimize our marketing programs and are introducing new productivity tools in fiscal 2016 across the enterprise."
Isle of Capri Casinos shares shot up 7.7% to 19.39 on the stock market Wednesday.

Its stock has a powerful 92 IBD Composite Rating , meaning it's outperformed 92% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth. It cleared a 15.49 buy point of a flat base Friday and continued rising. It was on track for its sixth straight higher close Wednesday.
Penn National Gaming, which boasts an 87 Composite Rating, rose 4.9% to 17.61, breaking out of a base.

Among top global casinos, Las Vegas Sands rose 0.6% Wednesday. Wynn Resorts was up 0.9%. MGM Resorts International, which is the largest casino operator in Las Vegas and less exposed to Macau, also advanced 0.9%.

Losses steepened and volume ebbed in midafternoon trade Thursday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq down 0.9%, and the S&P 500 diving through its 50-day moving average in an 0.8% slip.

Market attention turned from the morning's mix of economic reports to Friday's heavy news slate, which includes the U.S. non-farm payrolls report for May, a debt payment deadline between Greece and the International Monetary Fund, and a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna.

Twenty-nine of 30 Dow components traded lower late Thursday, but small caps led the declines on the stock market today, with the Russell 2000 showing a 1.2% loss. Among the hardest hit, Veritiv (VRTV), Contango Oil & Gas (MCF) and Cyberonics (CYBX) were all down 7% to 8%.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) led the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100 with a 7% gain. Telecom services provider Frontier Communications (FTR) fell to the bottom of the list with a 5% decline.

On the IBD 50 list, chipmaker Ambarella (AMBA) held its early gains, up 4% in strong trade to a new high. On Wednesday, investment bank Needham & Co. upgraded the stock to hold from underperform. Morgan Stanley kept its equal weight rating but boosted its price target to 100 from 65.

The dollar rose, and bonds recovered some ground after a three-day tumble. Oil prices slumped ahead of Friday's OPEC meeting, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate and Europe's Brent Crude standard both down 3%.Losses steepened and volume ebbed in midafternoon trade Thursday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq down 0.9%, and the S&P 500 diving through its 50-day moving average in an 0.8% slip.Market attention turned from the morning's mix of economic reports to Friday's heavy news slate, which includes the U.S. non-farm payrolls report for May, a debt payment deadline between Greece and the International Monetary Fund, and a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna.Twenty-nine of 30 Dow components traded lower late Thursday, but small caps led the declines on the stock market today, with the Russell 2000 showing a 1.2% loss. Among the hardest hit, Veritiv (VRTV), Contango Oil & Gas (MCF) and Cyberonics (CYBX) were all down 7% to 8%.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) led the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100 with a 7% gain. Telecom services provider Frontier Communications (FTR) fell to the bottom of the list with a 5% decline.On the IBD 50 list, chipmaker Ambarella (AMBA) held its early gains, up 4% in strong trade to a new high. On Wednesday, investment bank Needham & Co. upgraded the stock to hold from underperform. Morgan Stanley kept its equal weight rating but boosted its price target to 100 from 65.The dollar rose, and bonds recovered some ground after a three-day tumble. Oil prices slumped ahead of Friday's OPEC meeting, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate and Europe's Brent Crude standard both down 3%.

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other top casinos jumped Thursday on a report that Macau, the world's top gambling destination, may be bottoming or at least stabilizing. Revenue figures for the month of May show some "green shoots," Credit Suisse analysts Kenneth Fong and Isis Wong said Thursday, based on May gambling revenue figures released by Macau officials earlier this week.The report noted that revenue for the high-end VIP category rose 3% from April while it climbed 9% in the larger mass-market middle-class and tourist group.Sands, the world's largest casino company, and top-rated in the casino group, gets the bulk of its growth from the resort city on China's southern coast. Sands shares were up 4.6% to 54.90 in midafternoon trading in the stock market today, Thursday.Sands reported year-over-year earnings per share growth until last quarter, when its EPS plunged 32%. Consensus is for EPS growth to continue shrinking the rest of this year. Still, Sands stock crossed above its 50-day line Thursday and was on track for a third straight higher close.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was up 7% and MGM Resorts International (MGM), which is less exposed to Macau, rose 3%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another big casino company in Macau, climbed 7%.Like Credit Suisse, other market-watchers see light at the end of the tunnel after a yearlong Macau recession, triggered by slowing economic growth in China, tighter regulations by Chinese officials in the special administrative district, and a smoking ban that kept some gamblers away.Market-tracker Union Gaming Research noted Wednesday that Macau's gambling revenue remained soft in May, rising 6.2% overall from April but falling 37.1% from May 2014.Still, Union Gaming analyst Chris Jones said in a report that he sees some signs of stability ahead, with tailwinds starting in June."We continue to view June as a transitional month as trends should ... improve given the easier comparisons to June 2014."Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight sees improvement in Macau but expects growth to be permanently lower than its earlier, boisterous growth days."Based on current trends, we believe June gaming revenue decline could be closer to 30% year over year. Given this weakness, we see downside risk to our Q2 and 2015 estimates. We remain neutral on Macau gaming as estimates and valuations adjust to a 'new normal' " of lower growth.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Monday drifted to a quiet start as stocks posted narrow early losses in weak volume.
The Nasdaq slipped 0.3% and the S&P 500 fell 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average held to an 0.1% decline. Volume opened down 47% on the Nasdaq and 16% lower on the NYSE.

Investors received few clear early signals on the stock market today. The sole piece of U.S. economic news, the Federal Reserve's Labor Market Conditions index, came in with a positive 1.3 reading for May — better than April's negative 1.9 showing but well below the consensus estimate for an increase to 2.3.

Overseas, China reported Sunday that its imports dropped sharply while export declines slowed in May. The report was widely seen as showing weak domestic demand and investment. China's markets speculated that it meant more central bank stimulus measures ahead.
Oil prices slipped more than 1% Monday after last week's pullback, in which U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude lost 1.9% and Europe's Brent crude fell 3.4%.
Energy stocks remained largely resilient, with U.S. drilling contractors posting some of the market's best early gains.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) led automakers higher, jumping 2% after a report from Robert W. Baird said that the stock had more room to run and raised its price target to 335 from 275. The gain lifted shares just above a 252.97 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Casino owners were under pressure, with Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dropping 5% apiece. Both stocks had surged last week after Las Vegas Sands CEO and Chairman Sheldon Adelson reportedly said that his company was pondering a takeover of Wynn Resorts. Adelson said that Wynn operated in two of Las Vegas Sands' biggest markets but that a takeover was "only a remote thought." Both stocks have been in decline since March 2014.

Stocks slipped from mixed early trade into narrow losses Monday as investors took in a broad palette of economic news.
The Nasdaq slipped furthest, down 0.5%. The S&P 500 shed 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1%. Volume was higher, up 30% on the Nasdaq and 16% higher on the NYSE.

The stock market today received a wobbly, early push from April data showing personal income rose more than expected and price inflation remained largely in check, although personal spending was flat for the month. The dollar's early advance turned mixed after the data, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Oil prices trimmed early losses from more than 1% to a fraction.

News from the Institute for Supply Management was good, with its manufacturing index rising to 52.8 for May. That was better than the 51.5 flat line through March and April and above estimates for an uptick to 51.8.
A second purchasing managers index, from researcher Markit, was less optimistic, easing to 54, from 54.1 — although still above consensus views for a reading of 53.8.

April construction spending showed some strength, up 2.2% the Commerce Department reported. Economist consensus projected a 0.7% increase. The department also revised March's spending number to a 0.5% increase vs. initial estimates of a 0.6% decline.

In stocks, Altera (ALTR) pulled the early headlines, surging 10% after finalizing a deal to be acquired by Intel (INTC) for $16.7 billion. The move hoisted shares to their highest mark since September 2000. Intel shares slipped a fraction, but held support at their 50-day moving average.

Bristol Myers (BMY) popped 4%. Positive trial results led to Food and Drug Administration acceptance of the company's supplemental biologics license application for its Opdivo+Yervoy regimen for melanoma patients, the company said Monday. The stock dropped 7% in heavy trade on Friday.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dropped more than 2%, the worst loss among Nasdaq 100 stocks. China's Macau Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau reported a 37% year-over-year decline in gross gambling revenue in the gambling district during May. The decline was slightly better than expectations and less than April's 39% decline. Wynn shares have been falling for 15 months.

Cheetah Mobile (CMCM) raced ahead 7%, erasing last week's losses and putting shares 10% below their May 20 high. The China-based developer of mobile and network security software is extended above a 25.65 buy point and starting the fourth week of an eight-week hold rule.

Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI) bucked up 5%. Investor advisor Glass Lewis & Co. backed a candidate put forth by Land & Buildings, which has a 0.4% stake in MGM Resorts International (MGM) and is trying to place four people on MGM's board as it pushes for the casino company to separate its land holdings to free shareholder value. Earlier, advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services threw its support…

MGM Resorts International (MGM) reported better-than-expected first quarter earnings as its Las Vegas properties continued to perform well. But revenue fell as the recession in Macau continued to impact results. Earnings per share climbed 50% to 33 cents, trouncing estimates by 20 cents a share. Revenue fell 11.3% to $2.33 billion, down from $2.63 billion a year ago and below…
Stocks traced thin losses early Thursday as investors largely looked toward what promises to be a big news day on Friday.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq dropped to fractional losses. The S&P 500 shaved off 0.3%, weighted by losses among energy and chemical stocks.

Factors affecting the stock market today include the Eurozone's dilemma over Greece's debt, which faces a steep hurdle in the form of a $334 million debt payment owed to the International Monetary Fund on Friday. That uncertainty has helped trigger a volatile week in global bond markets, a situation given an additional stir by comments Wednesday from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi.
Markets are also positioning for a U.S. payroll report for May and a meeting of the Organization for Petroleum Exporting Countries, both on Friday.
That being said, not much positioning is going on in the U.S. stock market, where the Nasdaq and S&P 500 remain in a tightly rangebound posture.

In economic news, layoff data were positive early Thursday. The Challenger Job Cuts Report announced a 23% year-over-year decline in job reductions, down 33% from an oil-spurred surge of layoffs in April. Weekly jobless claims declined 2%, in line with consensus forecasts, but first-quarter productivity and unit labor cost revisions from the Labor Department were worse than expected.

In stocks, dollar store chain Five Below (FIVE) surged 10% out of the starting gate. The Philadelphia-based retailer's earnings and revenue narrowly topped Q1 consensus views. Management reported 19 new stores opened during the quarter and said store growth remained its No. 1 priority. Five Below has been in a general uptrend since March, trying to haul itself out of an eight-month consolidation.

T-Mobile (TMUS) and Dish Network (DISH) also staked out the early high ground. Dish jumped 5% to lead the Nasdaq 100. T-Mobile powered up 4%. News reports said the two companies were in discussions regarding a possible merger. The gain sent T-Mobile to a fresh high. It sent Dish further up the right side of a four-month cup base.

Casino owner Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) surged more than 5% at the start of trade. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) jumped 4% to top the S&P 500. MGM Resorts (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) gained 2% each. The group has largely been consolidating for the past 14 months.

Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) scratched out a 2% gain to lead the IBD 50 list in early trade. The Mississippi-based egg producer is in the fourth week of an eight-week hold rule, after rising more than 20% above a 47.61 buy point in fewer than 2 weeks.Stocks traced thin losses early Thursday as investors largely looked toward what promises to be a big news day on Friday.The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq dropped to fractional losses. Stocks pared much of their losses after the Fed policy statement implied a rate hike wasn't imminent, but gave up some ground into the close. The Nasdaq ended with a 0.6% loss; the S&P; 500 and Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.4% each. Volume was higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.While the central bank didn't explicitly rule out a hike in June, it expressed plans to raise the target range when it "has seen further improvement in the labor market." Weak economic data suggest a rate hike may be delayed. Q1 GDP estimates released ahead of the announcement came in at 0.2%, well below Q4's 2.2% growth and forecasts for a 1% increase.Baidu (BIDU) was down 4% in extended trading, after the Chinese online search giant reported mixed Q1 results and gave tepid Q2 guidance. The stock has been consolidating since November.Oil stocks were among the top gainers in the stock market today as West Texas intermediate crude prices rose after government stockpile data indicate an oil supply glut may be easing. Hotels also put in a strong performance.Casinos, HMOs and airlines suffered big losses. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) slumped 17% in fast turnover to a two-year low. The casino operator late Tuesday reported Q1 results that missed forecasts. Its revenue in Macau, where it has large stakes, fell 38%.Spirit Airlines (SAVE) fell 9% after its Q1 results met analyst expectations, but shares plunged amid increased capacity, stiffer competition in Dallas and a drop in nonticket revenue. The stock has been consolidating since December.Among IBD 50 stocks, 36 declined while 14 advanced. Apple (AAPL) reversed lower in above-average volume for a second straight session after climbing past a 133.70 flat-base buy point intraday Monday.A couple of former IBD 50 members made big moves. GoPro (GPRO) gapped up and vaulted 13% on a strong Q1 earnings report, while Twitter (TWTR) slumped 9%, extending its 18% plunge from Tuesday after its Q1 revenue and guidance disappointed Wall Street.Economic reports slated for Thursday include weekly jobless claims, personal income and outlays for March, and the employment cost index for Q1.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.

An independent stock advisory firm advised stockholders to reject Elaine Wynn's bid to retain her seat on Wynn Resorts'  (WYNN) board and elect two candidates she has nominated to the board. It was also critical of CEO Steve Wynn and the board. The casino resort company's board, backed by Elaine Wynn's former husband, Steve Wynn, who is founder and…

Stock futures dropped out of narrowly mixed trade to hefty losses ahead of Wednesday's open, after a disappointing Q1 GDP report.Dow futures sank 62.1 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures dropped 12.7 points. S&P; 500 futures fell 6.3 points.The stock market today is likely to be strung between earnings news, reaction to the early GDP report and this afternoon's release of a policy statement, following the Federal Open Market Committee's two-day meeting. The market showed some positive action, recovering early losses to finish narrowly mixed. The S&P; 500 held below its recent resistance level near 2120. But the Nasdaq's action hinted at possible support near 5000.Economic news opened on a weak note, with the Commerce Department's initial estimate showing the economy expanded a scant 0.2% in the first quarter. That was a serious downshift from Q4's 2.2% gain and sorely below consensus expectations for a 1% increase. Prices slipped 0.1% during the quarter, according to the GDP Price Index, reversing Q4's 0.1% increase and below projections for a 0.5% rise. The weak reading focuses even more attention on this afternoon's Fed announcement.Pending home sales numbers for March are expected from the National Association of Realtors at 10 a.m. ET. The Federal Open Market Committee's policy statement is set for 2 p.m.Despite the mildly mixed stance among stock futures prior to the release of Q1 GDP estimates, a number of leading stocks were volatile ahead of the open. Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) dived 10% after reporting results late Tuesday. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was also down 10%, while Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) surged 9%.GoPro (GPRO) vaulted 11% before the open. The maker of digital video cameras reported late Tuesday its first-quarter sales and earnings topped expectations. The stock has been climbing off a March low, ending Tuesday 52% below its October high.Twitter (TWTR) was down a mild 2% in premarket trade, but with its feather still seriously ruffled after diving 18% Tuesday upon the leaked release of its disappointing Q1 results. The company had intended to release results after the close. Tuesday's loss sent the stock well below key levels of support, and snuffed its attempt to climb above a cup-with-handle base.
Sellers were in the stock market again Wednesday, but major averages recovered a bit after the release of the Fed policy statement at 2 p.m. ET.
The Nasdaq lost 0.6% while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 gave up 0.4%. Preliminary data showed the NYSE coming in higher than Tuesday. Nasdaq volume fell a bit.

The Fed statement had an optimistic tone about the economy, despite a softer labor market. The Fed also cited slowing growth due to "transitory factors." Committee members voted unanimously to keep rates unchanged and will remain data-dependent in deciding when to hike rates.
Investors sold bonds. The 10-year Treasury yield hit a high of 2.07%, up 7 basis points from Tuesday. It was recently around 2.05%.
Oil and gas-related industry groups strengthened as oil prices surged. June crude oil gained $1.52, or 2.7%, to settle at $58.58 a barrel. The dollar index fell.
In the stock market today, Salesforce.com (CRM) surged 12% after Bloomberg reported the software provider hired bankers to help it field takeover offers.

Verisk Analytics (VRSK) gapped out of a flat base, rising 6%. It's still in a buy range from a 74.85 buy point. The business data analytics company reported adjusted earnings of 67 cents a share, up 22% from a year ago. Revenue climbed 12% to $459.4 million.

Former leader GoPro (GPRO) gapped up and ended with a 13% gain after reporting earnings of 24 cents a share, double the year-ago number and well above estimates. Sales rose 54% to $363.1 million. Ambarella (AMBA), a key supplier to GoPro, rose 5%.
Casino operators were weak after Wynn Resorts (WYNN) reported sluggish earnings and slashed its dividend. Airline, HMO and restaurant stocks also underperformed.

After the close, Baidu (BIDU) will be out with earnings. Shares edged lower ahead of the results. Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos fell hard Tuesday on a report that Macau's government may cap the number of tourists coming from inland China. Credit Suisse revised its forecast for Macau casinos downward.Macau's government has decided to fight a decline in visitors that's led to its worst financial slump ever by — wait for it — proposing a cap on the number of visitors.Macau Business, a news publisher, said the government of the former Portuguese colony, now a special administrative district like Hong Kong, is proposing to China's government that the number of mainland tourists allowed to visit Macau be limited to fewer than 21 million a year.It wants to cap China tourists, who are mainly middle-class gamblers, to focus on attracting more high-roller VIP category gamblers, the report said. VIP gamblers are fewer in number but spend more, and most don't come from the mainland.Macau casinos' total revenue has already plunged amid tighter regulations by China's government and the shrinking growth rate of China's economy.Last year, Macau reported its first decline in year-to-year revenue, and the slump has continued this year.Macau's plan could backfire if the number of tourists from China falls and it isn't able to boost global tourist count. That could cause more pain for Sands, Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and others.Sterne Agee analyst David Bain said Macau's government may be posturing, saying "a key Macau contact with political insight suggests that comments regarding limiting visitation growth acts as a lever to address the mainland for additional (much needed/desired) land allowance for Macau for resident housing, etc."Bain expects a 35% year-to-year decline in Macau gambling revenue in April. He doesn't expect much improvement in Macau until later this year, although by midyear the situation should be "less bad."Credit Suisse analyst Kenneth Fong on Tuesday cut his first-quarter forecast for Macau gross gambling revenue to a range of 23% shrinkage to 9% growth, from an earlier forecast of 21% reduction to 10% growth.And "with fundamentals continuing to weaken" and valuation of Macau casinos relatively high, "gaming names may see downside here," Fong said.Sands shares gapped down 4% in strong volume in Tuesday afternoon trading in the stock market today.The world's biggest casino company's stock price is down 37% from a six-year high set in March 2014, and it fell below its 50-day average Tuesday.Wynn Resorts skidded nearly 5% and MGM,which has less exposure in Macau, fell 1%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) was down 4%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

The boards of MGM Resorts International (MGM)and Wynn Resorts are both in pitched battles for control amid one of the worst industry slumps in recent memory. The casino giants, along with peer Las Vegas Sands (LVS), have been hurt by a slowdown in Macau — the world's top gambling destination — amid tighter regulation by the Chinese government and slower…

The number of visitors arriving in package tours in Macau soared 51% in November to 1.17 million, compared to the same month a year ago, according to government statistics. That could give a boost to Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and other Las Vegas casinos that get the bulk of their revenue from the Chinese gambling enclave. Tourism in the world's top…
Struggling Caesars Entertainment (CZR) expects its merger with a unit it spun off in late 2013 will move it closer to resolving its debt through bankruptcy.
Caesars provided details of its latest restructuring move Monday, the Wall Street Journal said, after announcing a week ago on Dec. 22 that it planned to buy Caesars Acquisition in a stock swap deal.
Caesars Entertainment set up Caesars Acquisition to buy online gaming sites, and split it off in late 2013.
Shares of Caesars, the top U.S. casino company, rose 1.9% in Monday morning trading on the stock market todayhttps://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/.

Caesars earlier missed the boat to Macau, where rivals Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) all built multibillion-dollar casinos years ago that today generate the bulk of their growth.

Caesars' proposed merger would give the combined company, to be called Caesars Entertainment Operating Co., an additional $1.7 billion cash, it says, to help alleviate its estimated $18.4 billion in debt.

The new operating company would be controlled by a real estate investment trust. That REIT would continue to be controlled by private equity firms Apollo Global Management and TPG Capital, the reports said.

Shares of Caesars Entertainment plunged as much as 14% early Friday on a report that its biggest debt holders are balking at its latest restructuring plan as the company moves toward Chapter 11 bankruptcy as early as January.Caesars Entertainment (CZR) reached a tentative deal with some first-lien bondholders this week, just as the biggest holders exited talks and put out a 550-page report that provided details of Caesars' plans to enter bankuptcy, Bloomberg News said, citing two sources close to the company.The largest U.S. casino operator has been trying to renegotiate its $18.4 billion debt. Last year, Caesars split into two companies: casino operator Caesars Entertainment and Caesars Acquisition (CACQ), which was set up to acquire online gambling sites.The push for online gambling in the U.S. has stalled this year, partly because it's opposed by the CEO of the world's largest casino company, Las Vegas Sands (LVS), as well as by the CEO of Wynn Resorts (WYNN). Both companies get the bulk of their earnings from Macau casinos.With negotiations shelved for now, Caesars must decide whether to move forward with bankruptcy without its biggest debt holders on board or continue to try to come to terms with them before it proceeds, the report said.Caesars operates more than 50 casinos in the U.S. and Europe, including Las Vegas, Atlantic City and other U.S. locales. It's also laid out preliminary plans to build a casino in South Korea, which would be its first foray in Asia.Caesars formed a 4-1/2-month-long cup-with-handle base from mid-September 2013 to early February of this year and briefly tried to rally before turning down.Its stock price has been roughly halved since then, from a 26.74 high on Feb. 29 to 13.24 in midday Friday trading in the stock market today, down 10.6% for the day so far.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Sin City casinos are being squeezed by slower revenue from the Vegas Strip as well as weakness in Chinese hot spot Macau. The Nevada Gaming Control Board said Tuesday that September gambling revenue for the Las Vegas Strip fell 12% to $495 million, led by a whopping 30% decline in Baccarat revenue as high-roller…

Macau-centric casinos such as Las Vegas Sands got a glimmer of hope Friday in a report that the number of visitors to the world's most popular gaming destination rose to 2.41 million, up 3% last month vs. the same month a year earlier .But it's unclear whether the rise in visitors will translate into a revenue increase for Macau casinos.The report comes ahead of Wynn Resorts' (WYNN) third-quarter earnings, slated for Tuesday after the market closes.The consensus of 19 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for Wynn to report $1.84 earnings per share for the September-ending quarter, unchanged from a year ago, and a 1.8% drop in revenue to about $1.37 billion.Like Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), Wynn gets the bulk of its revenue from its Macau casinos.Macau finance secretary Francis Tam, in an interview with Macau radio and TV broadcaster Teledifusao de Macau, last week forecast the city's drop in casino revenue will worsen in October, and projected that recovery won't come until the second half of 2015.Meanwhile, the number of visitors from inland China to Macau, on China's southern coast across the strait from Hong Kong, rose 6% to nearly 1.6 million last month, macaubusiness.com reported, citing government figures.The number of visitors from South Korea and Japan rose, too. But the numbers from Hong Kong and Taiwan fell amid recent democracy protests in Hong Kong that curbed travel to and from the island.Investors are looking for any sign of upturn in the battered casino sector after stocks plunged over the summer and the downturn extended into fall.The slump in Macau came as China's economic growth slowed, and China's government tightened credit rules and cracked down on casinos amid a broad anti-corruption campaign. A smoking ban on Macau casinos that goes into effect this month also turned off some gamblers.June showed the first year-over-year monthly decline in Macau gambling revenue in five years. Revenue has now fallen an unprecedented five months in a row, according to Macau's Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.Wynn shares were up fractionally in Friday-afternoon trading on the stock market today.Sands, the world's largest casino company, rose more than 6% on Oct. 16 after it lifted its dividend 30% and reported higher Q3 earnings but lower revenue, missing estimates on both. It's since dropped back a bit and was down 1% Friday afternoon.MGM Resorts rose 0.6%, and Melco Crown edged lower.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

What at first looked like a summer hiccup for Macau-centric casinos such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS) is quickly turning into a long-term slump. Shares of Sands, which is slated to report third quarter earnings after the market closes Wednesday, fell to a 52-week low early Tuesday. But the stock recovered for a modest advance in the afternoon amid a…

MGM Resorts International's (MGM) balanced portfolio of casinos in Las Vegas and Macau, the world's top two gaming spots, has helped make it the apparent favorite casino company of the moment, as it got a second stock rating upgrade this week.

Craig-Hallum analyst Bryan Maher upgraded MGM to buy from hold Thursday, citing MGM's improving fundamental trends and saying investor sentiment on Macau is at "maximum pessimism," which indicates a bottom is near. Maher maintained a 28 price target.

The upgrade came after Deutsche Bank on Tuesday raised its rating on MGM to buy from hold and lifted its price target to 30 from 29. Deutsche Bank analyst Carlo Santarelli also downgraded Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company, to hold from buy and cut its price target to 65 from 74.

Shares of Macau-centric casinos including MGM, Sands, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) were pounded over the summer as Macau posted its first multi-month gambling revenue decrease in years.

The slump resulted largely from a crackdown by China's government on junket operators in Macau who allegedly made illegal loans to gamblers. The crackdown made some gamblers stay away. More recently, pro-democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong, just across the strait from Macau, may have driven some business away.
Maher said MGM, the biggest casino operator in Las Vegas, is poised to grow.
"I wouldn't call it robust, but there has been a healthy increase in gaming revenue of 5% in Las Vegas on a trailing 12 months basis," Maher told IBD.
But the real story is Macau, which generated just above $45 billion in gaming revenue last year, roughly six times that of Las Vegas.
Recent reports indicate the Chinese government may be scaling back its broad "misbehavior" crackdown.
"If the Chinese government takes its foot off the throttle on misbehavior to any degree, it will resonate to a degree throughout the (Macau) market" in a positive way, Maher said.
And China has good incentive to throttle back.
"I would submit that with a tax rate in Macau of 39.2% the Chinese government has an extremely vested interest in making sure it thrives," Maher said.
Maher noted that visits to Macau during its Golden Week celebration, which began Oct. 1, rose 17%.

"That caught people by surprise. With protests in Hong Kong there was thought it would be weak. But people bypassed Hong Kong and went to Macau. And people in Hong Kong may have gone to Macau to get away from demonstrations," Maher said.
MGM shares were down 1.8% in Thursday afternoon trading on the stock market today amid a sector selloff. Sands was down 2%, Wynn 2.4% and Melco Crown 1.6%.

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos climbed early Monday after Macau said September gambling revenue was in line with estimates, an indicator of improvement after a steep drop over the summer.

Macau casinos have seen revenue decline for four months in a row amid a crackdown by Chinese officials on the practice of some junket operators who lend money to gamblers in the special gambling district on China's southern coast.
More recently, pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong — just across the straits — and associated travel bans caused visitors to stay away over the summer after years of surging growth.
Total casino revenue fell 12% to $3.2 billion last month, a bit better than the projected 12%-13% decline from the same month a year ago, Macau officials reported.
Roughly 20% to 25% of Chinese tourists go to Macau and Hong Kong on the same trip, Bloomberg quoted Deutsche Bank analyst Karen Tang saying.
Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight projected October revenue will be down 19% from the comparable month in 2013, lower than Wall Street's outlook for a mid-teens decline.

"Of note, Golden Week visitation was up 14% year over year vs. August visitation growth of 12% year over year," McKnight said in a report, referring to the Golden Week celebration that begins Oct. 1 each year and usually lifts gambling revenue in Macau.

Sands shares were up 1.2% in Monday morning trading on the stock market today. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) 1.4, MGM Resorts International (MGM) surged 1.1% and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown International (MPEL) 5%.

Just when it looked like Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and others might see an upturn from a deep summer slump, Hong Kong protests have taken some of the wind out of their sails.
Macau was looking to Golden Week, a two-week celebration that starts on Oct. 1 every year, to boost revenue this month.
But Hong Kong protests, labor unrest in Macau, an ongoing anticorruption campaign and other factors threaten to derail Macau's recovery, at least for now.

Hundreds of casino workers in Macau walked off the job on Friday, Voice of America said. The report quoted a union leader there saying workers are demanding higher wages and better benefits. It was the latest in a wave of labor unrest to hit casinos facing shrinking revenues.

Still, shares of Las Vegas casinos that operate in Macau, including Sands, MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose Friday afternoon. They've stabilized a bit recently amid a slowly accelerating recovery in Las Vegas and a rising number of casinos in various states besides Nevada.

Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Friday that Macau casinos are in trouble in part on protests in — and travel suspensions to and from — Hong Kong amid continuing protests by pro-democracy activists to persuade the government to open local elections to all candidates.
"Investor sentiment (on Macau-centric casinos) is definitely more negative/cautious than a month ago, though we don't feel we're at the bottom," McKnight said.
Many investors also misread a report in China Daily on Tuesday that said "a campaign to put a check on misbehavior by party officials may just be ending," he said.

The campaign that's ending was just one facet of a larger anticorruption drive by China's Communist Party that also targets Macau junket operators who lend money to high rolling VIPs in Macau, he said.
Gamblers get loans from junket operators to get around Chinese rules that strictly limit the amount of cash visitors can bring into Macau.

Wells Fargo's checks with Macau contacts suggest "the anticorruption drive could ramp and persist for some time." As a result, VIPs who account for a large portion of Macau casino profits are likely to stay away for some time to come.
And a smoking ban about to go into effect in Macau casinos will "be strictly enforced" and could drive other gamblers away.
Sands shares were up 2% to 63.16 in Friday afternoon trading in the stock market today. The world's largest casino company has fallen about 29% from a 2014 high of 88.28 on March 7.

MGM and Wynn were both up more than 1%. Hong Kong based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another Macau casino operator, rose less than 1%. Morgan Stanley on Friday downgraded Melco Crown from overweight (buy) to equal weight (hold) with a 28 price target.

A campaign by the Chinese government that roiled the Macau gambling market appears to be coming to an end, which could help Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other casinos in the world's top global gaming destination.Casinos in the special administrative district on China's southern coast have been battered in recent months as revenue fell for perhaps the first time since China opened the door to foreign casinos in 2002.Investors eager for any positive news after the summer slump bid shares up Tuesday.A perfect storm of negatives has impacted Sands and other Macau-centric casinos such as MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) .China's economic growth has slowed this year. China cracked down on what it said were illegal lending practices in Macau, and new rules including a smoking ban in casinos have driven some players away.Chinese officials arrested some lenders in Macau earlier this year, saying they illegally used the government-sanctioned credit-card system to get around rules that limit how much cash Chinese citizens can bring into the former Portuguese colony.The crackdown made some gamblers uncomfortable, analysts said, so they stayed away.Chinese newspaper China Daily on Tuesday said a campaign to put a check on misbehavior by Chinese party officials may be ending."The campaign has reached its goals," the report quoted the Communist Party of China saying in a statement. The report noted that "lavish banquets and entertainment at VIP clubs," such as those at Macau casino resorts, were targets of the crackdown.Las Vegas casinos also may have gotten a boost from a Bloomberg report that a Japanese lawmaker backing a bill to legalize casinos in that country said he expects the bill to win approval in Japan's lower house as early as next month.Casinos have plans on the drawing board to build Macau-like casino resorts there if the bill passes.Sands shares were up 4.3% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. They had tumbled 32% from a 2014 high 88.28 set on March 7. Wynn climbed 5.3% and MGM 3.2%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another top Macau casino company, rose 3.7%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Las Vegas Sands shares fell to the lowest point in more than a year, and other Macau-centric casinos dropped hard after Wells Fargo said that the dire situation in Macau is continuing to deteriorate.

The bank lowered its rating on the large-cap gaming sector from overweight to market weight, and cut its ratings on Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) from outperform to market perform, citing a variety of factors including an upcoming investigative report on the Macau gambling industry.
Wells Fargo left its rating on MGM Resorts International (MGM) unchanged at market perform, saying that it's less at risk because of its huge casino resort holdings in Las Vegas.

The analyst report came after China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei said over the weekend that economic growth in that country continues to face downward pressure. More ominously, Lou also said that the country doesn't plan any major policy changes in response to shrinking growth, dashing hopes for more stimulus.
Wells Fargo's Cameron McKnight said that Monday's ratings cuts were his fourth this year and came "after what we thought were fairly hefty cuts last month."
He reiterated that he's still bullish on Macau casinos long-term but added, "It's possible things will get worse before they stabilize and get better."

Three major negatives are at work, McKnight said. There's a shift in the mix away from affluent, high-margin "VIP" gamblers toward the high end of the middle-class "mass market" gamblers. China has tightened lending standards, cooling visits by VIPs, who often borrow heavily to play baccarat.

Second, various China policy initiatives are impacting Macau, including a crackdown by the government on alleged corruption among junket operators who bring visitors to Macau. And a pending partial smoking ban could cause some to stay away. An employee union has also said that it may call for a full smoking ban, further dampening enthusiasm for Macau.
Finally, China's economic growth has slowed, so tourist dollars from inland Chinese are drying up.

McKnight added that there are other negative events on the near horizon, especially an upcoming Frontline investigative report that was four years in the making and is due to air on PBS Sept. 30. A preview of the documentary said that hundreds of billions of dollars end up in Macau despite currency controls, with organized crime also involved.
Sands shares were down nearly 4% on the stock market today. It's down about 32% from a more than six-year high of 88.28 set on March 7.
Wynn was down nearly 3% and MGM a bit more than 3%. Melco Crown fell 3.4%.

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) jumped 3% early Friday, leading a sector surge after it said its Macau casinos will be full during Golden Week, a two-week Chinese celebration that begins Oct. 1.A spokeswoman for Sands China, a Chinese casino company controlled by Sheldon Adelson's Las Vegas Sands, told Bloomberg News that its hotel room booking rate is close to 100%. Macau, located on China's southern coast, is the world's largest and fastest growing casino resort destination.The report was a bright spot in what has been a dismal period for global casinos, both in Macau and No. 2 global gambling venue Las Vegas.Nevada gaming officials said Friday that Las Vegas Strip year-to-date gaming revenue as of Aug. 31 was down a bit more than 1% at $1.09 billion, vs. $1.1 billion a year ago.Gambling revenue for the state of Nevada, according to Nevada's Gaming Control Board, was 1.5% below a year ago, at $1.85 billion.Investors shrugged off the weak Las Vegas numbers and eagerly focused on the possibility of strong Golden Week revenue in Macau.Macau saw revenue fall in August for a third month in a row amid a slowdown in Chinese economic growth and a crackdown by Chinese officials on illegal lending practices in the special administrative district.MGM Resorts International (MGM), the largest casino operator in Las Vegas, was up 1.4% in Friday afternoon trading in the stock market today. Smaller peer Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose 1.6%.Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) advanced 2.3%. Caesars Entertainment (CZR), which doesn't operate any casinos in Macau but is the largest casino operator in the U.S., was up more than 3%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Stocks extended their gains in early-afternoon trading as the major indexes held at or near session highs.

The Nasdaq led with a 0.6% advance, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 0.5% and the S&P 500 0.4%. Volume was tracking higher in the stock market today compared with this time Wednesday.
TAL Education Group (XRS) soared 3% to a record best, clearing a 35.55 three-weeks-tight buy point in twice normal trade. It's trading 1% above the entry.

Fellow Chinese stock Vipshop Holdings (VIPS) added 4% in above-average volume as it aims for its third straight advance. Shares of the Internet retailer are up 14% from a 182.10 cup buy point they cleared in June, but remain below the 50-day line. Analysts expect another quarter of triple-digit profit and sales growth in Q3.

China Mobile Games (CMGE), a tech developer and handset designer, surged 9% in busy trade as it headed for its third consecutive up session. The stock has moved off recent lows, but is still 32% below its high.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was on track to extend its gains for a second straight day as it rose 4% in heavy turnover. On Wednesday it climbed 2% on news the casino operator signed a license to build a proposed $1.6 billion resort casino on the Mystic River in Massachusetts.

Among other casino stocks, Las Vegas Sands (LVS) gained 2%, Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) 4% and racetrack operator Churchill Downs (CHDN) 2%. The group is among the day's top gainers, but has lagged in recent months — it ranked No. 184 in Thursday's issue, up from No. 190 six weeks ago.

Total gross gambling revenue for Macau fell nearly 40% to $4.76 billion in March vs. the same month a year ago, continuing the slide that began last summer for Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos.Though severe, the 39.4% drop in March was better than the 48.6% fall in the prior month, and in line with analyst estimates as market watchers and investors get used to the "new normal' for the world's top gambling destination.Chinese officials last year imposed tighter government restrictions on lending and other practices in Macau as part of an ongoing national "anti-corruption" campaign. Many high-roller, VIP-category gamblers had relied on short-term loans to get around restrictions against bringing more than a limited amount of outside currency into Macau and are staying away.Additionally, shrinking economic growth in China and a smoking ban that went into effect in casinos last fall are keeping some some tourists away.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said the decline was in line with consensus. McKnight said in a report that, based on channel checks in Macau "we expect April and May gaming revenue growth could be down 30%-plus."We remain neutral on Macau gaming as estimates and valuations adjust to a 'new normal' of (1) tighter government oversight, (2) 10% and 15%-20% medium-term industry revenue and earnings growth, and (3) a recovery that is likely to be flatter than reflected in valuations."Shares of Sands, the world's biggest casino company, closed down 0.1% on the stock market today. MGM Resorts International (MGM) lost 0.7%, its ninth straight lower close.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dipped 0.3%, while Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) finished up 2.3%, reversing an earlier loss.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar .

Monday, on track to close higher for a seventh day in the last eight trading sessions, on upbeat reports about the global gambling hub Macau.HSBC Bank last Thursday said it thinks the strong dollar rally is coming to an end. The unfavorable currency rate has hurt U.S. global companies' revenue by weakening the value of revenue they derive from overseas operations. The dollar has continued to slide since the Federal Reserve signaled last Wednesday that rate hikes may be later and slower than previously expected.Early Monday, HSBC's head of equity strategy in Asia-Pacific, Herald van der Linde, said in a follow-up report said that Asian stocks will benefit from a more stable dollar.Van der Linde said among Asian equities, including subsidiaries of U.S. casinos with Macau interests: "Consumer discretionary names tend to benefit the most from a weaker U.S. dollar."Last Wednesday after the market closed, Brean Capital analyst Bryan Maher launched coverage of Sands and three other top casino companies with buy ratings. Maher expects the slide in gambling revenue there to reverse later this year and urged investors to position themselves for an uptick in share values.Sands fell hard in the back half of 2014 as the Chinese government continued a crackdown on casinos, China's economic growth weakened and Macau put a smoking ban into effect that kept some smokers away.Sands, the world's largest casino company by annual revenue, MGM Resorts International (MGM) Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and others with casino resorts in Macau rose in Monday afternoon trading even though the upbeat reports were tempered by a cautious outlook in Macau, where officials slashed their average monthly gambling revenue outlook 27% to $2.5 billion a month for calendar 2015.Macau Chief Executive Fernando Chui said in his annual policy address that Macau has also entered a period of slower growth and casinos need to add new features to the resort side of the business to attract visitors.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Cameron McKnight has doubts Macau is ready for a turnaround."We remain neutral on Macau gaming, and continue to believe stocks will remain range-bound this year as Macau adjusts to the 'new normal' of greater government intervention and lower, steadier longer-term growth," McKnight said in a report Monday.After peaking at 57.27 by late morning, Sands shares had settled somewhat, still up 0.5% at 56.40 in afternoon trading in the stock market today. Macau's gambling revenue tumbled almost 49% as China's anti-corruption campaign continued and high rollers took their money elsewhere in February. But the timing of the Lunar New Year also impacted results, says one analyst.
Monthly gross revenue sank 48.6% to 19.5 billion patacas, or $2.4 billion, down from 38 billion patacas the year before, according to Macau's Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.
Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) fell 0.8% by early afternoon in the stock market today (Tuesday). Wynn Resorts (WYNN) shares were down 0.8%, too. But MGM Resorts International (MGM) shares rose 0.7%.

The February decline came amid a crackdown on corruption and weaker economic growth in the country. But the month nevertheless ended strongly, which one analyst attributed to the timing of the Lunar New Year, which arrived on Feb. 19 this year. The Lunar New Year falls in January or February.

"Typically, early days of Chinese New Year are spent at home with family — not in a casino — and we believe this led to an initial lull in early February Chinese New Year results," said Sterne Agee analyst David Bain in a note.
"Recall that February of last year did not show a pre-holiday slowdown as (the Chinese New Year) began Jan. 31 versus Feb. 19 this year."
Gross gaming revenue during the last five days of February climbed nearly 80% from the previous seven days as people flocked to the casinos after the close-to-home festivities ended.

The VIP segment sank about 56% year over year, while the mass gaming segment fell about 33%, said Bain; he added that Sands gained market share in February on its appeal to mass gaming, but Wynn's share was "slightly disappointing," given the casino renovation and a new junket group.
RELATED:
MGM Resorts Loss Widens On Plunge In Macau Revenue.

The S&P 500 eased 0.1%, while the Nasdaq fell 0.2%. They had fallen 0.5% and 0.7%, respectively after reversing early gains. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average rose a fraction. Volume was tracking higher across the board in the stock market today.

Among leaders, U.S. Silica (SLCA) slumped 8%, extending its recent slide. But the stock is pennies away from potential support at its 50-day line. It's now 35% off its September peak. Energy and related stocks tumbled as crude prices slumped nearly 2%. U.S. Silica supplies sand used in fracking.

Leaders up in volume were few, but Skechers (SKX) rose 3% as it bounced back from a two-day pullback. Overall, the stock appears to stabilizing after selling off on sales concerns.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos could be in trouble in the waning months of 2014 after Hong Kong, about 40 miles across the strait from Macau, on Friday cut its full-year economic forecast.

Hong Kong officials now see the economy expanding 2%-3% this year, down from a February projection of 3%-4% growth, after data showed gross Q2 domestic product fell 0.1% vs. the prior quarter, below analyst estimates.
Hong Kong Financial Secretary John Tsang said on his blog that purchases of watches, jewelry, electronics and other high-end goods fell sharply.
"Annual investment spending fell markedly; private consumption over the same period recorded only a slight increase," he said, adding performance for those sectors was the worst since Q1 of 2009.
Macau casino resorts rely on tourists from throughout China and nearby Asian countries, as well as affluent VIP customers from around the globe.

Gambling revenue for the world's top casino destination has contracted in recent months amid a perfect storm of factors. Among them: China has made it harder to get credit amid a deliberate belt-tightening.

And gamblers, especially VIPs, have shied away due to a crackdown by the Chinese government on junket operators and pawnshop lenders. China says some lenders use the government-backed debit/credit card system to illegally launder money.

Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight, citing the government crackdown, began warning early this year that the second half would be choppy for Sands, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM), which rely on Macau for the bulk of their revenue and growth.

On Friday, McKnight said the situation is deteriorating. "With slowing mass (middle-class tourist spending) growth in July and few signs of improvement in August, trends have turned from choppy to rocky," he said in a report.
Wells Fargo cut its stock price target for Sands from 90-100 to 80-85, and for Wynn from 260-270 to 245-250.
Additionally, "We are reducing our 2H14 Macau market total revenue growth estimate from 4% to -2% on lower mass market revenue growth assumptions," McKnight said.

Still, McKnight projects Macau casino growth will resume eventually as the effects of these factors are absorbed. "We remain bullish on the medium and long-term outlook. We see a $100 billion-plus Macau market over the next five years," up from about $50 billion currently, he said.
Sands shares were down 1.4% in midday trading in the stock market today. Wynn and MGM were both down about 1.5%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown (MPEL) slid more than 3%.

Revenue for Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos collectively fell 3.6% in July to $3.5 billion, Macau officials said recently, led by a slide in high-roller VIP segment gaming. Telsey Advisory Group analyst Chris Jones said Monday that the mass market segment in Macau — tourists and casual middle-class visitors — is also losing steam. And Las Vegas…
MGM Resorts International's (MGM) fourth-quarter loss widened and its revenue was lighter than expected as Macau operations continued to be a drag on results.
Shares fell early Tuesday, pulling the casino sector down, even though MGM announced a special $400 million dividend.
MGM Resorts reported a 70 cents per share loss minus one-time items, far worse than the 6-cent profit Wall Street expected. It was the third quarter in a row the company missed earnings estimates.
Revenue of $2.39 billion was down from $2.51 billion a year ago. Analysts expected $2.41 billion.

MGM Macau revenue of $719 million was down 22% from Q4 2013. In contrast, revenue at U.S. casinos rose 5% year over year to $1.55 billion, with management fees and other operations accounting for the balance of revenue.
The company noted that Q4 results were hurt by a one-time tax charge.
MGM CEO Jim Murren is looking for stronger results in 2015 and said, "In fact, we are already off to a good start with strong January results in the U.S."

But Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said the situation in Macau is likely to stay negative well into 2015, which could keep a lid on earnings for MGM and other Macau-centric casinos such as Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL).
In a report prior to MGM's earnings release, Wells Fargo said total China credit contracted 20% year over year in January, a negative for Macau casinos .

MGM shares dropped from a 5-1/2-year high of 28.75 on March 7 to a 2014 low 17.25 on Dec. 17 amid a slump in Macau resulting from a crackdown by China on lending practices, a smoking ban that drove some customers away and weaker China economic growth.

MGM had recovered to nearly 22 per share on Friday and was down less than 1% in early Tuesday trading in the stock market today. It dropped further below its 200-day line but was still trading above its 50-day.
Among other casinos, Sands and Melco Crown were both down fractionally while Wynn Resorts dropped more than 2%.
