Revenue for Macau's casinos could fall a jaw-dropping 35% to 42% in February vs. the same month a year ago, according to a new market analysis. That could further drive down shares of battered Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos. Early February's average daily receipts for Macau casinos hit $83.27 million through Feb. 8, down 13% from January's…
Macau gambling revenue plunged 17.4% to $3 billion in January, the eighth monthly drop in a row.
The decline pushed down shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and others that get the bulk of their revenue from the Chinese gaming enclave.

It followed a 30.4% drop in December and 19.6% drop in November as the global gambling hub in 2014 posted its first-ever gambling revenue decrease, according to figures released by the Macau Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.
Sands shares were down 1.8% in Monday morning trading on the stock market today.
Among other large casinos, MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) were down about 1%.
Wynn is slated to report earnings Feb. 3. Consensus is for earnings per share to fall 37% to $1.43 on a 20.4% drop in revenue to $1.21 billion.
Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) rose fractionally.

"Mass market" gamblers — tourists and middle-class inland Chinese visitors to the southern China coast hot spot — fell 20%. "VIP" high-roller revenue dipped 16%, Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said.
The slide is likely to continue, McKnight said, as a crackdown by the Chinese government on alleged corruption and weakening Chinese economic growth keep a lid on spending.
"Based on current ADR (average daily revenue rate) and seasonal trends we believe February gaming revenue growth could be closer to -35%, vs. our -31% estimate."
Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 19 this year, could have major impact. McKnight said channel checks show Chinese New Years vacation travel bookings are lower than in prior years.
Sands, the world's largest casino company hit a six-year high in early March 2014 and slid for the rest of the year. It's down about 39% from that point, trading below its 50-day and 200-day lines.

Gaming and Leisure Properties (GLPI) hopes to get lucky with its $4.1 billion hostile offer for casino operator Pinnacle Entertainment's (PNK) properties.
Gaming and Leisure Properties said its offer was rebuffed and it plans to take the offer to the company's shareholders if Pinnacle refuses talks.

Real estate investment trust Gaming and Leisure, itself a spinoff of Penn National Gaming (PENN), sent a letter to Pinnacle's board offering to acquire its real estate assets and assume debt in exchange for shares.
Pinnacle responded Monday afternoon, saying it received a proposal from Gaming and Leisure on Jan. 16 and that it was willing to talk at that time "under appropriate terms."

Pinnacle added that it received a revised proposal last Friday and told Gaming and Leisure its board would review the offer and respond promptly, "but GLPI decided not to wait for the consideration of Pinnacle's Board."

Pinnacle owns 15 casinos in eight states and a majority interest in Retama Park Racetrack near San Antonio. Last November, it announced plans to separate its gaming operating business and real estate assets.
Under terms of the latest offer, Pinnacle's operating business would become a separately traded public company and would be operated by its current management and board.
The Pinnacle operating company would enter into a master lease agreement with Gaming and Leisure for its casino properties.
Pinnacle shareholders would receive one share of the new operating company and 0.5517 share of Gaming and Leisure stock for each share of Pinnacle they own.
After the deal concludes, current Pinnacle shareholders would own 100% of the operating company and about 20% of the combined real estate company.
Pinnacle shares were up 15% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Gaming and Leisure was up 11%. Pinnacle stock shot up from a four-month consolidation with a 27.45 pivot point.

Meanwhile, shares of casino giants Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) were down after Macquarie Securities warned that the worst is yet to come for Macau gaming, and forecast that dividends will be slashed across the board for companies with heavy presences in the Chinese gambling hub.
Macau casinos have seen revenue drop sharply in the last year amid a crackdown by the Chinese government and weakening economic growth in China.

Gambling revenue in the hot Macau resort may shrink much more than earlier thought.
In one of the first bets on 2015 casino gambling, Wells Fargo cut its estimate for existing Macau casinos to a steep 15% fall from the 4% decline projected earlier.
The projected revenue drop could further drive down shares of struggling Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos.
Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight has a market perform (neutral) rating on Sands and other casinos the bank tracks.

"For 2015, we now expect revenue sequentially flat with (fourth quarter) trends, resulting in -15% year-over-year same-store growth and -10% year-over-year total growth," factoring in casinos that are expected to open this year, McKnight said.
China has cracked down on lending in Macau, the gambling hotspot on China's southern coast, as part of a nationwide "anti-corruption" drive.
It has also put visa restrictions on visitors from inland China to the Macau special administrative district and implemented strict currency regulations, McKnight said.
"We are not being bearish for the sake of it, but currently don't see a reason to expect any same-store revenue improvement in the near term, given China's policy actions toward Macau," he said.
McKnight reduced his price target range for Sands, the world's largest casino company, from 60-70 to 55-60.
He cut his target for Wynn Resorts (WYNN) to 150-170 from 170-190, and for Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) to 23-27 from 26-29.
McKnight left his target for MGM Resorts International (MGM) unchanged at 23-26.

Sands shares were down 2.2% in late afternoon trading in the stock market today, Tuesday. Although it's the highest-rated global casino company in the struggling group, it has a weak 40 IBD Composite Rating, meaning 60% of all stocks have performed better in recent quarters on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.
Sands hasn't formed a viable base recently, and is trading well below both its 50-day and 200-day averages.
Wynn shares were down 1.6%, MGM 3.2% and Melco Crown 2.8%.

Stocks rattled off healthy gains in quiet trade early Wednesday, taking back a bit of the ground lost in Tuesday's rout and ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy announcement this afternoon.
The S&P 500 bumped up 0.6%. The Nasdaq gained 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.4%.
Volume was 13% lower on the Nasdaq and down 20% on the NYSE compared with trade at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today is all ears with regard to the outcome of the Federal Open Market Committee's meeting, with a policy statement due out at 2 p.m. ET. While no specific strategy changes are expected, the Fed could be set to back away from its pledge of sustained low interest rates, a move that could affect the dollar and set global stocks and currencies into a reactive mode.

In U.S. trade, FedEx (FDX) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) crumbled 4% each. Exxon Mobil (XOM) led the Dow, up 2%. The company on Tuesday announced a joint venture with ConocoPhilips (COP) and Canada's Suncor Energy (SU) to bid $559 million for rights to explore offshore from Newfoundland.
Three-in-five IBD 50 list stocks rose in early trade.

Spirit Airlines (SAVE) popped 3%. The Miramar, Fla.-based budget airline said it had launched a $100 million share buyback program. Shares toppled 19% last week after the company reported some competitive pricing pressure on short-term bookings. The stock is a fraction higher this week, but still well below its 10-week moving average.

BitAuto (BITA) jumped 5%. Hedge fund Tiger Global Management reported Tuesday it had amassed a 14.9% stake in the China-based provider of online car information. The stock remains lower for the week in what would become a third straight weekly decline. Las Vegas Sands lost the lead in market share to Hong Kong-based SJM Holdings, one of the six casino companies licensed to operate the 35 casino resorts in the world's most popular gambling hotspot.
SJM, operator of the Grand Lisboa, Casino Babylon and 16 other casinos, had about 22.6% of Macau's gross gaming revenue in November, various reports said, citing Macau gambling commission figures.
Sands Macau — a unit of Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company — saw revenue decline 4% on a year-over-year basis, giving it a roughly 22.5% share.
But Sands Cotai Central, the company's new $4 billion casino on Macau's popular Cotai peninsula, continued to outgrow the market, according to Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight.

Hong Kong-listed Galaxy Entertainment had a market share of 21.5%. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) had 9%. MGM China, a unit of MGM Resorts International (MGM), had 11%, and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) had 13.4%.
Las Vegas Sands stock was down fractionally on the stock market today. Wynn and Melco Crown shares were up less than 1%, while MGM fell less than 1% on Tuesday.
The market-share shift comes as Macau's overall gambling revenue continues to shrink. In November, according to government figures, total revenue dropped nearly 20% to $3.94 billion.

"We believe China policy settings are negatively affecting growth, specifically: (1) visa restrictions (on tourists from inland China to the Macau special administrative district), (2) the anticorruption drive, (3) a pullback in credit and (4) a soft housing market," wrote Wells Fargo's McKnight in a report Tuesday. "We remain on the sidelines as uncertainty remains high."
In November, total "mass" market revenue — middle-class tourists — fell 13% vs. a year earlier in Macau, and the volume of junkets plunged 31%, McKnight said.

So-called junket operators bring gamblers to Macau, especially affluent "VIP"-category high rollers, often lending them money to get around local restrictions on how much cash can be brought into Macau.
The Chinese government has cracked down on the lending practice as part of a broad "anticorruption" campaign, arresting several junket operators earlier this year on charges of money laundering.
VIP revenue fell 24% for the month, McKnight said.

Gambling revenue in Macau fell nearly 20% on a year-over-year basis to $3.94 billion in November, continuing a downward trend that began last summer.
The greater than expected drop also drove down shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos on Monday.
The Macau gaming inspection bureau reported the raw number and will release a detailed breakdown later this week.
According to bureau figures, after Macau gambling revenue shrank by single digits monthly from June to August, it plunged 23.2% in October before sliding 19.6% in November.

Gambling revenue in Macau has fallen amid a government crackdown on junket operators who lend money to gamblers, tighter restrictions on visas for Chinese tourists to visit the special administrative district and a new smoking ban in casinos.
Las Vegas Sands shares were down 3.9% in early afternoon trading on the stock market today.
MGM Resorts International (MGM) was down 2.4% and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dipped 2.1%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) was down 3%.

December growth might also disappoint, Wells Fargo Securities analyst Cameron McKnight stated in a report, due to President Xi Jinping's visit to Macau. "Historically, December gaming revenue has seasonally improved 6% month over month, implying a 23% year-over-year decline, based on current November trends," he said.
McKnight projects that December revenue could fall 25%, based on November trends, which would be below consensus.

The touted recent interest rate cut by Beijing is a signal that China's economy is worsening, McKnight said. "Reports suggest that People's Bank of China officials do not view the rate cut as a change in the Central Bank's monetary policy."
He added that recent key monthly data out of the Middle Kingdom "suggest that China's economic growth continues to decelerate."
Sterne Agee analyst David Bain agreed.
"President Xi Jinping's visit to Macau is likely to disrupt the gaming appetite of some VIP (high roller) and premium mass (affluent tourist) players," Bain said.
Sterne Agee forecasts a 23%-28% drop in Macau gambling revenue in December.

Analysts began warning this past spring that a summer slowdown would impact Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos. But the slump has dragged on, and a report out Tuesday forecasts the downturn will extend into 2015. "We continue to forecast mostly negative high- to mid-single digit growth declines for early next year," Sterne Agee analyst David Bain said.…
Hedge fund manager Jim Chanos warned that he expects overcapacity will squeeze profits for Macau-centric casinos such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS).
Sands and other casino stocks shrugged off the reports as casino stocks staged a strong rally early Friday.

"I think estimates are going to come down," Chanos, founder and managing partner of Kynikos Associates, was cited as saying in various reports. "The stuff that is being built, as that's happening, the revenues have now turned down due to credit crunch, corruption, all the things we've been talking about. Take your pick."
The small city of Macau on China's southern coast became the world's top gambling destination after China opened the door for Las Vegas-based casinos to build there.
Analysts began warning of a slowdown last spring on a convergence of negatives.

China's economic growth cooled. China's government tightened regulations, reined in credit rates and launched a massive anti-corruption campaign that included a cracking down on lenders in Macau that provide funds to gamblers.
Democracy protests in nearby Hong Kong last summer curbed travel to and from that island, further cooling Macau gambling, as did a smoking ban that recently went into effect.

Revenue and earnings for Sands, MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) could be curbed after massive building in Macau has created what could be a glut, Chanos said.
Sands was up 1.7% in Friday morning trading in the stock market todayhttps://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ , although it's down 29% from a 2014 high of 88.28 on March 7.
MGM rose 2.2%, Wynn Resorts 1% and Melco Crown Entertainment 2%.

A weak start turned to narrow gains then mixed trade as the dollar eked lower early Tuesday.
The Dow Jones industrial average bobbed back and forth between fractional gains and losses. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 kept their heads up 0.1% apiece.

The stock market today is likely to reflect investors' jockeying ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee policy statement scheduled for Wednesday, a Scottish independence vote on Thursday and the launch of China's Alibaba on the New York Stock Exchange Friday.
The dollar downshifted from early, level trade. Investors apparently locked in profits from the buck's recent gain ahead of the Fed announcement.

Gains and losses were modest across most stocks listed on the major indexes. The session opened with Apple (AAPL) slicing 2% lower in massive trade. The pullback stopped pennies shy of a test of the stock's 50-day moving average.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) dropped 4% each. The casino operators were apparently under pressure following a report in the Macau Business Daily that said casinos there would likely see a 5% drop in revenue from June to August, and a report from Morgan Stanley that said the decline in China's top gambling region has not yet found a bottom.

The predicament for Macau-centric casinos like Las Vegas Sands (LVS) is worse than originally thought, according to various reports.Wells Fargo, Sterne Agee and other analysts began warning early this year of a summer slowdown in gambling revenue in Macau, the popular gambling hub on China's southern coast, across the strait from Hong Kong.But Morgan Stanley analysts, who just returned from a fact-finding trip to Macau on Monday, said Macau casinos have not found bottom yet and Macau casinos valuation "is not compelling."FBR Capital said Macau gambling revenue is on trajectory for a fourth straight monthly decline in September, and its first quarterly decline in years. FBR is looking for a midteens decline in September and said a recent sharp sell-off in casino stocks still hasn't revealed a possible bottom.Macau gambling revenue is weak amid sluggish China economic growth and a crackdown by Chinese officials on illegal lending practices in the former Portuguese colony.Additionally, a casino smoking ban that goes into effect in October, in a country where smoking is still popular among gamblers, is expected to cool enthusiasm for casino visits.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Cameron McKnight said Tuesday that, based on channel checks through Sept. 14, he expects September Macau revenue to be down in the midteens, worse than his prior estimate for a high single- to low double-digit decline."The Chinese economy and Macau continue to remain soft, and weak growth trends into Golden Week and the smoking ban may create additional uncertainty," McKnight said.China's two-week Golden Week holidays in early October usually generate a big chunk of Macau casinos' fall revenue.Official numbers aren't out yet, but Macau Business Daily estimated Macau gambling revenue slid 5% in the June-to-August quarter. Like others, that report cited China's weak economy and aggressive stance against corruption in Macau.Shares of Las Vegas Sands, the world's largest casino company, were down 2% in Tuesday afternoon trading on the stock market today. Sands' stock price has fallen 31% from a March 7 high of 88.28.Among other companies with casino resorts in Macau, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was also down 2%, MGM Resorts International (MGM) slid 3% and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) skidded 4%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Goldman Sachs sees light at the end of the tunnel for struggling casino giants Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), and in a client note Tuesday recommended buying their shares.

But Morgan Stanley on Wednesday downgraded its rating on smaller peer Boyd Gaming (BYD), citing the Las Vegas casino company's presence in the the U.S. online gaming market, which the bank says isn't growing as quickly as expected.
Although one report was negative and the other positive, shares of all three casino companies continued to drift down in mid-Wednesday trading amid a sector slump.
Goldman analyst Steven Kent said in a report that "Times like these create entry points: Buy LVS and WYNN."
Sands and Wynn operate casinos in Las Vegas but their growth is primarily driven by multibillion dollar casinos in hotspot Macau, on China's southern coast.

Kent acknowledged "near-term weakness," but added, "solid visitation growth (at their casinos) has continued and hotel occupancy is at all-time highs. Combined with lower sell side expectations and current low relative valuation levels we believe LVS and WYNN are now set up for a rebound in performance."
Goldman has a buy rating on Sands and Wynn, with price targets of 85 and 247, respectively.
Sands shares fell 0.1% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. The company's stock is about 30% down from a more than six-year high of 88.28, set March 7.
Wynn slid 1.3% to 181.88, and was down about 27% from an all-time high of 249.31 set March 5.
Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley analyst Thomas Allen cut his rating on Boyd to equal weight from overweight, and lowered his price target to 11 from 12.
Boyd operates Sam's Town and Orleans casinos in Las Vegas, the Midwest and elsewhere in the U.S., but doesn't operate in Macau.
Boyd's Borgata hotel casino in Atlantic City received the first Internet gambling permit in New Jersey last October, giving it early entry into what promises to be a lucrative market long-term.

But Morgan Stanley also lowered its estimate for total U.S. online gaming revenue. Online gambling is now legal in some form in only three states: Nevada, New Jersey and Delaware. Other states are expected to follow, and federal legislators are working on bills to legalize it nationally.

Morgan Stanley cut its 2017 and 2020 online gaming revenue estimates to $1.3 billion and $5 billion from $3.5 billion and $8 billion, respectively. It projects online gaming will be legal in seven states by 2017.
Shares of Boyd Gaming slid 0.1% intraday.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) stock was downgraded by Argus Research to hold from buy, but investors initially shrugged it off, as the company's share price barely budged.
Argus' downgrade for the world's largest casino resort company follows that of UBS and others amid a slump at the gambling enclave Macau on China's southern coast.
Macau, the top global gaming destination — and fastest growing — saw a rare shrinkage in gambling revenue growth over the summer.

Some gamblers, especially affluent VIPs, have stayed away due to a crackdown by the Chinese government on junket operators and pawn-shop lenders that China says use the government-backed debit/credit card system to illegally launder money.
But Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight and others expect the slump in Macau to be brief, with a recovery as early as this year.

"Despite a choppy near-term outlook, we remain positive on Macau and LVS with the Macau market still significantly underpenetrated and expected to reach $100 billion of gaming revenues by 2018," which would nearly double last year's Macau gambling revenue, McKnight said in a client note last month.

Still, shares of Sands and other Macau-centric casinos such as MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) have fallen the last couple of months.
Sands, which is down about 28% since early March, had slipped less than 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, Thursday. MGM and Wynn were up more than 1% and Melco Crown climbed 3%.

Stocks hit fresh session highs late Thursday and were on track for a fourth straight gain.

Helped by Internet and computer hardware stocks, the Nasdaq rallied 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up 1%. Volume was tracking modestly higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today

Tata Motors (TTM) stretched its gain to 3%. Earlier, the stock cleared a 48.28 buy point in a double-bottom base in heavy trading. The Indian carmaker has a Composite Rating of 83, the highest in the Auto Manufacturers group. Tata was mentioned in International Leaders earlier this month.

Under Armour (UA) rallied 3% and regained its 50-day line in fast trade. The stock is in a flat base within a larger pattern. Telsey Advisory Group upgraded shares to outperform from market perform Wednesday.

On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) reversed and fell 2% ahead of its fiscal Q1 earnings after the close. The chipmaker is expected to earn 65 cents a share, up 41% from a year ago. That would mark a second straight quarter of accelerating growth. Microsemi is working on a potential base.

Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), KLA-Tencor (KLAC), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and Starbucks (SBUX) will also be reporting earnings after the close.Stocks hit fresh session highs late Thursday and were on track for a fourth straight gain.Helped by Internet and computer hardware stocks, the Nasdaq rallied 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up 1%. Volume was tracking modestly higher on both major exchanges in the stock market todayTata Motors (TTM) stretched its gain to 3%. Earlier, the stock cleared a 48.28 buy point in a double-bottom base in heavy trading. The Indian carmaker has a Composite Rating of 83, the highest in the Auto Manufacturers group. Tata was mentioned in International Leaders earlier this month.Under Armour (UA) rallied 3% and regained its 50-day line in fast trade. The stock is in a flat base within a larger pattern. Telsey Advisory Group upgraded shares to outperform from market perform Wednesday.On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) reversed and fell 2% ahead of its fiscal Q1 earnings after the close. The chipmaker is expected to earn 65 cents a share, up 41% from a year ago. That would mark a second straight quarter of accelerating growth. Microsemi is working on a potential base.Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), KLA-Tencor (KLAC), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and Starbucks (SBUX) will also be reporting earnings after the close.
Macau-centric casinos continue to be pounded by a mid-year slowdown, with Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) on Thursday becoming the latest to fall short of revenue and profit targets.

Additionally, Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a post-earnings report that the Taipei District Prosecutors Office had indicted Melco Crown's Taiwan branch office and certain employees for alleged violations of local banking and foreign exchange laws. The company was expected to provide details on its earnings call.

Melco Crown, which competes with Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other large U.S. casinos in Macau, said Q2 earnings per share fell 26% from the same quarter a year ago to 26 cents. That was 10 cents below consensus of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Revenue slid 7.4% to $1.199 billion, undershooting Wall Street's $1.297 billion target.
Casino mogul and Melco CEO Lawrence Ho said the shortfall was mainly in the high-roller VIP segment, partly offset by a 38% increase in so-called mass market, or tourist, table game revenues.
Melco shares slid as much as 5% early and settled to a 2.9% drop at 29.14 in morning trading on the stock market today.

McKnight in a report said it was a "soft" quarter for Melco and noted its "City of Dreams Manila is on track to open later this year, while Studio City remains on-track for a mid-2015 opening." Wells Fargo has an outperform rating on Melco.
The company's board also approved a $500 million share repurchase program.
Las Vegas Sands last month also reported disappointing results, mainly on weakness in Macau. Sands shares lost 2.2% Thursday.

Among other Vegas casinos with Macau operations, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) lost more than 1% intraday. Both reported Macau weakness in their recent earnings reports, partially offset by resurging business in Las Vegas.

A pair of reports confirming falling revenue for Macau gambling proved a losing hand for Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said Macau gaming revenue for July fell 3.6% to $3.5 billion. The drop came amid a crackdown on practices by local lenders who allegedly used credit cards to illegally launder money. Some of those lenders have been arrested as a result.Visitors to Macau routinely borrow money to get around restrictions on the amount of cash that can be brought into the special district across the strait from Hong Kong.The crackdown includes tighter restrictions on lenders that make it harder for visitors to borrow, causing some, especially high-roller VIP gamblers, to stay away.The revenue drop was led by a 13.9% slide in VIP gaming, mostly from baccarat play. Mass market (middle class tourist) revenue rose 17%, but that was the weakest growth since the bank started tracking Macau casinos in 2010.McKnight said Macau "revenues did not improve materially in the back half of July, which could mean mainland China's political initiatives, and potentially transit visa changes, are impacting premium mass" gambling revenue.In a separate report, Deutsche Bank lowered its third-quarter and full-year 2014 revenue forecast for Macau.Deutsche Bank analyst Carlo Santarelli expects Q3 revenue to fall 0.9% vs. the same quarter a year ago and full year revenue to grow 6.5%, well below the region's usual growth rates, and down from his earlier outlook for 3% Q3 growth and 8.6% for the full year.Deutsche Bank also lowered its August gross gaming revenue forecast to a mild 3% increase "to account for softer VIP volume and mass revenue trends against a tough comparison" vs. the same month a year ago, StreetInsider quoted Santarelli as saying in the report.Las Vegas Sands shares were down more than 4% at 68.93 in Wednesday afternoon trading on the stock market today.Other large Las Vegas casinos with operations in Macau dived. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell 3.5% and MGM Resorts International (MGM) slid 2%.Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) skidded 5%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

MGM Resorts International's (MGM) massive presence in Las Vegas helped the company beat second-quarter earnings estimates.But weakness persists in the Chinese gambling enclave Macau, and MGM said revenue for its MGM China majority-owned unit fell 1% to $828 million during the quarter.MGM's Q2 earnings per share rose 15% to 70 cents, 3 cents better than expected.Revenue grew 4% to $2.58 billion, edging consensus for $2.57 billion.MGM shares rose early Tuesday on the earnings beat but reversed and were down about 2% amid a sector rout in afternoon trading in the stock market today.Union Gaming analyst Robert Shore said he was surprised that shares reversed."It was a clean beat and their comments on the call were positive," Shore told IBD. "I was surprised their stock fell. We think maybe people were looking for them to be even more bullish after (Wynn Resorts (WYNN) CEO) Steve Wynn gave bullish comments on the Wynn conference call earlier."Union Gaming maintained its buy rating on MGM and Shore said he expects its shares will bounce back in the days ahead.MGM China and other Macau casinos are struggling after the government cracked down on alleged money laundering by lenders and imposed tight new regulations on casinos designed to choke off illegal lending.Still, MGM China announced a $136 million dividend, of which MGM Resorts International will receive a 51% share, or $69 million.MGM's various casino resorts in Las Vegas sprawl across 742 acres, well ahead of Caesars Entertainment (CZR), the No. 2 presence in Sin City with 414 acres, a Union Gaming report said Monday.Q2 revenue at MGM's U.S. resorts rose 6% from a year ago to $1.639 billion. Hotel room sales were also up 6% as revenue per available room rose to $141 from $134 a year ago.Struggling Caesars traded lawsuits with noteholders Tuesday, with creditors saying Caesars was fraudulently transferring assets and liabilities as part of its ongoing restructuring. Caesars claims investors are pushing for a default just to get a profit. Caesars plunged 11%.Shares of Wynn, No. 3 U.S. casino by revenue, fell 1.7%. Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company, was also down about 1.8%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Wynn Resorts'  (WYNN) earnings per share leapt nearly 40% to $2.11, better than Wall Street's $1.95 per-share target, amid cost-cutting measures and a general resurgence of visitors to Las Vegas. Shares fell early after the company reported a 6% hike in revenue to $1.41 billion, short of consensus for $1.43 billion, on a general slowdown at Chinese gambling enclave…
Shares of Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and other top casinos fell for a third straight session amid conflicting reports Monday about gambling hotspot Macau.
SSome analysts had earlier forecast a short-term decline in Macau after the government cracked down on lenders in China's gaming enclave
Gamblers often borrow money to get around restrictions on how much cash they can bring into the the special administrative district across the strait from Hong Kong.
Chinese officials say some lenders engage in illegal money laundering.

Sterne Agee analyst David Bain said in a report channel checks indicated that Macau's gross gaming revenue, or GGR, was up about 5% so far for June, year over year, to an annualized rate of $3.9 billion.

"This morning, there were initial reports that the first nine days of GGR amounted to 7.8 billion Macau pacatas ($980 million), which would have shown a slower than expected start to June (-4%). Those reports were incorrect," Bain said in his report.
"Our June year-over-year GGR outlook is between -2% and +3%. Recall that we expect some GGR head winds from the World Cup," which began June 12 in Brazil and will likely draw tourists away, he said.
Wells Fargo Cameron McKnight was also moderately downbeat.

"Based on (channel) checks through June 8, we estimate June Macau gaming revenue growth is trending between 1%-5% (higher) year over year, vs. our June estimate of 6.5%," even though that period included two weekends when more people visit Macau, McKnight said.

He remains positive about Macau's long-term prospects. However, "2014 could be choppy due to a potential slowdown in VIP driven by decelerating credit growth and a softer macroenvironment. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) remains our top pick for 2014 given its strong mass market" position. Mass market refers to middle-class tourists from inland China and other countries.

FBR Capital Markets said the crackdown, tighter restrictions on visas for people visiting the city and a recent smoking ban are likely to keep gamblers away. FBR analyst Jake Fuller expects Macau gambling revenue to grow about 10% this quarter, below consensus. He kept market perform ratings on Las Vegas Sands and Wynn and an outperform rating on MGM Resorts International (MGM), a third Vegas casino with Macau operations.

Deutsche Bank cut its 2014 full-year Macau gross gaming revenue forecast from 15% to 12%. It also downgraded Wynn Macau and SJM Holdings — a Hong Kong-based casino that operates in Macau and trades on the Hong Kong exchange — to hold from buy. The bank lowered its price targets on Wynn, Sands, MGM and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), a Hong Kong-based Macau casino operator that trades on the NYSE.

Morgan Stanley said in its report there may be a quarterly decline in earnings this quarter, the first since the fourth quarter 2009. The bank projected year-to-year VIP gambling revenue could fall 7% "due to fewer weekend days and potential distraction from the World Cup starting June 12."
Shares of Wynn Resorts fell nearly 3% on the stock market today.
Sands and MGM Resorts fell more than 2%, while Melco Crown skidded nearly 6%.
Caesars Entertainment (CZR), which doesn't own casinos in Macau but is the largest U.S. casino operator, climbed 2%.

International Game Technology (IGT), a maker of computerized slots and other casino gaming gear, shot up more than 14% Monday after Reuters reported that IGT is mulling a sale of the company. Casino companies and private equity firms reportedly are interested.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other top Vegas casinos fell sharply early Tuesday in heavy volume after officials in gambling hotspot Macau said gaming revenue rose just 9.3% in May vs. a year ago, well below consensus for 13% to 15% growth. The drop was a surprise for many, coming a day after Chinese officials reported stronger manufacturing growth for…

Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.

A second bank said Macau faces a short-term slump in gambling revenue that could affect earnings for Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other top casinos in the hot gambling destination on China's southern coast.
Nomura Securities on Thursday cut its earlier-raised 2014 revenue growth forecast for Macau from 17% to 14%.
The Japanese bank joined Wells Fargo, which, as reported earlier, has been warning for some time that Macau casinos face headwinds in the short term.
Sands separately said Thursday that President and Chief Operating Officer Michael Leven will retire at the end of this year. And CEO Sheldon Adelson tried to quash rumors that he plans to step down.
"I am as bullish about this company as I've ever been, and I have no plans of slowing down or passing the CEO title or job to anyone," Adelson said in a statement.

Meanwhile, Nomura analyst Harry Curtis in a report noted the bank raised its estimate for Macau in March, based on stronger-than-expected demand early in the year. "Since then, growth has contracted to 12%-13%, which we expect to continue through year-end," Curtis said, "so our revised forecast for the full year is back to our original +14% estimate."
Both banks blame a credit crunch in the world's top gambling destination for the projected slowdown.

VIP gamblers rely on local loans to play in Macau because Chinese officials restrict the amount of cash visitors can bring in. But Chinese officials have accused some lenders of laundering money for illegal activities and imposed further restrictions that could keep some VIPs away.
Like Wells Fargo, Nomura remains bullish on Macau in the long run as the gambling mecca continues to expand.
Las Vegas Sands shares rose 1% in Thursday morning trading in the stock market today.

Sands threw a huge party this week, celebrating the 10th anniversary of its first casino in Macau. It now has more than 9,000 hotel rooms and suites, 1.5 million square feet of convention space, more than 100 restaurants and 600 duty-free retail shops, two theaters and a 15,000-seat arena there.

Among rivals in Macau, MGM Resorts International (MGM) was up more than 2% early Thursday. MGM shares hit a five-year high of 28.75 on March 7 and have consolidated about 14% in sync with a market correction.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose 1.5%. Wynn said in a May 16 filing that it appointed Stephen Cootey treasurer and chief financial officer. Cootey had served as interim CFO since February.

Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), a Hong Kong casino that competes in Macau with Vegas rivals, jumped 3%. Melco Crown continues to expand in Asia and, like Sands and others, is eyeing Japan, whose legislature is debating legalizing casino gambling.

Stocks were tightly mixed at Tuesday's open, with earnings reports driving much of the early action.
The Nasdaq, hamstrung by Baidu's (BIDU) 14% decline, fought with a fractional loss. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each added 0.2%.
Volume was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 17% lower on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Monday.

The stock market today has an eye on the Federal Open Market Committee, which is meeting in Washington but not expected to generate any news until the policy announcement scheduled for 2 p.m. on Wednesday.

Other economic news began with home prices, which were effectively flat in May, according to a 4.9 reading for the Case Shiller 20-City Home Price Index. Economists had expected a reading of 5.6. April's number was revised a notch higher, to 5.

The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index also fell, dropping to 90.9 in July, down from June's 101.4 tally, which was revised lower to 99.8. Economist consensus projected a very slight dip, to 99.6, for July.

A more positive note from researcher Markit reported the services sector of the economy improved in July. The preliminary estimate for its PMI index rose to 55.2, up from a 54.8 reading in June. Consensus had looked for a no-change number of 54.8.
In stocks, reactions were generally positive as quarterly reports rolled out from a broad range of companies.

Ford (F) and heavy truck maker Paccar (PCAR) climbed nearly 2% each. GrubHub (GRUB) jumped 3% after its Q2 report. Norway's state-owned oil producer Statoil (STO) jumped more than 2% on its second-quarter results.

Baidu (BIDU) posted the news-leading decline, with shares diving 14% after the company reported a Q2 earnings miss late Monday. The drop put shares down 17% so far for the week, and far below critical levels of support.

Cummins (CMI) powered up almost 4% after the diesel engine maker easily beat analysts' second-quarter sales and earnings projections. Management held to its prior revenue guidance for the year, which is consistent with consensus views. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since June last year.

United Parcel Service (UPS) swept up nearly 4% as its earnings beat consensus estimates. Revenue stopped short of expectations, but management backed its prior EPS range of $5.05 to $5.30 for the year, and said it would come in near the top of that range. The stock has been crawling along the bottom of a flat consolidation and fighting to retake 10-week support since January.
The IBD 50 list opened the session evenly split — half up, half down at the start of trade.
Horizon Pharma (HZNP) and Blackhawk Network (HAWK) led the group, up more than 2% each. United Therapeutics (UTHR) grabbed the low post, dropping almost 4% after a mixed second-quarter report.

JetBlue Airways (JBLU) slipped nearly 4% after 132% EPS growth met Q2 expectations, but an 8% revenue gain stopped short of consensus estimates. The stock narrowed its gain to 2% above a 21.70 buy point following a low volume breakout.Stocks were tightly mixed at Tuesday's open, with earnings reports driving much of the early action.The Nasdaq, hamstrung by Baidu's (BIDU) 14% decline, fought with a fractional loss. Stocks held solid gains near midday Thursday, but eased from session highs. The Nasdaq trimmed a 1% gain to 0.7% and the S&P 500 pared a 0.7% gain to 0.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%. Turnover was running higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

In leading stocks, WNS (WNS) gapped up and bolted nearly 7% to its best levels since February 2007. It blew past a 31.60 buy point in a cup base. Before the open, the Indian outsourcing firm posted fiscal Q2 earnings above views and raised guidance.

Inphi (IPHI) rallied 5% and hit an all-time high. The stock cleared a 27.21 buy point in a consolidation. Volume was heavy. The chip designer will report Q3 earnings Oct. 27. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit doubling to 24 cents a share. That would mark an eighth straight quarter of double-digit growth.
On the downside, Netflix (NFLX) gapped below its 50-day line and dumped 10% following late Wednesday's disappointing Q3 results and news of soft U.S. subscriber growth.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) was off its session low, but still down 5% on news that it received a federal subpoena over its drug-pricing policy. Shares of the Canadian drugmaker were off as much as 12% intraday.

That would mark an eighth straight quarter of double-digit growth.On the downside, Netflix (NFLX) gapped below its 50-day line and dumped 10% following late Wednesday's disappointing Q3 results and news of soft U.S. subscriber growth.Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) was off its session low, but still down 5% on news that it received a federal subpoena over its drug-pricing policy. Shares of the Canadian drugmaker were off as much as 12% intraday.Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.

Las Vegas Sands' second-quarter estimates will be a high bar for the company to jump when it reports Wednesday. For four quarters in a row, it's posted double-digit earnings growth, but likely hosted fewer VIP visitors to its Macau casinos recently. Like Las Vegas peers MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) gets the bulk…

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casino giants sold off sharply on a report of money laundering crackdown in the Chinese gaming enclave, though they pared losses by the afternoon. Players routinely borrow money from junket operators in China to gamble in the special district on China's southern coast to get around regulations restricting the amount of cash players…

Stocks were back in positive territory Tuesday afternoon. News of the European Union's new sanctions against Russia hurt stocks earlier.The Nasdaq climbed 0.3% while the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%, with the Dow Jones industrial average also rising 0.1%. Volume was tracking higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today .TAL Education Group (XRS) rallied 9% to its best levels in just over three weeks. It's now back to being 11% past a 26.68 buy point from a consolidation after finding support at its 10-week line last week. The stock had wiped out a 12% gain past the 26.68 trigger. TAL was recently featured in Sector Leaders Review.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose 4% to its best levels in nearly two months after posting mixed quarterly results. Before the open, the casino operator beat views with Q2 earnings that climbed 40% to $2.11 a share. Sales rose 6% to more then $1.41 billion, but missed views on $1.43 billion. Business in Las Vegas was strong, but its Macau business was soft.Skechers (SKX) added 1% to an all-time high. The lift puts it 14% past a 47.63 buy point from a flat base. Last week, the shoemaker and retailer delivered a 386% surge in Q2 earnings and a 37% jump in sales. The company has now delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit profit growth. Revenue growth accelerated in the latest two quarters.Leaders down in volume were few, but Zillow (Z) pulled back 4%. It reversed higher Monday on news that it would buy rival Trulia (TRLA) for $3.5 billion in stock.

Total gambling revenue for China's Macau gaming hotspot rose 10.7% in April vs. the same month a year ago, to $3.9 billion. That should have given Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and others with casinos there a boost, but casino stocks generally fell amid the prospect of slowing growth this year. The 10.7% growth topped Wells Fargo's lowered estimate for 7%-10%…

Stock futures traded lower, but steady ahead of Monday's open as oil prices and the Federal Reserve tested investor confidence. Dow futures traded 40.2 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures hung 5.5 points below the line. Nasdaq 100 futures were off a mild 7.6 points. Small caps were under disproportionate pressure, with Russell 2000 futures falling 8.2 points.The stock market today opens under a clear caution flag ahead of Wednesday's policy decision from the Federal Reserve. The Nasdaq dropped 4.1% last week, slicing below support at both its 200-day and 50-day moving averages. The S&P 500 crumpled 3.8%, also violating both levels of support. That means all bets are off on the market's direction for the next two days.Within that uncertainty, oil prices continued diving early Monday, with West Texas Intermediate down more than 2% to below 35% a barrel, its lowest mark in more than a decade. Brent crude dropped nearly 3%, below $37, to its weakest level since 2008. Both benchmarks have logged steady losses since the Dec. 4 Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting, in which the group failed to agree on a production quota, permitting member countries to continue current production levels.Despite the oil price slump, it was DuPont (DD) and Apple (AAPL) that dragged down the Dow before the open. DuPont dipped more than 1%.Apple trimmed its premarket loss to 1%, up from a 3% dive, after Morgan Stanley cut its price target to 143 from 162, citing pressure on international iPhone prices due to oversupply outside China. Apple ended Friday well off an August low, but struggling to retake its 10-week moving average within a five-month consolidation.Jarden (JAH) jumped 5%, Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) slipped more than 2% after Newell said it would pay $13.2 billion in a cash/stock deal to acquire the Boca Raton, Fla.-based maker of Sunbeam irons, Marmot outdoor gear and Crock-Pot cookware.Newell management said the combination is targeting $500 million in annualized cost savings, would be immediately positive for earnings, and should close in Q2 of 2016. Jarden rose 9% last week on merger speculation, moving the stock up the right side of a five-month consolidation.China-based maker of solar electrical components Trina Solar (TSL) spiked 9% on news reports that the company had received an offer to be taken private at $11.60 per share by Shanghai Xingsheng Equity Investment & Management. The offer was 321% above Friday's closing price.Edwards Lifesciences (EW) was confusing brokerage data collection systems in premarket trade, as it prepared to go live with its 2-for-1 stock split at today's open. It is the company's first stock split since May 2010.Overseas, Europe's stocks came off their lows near midday. London's FTSE 100 reversed early losses and wrestled into narrowly positive territory. Frankfurt's DAX was down 0.8%, up from a 1.2% loss. The Cac-40 in Paris eased to a 0.4% loss, from 0.6%.Asia's markets were widely mixed: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dipped 0.7%, the Shanghai Composite jumped 2.5% and the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo stumbled to a 1.8% loss.
Caesars Entertainment (CZR) will close its money-losing Harrah's casino in Tunica, Miss., on June 2, as casinos in the U.S. struggle with anemic growth amid continuing consumer caution.
"There's just too much supply in that market," John Payne, president of the company's central markets division, told Bloomberg. "The Harrah's has not been profitable for a while."
Top U.S. casino operator Caesars will eliminate 1,300 jobs in the move, which comes amid a broad restructuring for the company. Caesars has lost money in five of the last six years.
It's also indicative of a broader malaise in the U.S. casino industry.

Atlantic City, N.J. is one of the country's hardest-hit locales. On Jan. 13, the 33-year-old Atlantic Club Casino Hotel, owned by Santa Monica, Calif.-based private equity firm Colony Capital, closed its doors.
A subsidiary of Caesars, the largest Atlantic City casino operator, bought the non-gaming assets of the Atlantic Club in a bankruptcy auction.
Like rivals Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's biggest casino company, MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Caesars is based in Las Vegas.
But Sands, Wynn and MGM mostly rely on casinos in Chinese gambling hotspot Macau for their growth.
Caesars has been U.S.-centric until now, but earlier this month said it had gotten preliminary approval from South Korean officials to build a casino there.
Meanwhile, Vegas, the hub of U.S. casino gaming, has experienced a weak recovery from the 2008-'09 recession.
After total Vegas gambling revenue dropped about 10% in 2008 and 2009, it grew just 3% a year from 2010 to 2013, the UNLV Center for Gaming Research said in a recent report.
Caesars shares were down 3% in Thursday midday trading in the stock market. Sands, which is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, fell 2%, MGM 1% and Wynn 3%.

Stocks ended mixed Tuesday after making a feeble attempt to rebound from a sharp sell-off the prior day. The S&P 500 added 0.2%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.2%.Volume was lower across the board, falling 12% on the NYSE and 8% on the Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.Apple (AAPL) was the Dow's biggest decliner, sinking 2.5%, after Japan's Nikkei newspaper reported that the tech giant would cut production of its 6S and 6S Plus iPhone models by about 30% more than planned in the first three months of the year. The report cited Apple suppliers in Japan and abroad.Apple, a former market leader, is now more than 20% off its 52-week high and its Accumulation/Distribution Rating stands at D-, indicating heavy selling.Elsewhere in the stock market today, Gilead Sciences (GILD) rose nearly 1.3% following positive results for its experimental hepatitis B drug.Semiconductor stocks were among the worst performers in the IBD 50.Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI), which makes semiconductors for the auto, communications and defense industries, lost 3.3%. The stock erased a 12% gain past a 38.69 buy point of a cup-with-handle base, triggering a sell signal.Singapore-based chip designer Avago Technologies (AVGO) dropped 3.4% in light trade as it works on a handle in a long consolidation with a buy point at 149.82.Meanwhile, Smith & Wesson (SWHC) was easily the biggest winner in the IBD 50. Shares jumped 11% after the firearms maker issued bullish guidance late Monday.Monsanto (MON) and RPM International (RPM) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Wednesday.Economic reports scheduled for Wednesday include the Institute for Supply Management's index of service sector activity for December, factory orders for November, the trade balance for November and minutes from the Federal Reserve's Dec. 16 meeting.Follow Scott Stoddard on Twitter @IBD_SStoddard.
Stocks mounted a comeback and have turned mixed in late trading Tuesday.

The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up about 0.1%. They were off by as much as 0.7% and 0.8%, respectively. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq pared a 1.9% drop to 0.6% after finding support near its 200-day line. Turnover continued to track sharply higher across the board in the stock market today.

Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) tumbled 11% and sliced its 50-day line. It rumbled up 11% in premarket trade. The Illinois-based maker of barcode and scanning-related technologies was up as much as 5% after updating its Q1 earnings and revenue guidance to above consensus forecasts. The firm also said it had agreed to pay $3.45 billion to buy Motorola Solutions' (MSI) enterprise business. Zebra said the deal would immediately add to earnings, and that it planned to add 4,500 employees once the deal was closed.
Anika Therapeutics (ANIK) was off its session low, but still down nearly 7%. Anika is also on pace to close below support at its 50-day moving average.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dropped 4% to its lowest levels since late January. The stock has fallen for five weeks and counting and is now 20% off its March peak.

Leaders up in volume were few, but Michael Kors (KORS) rose 2%, putting it on track for a second straight gain. Earlier Tuesday, the fashion house announced that it signed a 10-year licensing deal with Italian eyewear-maker Luxottica Group (LUX).

Stocks pushed off their session lows and were again mixed in late trading Monday.

The Dow Jones industrial average climbed back into positive territory, rising 0.1%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq was off by 0.7%, and the S&P 500 slipped 0.2%. They were off by as much as 1.5% and 0.7%, respectively. Volume was tracking sharply higher across the board in the stock market today.
Despite the improvement, some leading stocks were still under pressure.
Baidu (BIDU) and Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) were the biggest decliners, down 8% and nearly 7%, respectively. Both broke their 200-day moving averages.
Ambarella (AMBA) fell 6% after reversing early gains. It broke support near 25 and neared its 200-day line, where it found support in late August.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) slumped nearly 6% and breached support at the 200 level. Shares of the casino operator have already fallen for seven straight weeks. Wynn is getting close to potential support at its 200-day moving average.

On the upside, Apple (AAPL) was off its session peak but still up 2% and on pace for its third straight gain. Last week, the company posted better-than-expected fiscal Q2 results and upped its buyback and dividend. Intraday, the stock touched its best levels since December 2012.

Gaming and gambling are popular in China, and Chinese and American entertainment companies are doing well in the country. Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU), Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Baidu (BIDU) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) are all highly rated and performing especially well in China.

The five gambling and Internet companies are featured in the Big Cap Screen of the Day. The screen lists large stocks with strong earnings and price performance. Bigger can sometimes mean better as larger companies have more liquidity.

Qihoo has a 99 Composite Rating, the highest possible. The Chinese company started off developing security software, but has since expanded by developing its own search engine to rival Chinese Internet giant Baidu.
According to Chinese government statistics, the 310 million mobile gamers in the country spent 247% more on games in 2013 than 2012.
In Q4, 17% of Qihoo's sales came from mobile games; mobile gaming revenue soared 131% to $63 million. The Maxim Group expects Qihoo's mobile gaming revenue to rise 260% in 2014.

Baidu is also on the screen with a 99 Composite Rating. A fifth of Baidu's Q4 revenue came from mobile gaming and other mobile products. The company ended 2013 with 100 million active mobile app customers and has plans to expand its mobile gaming and music products into international markets.
Gambling is also popular in China.

Wynn Resorts also has a 99 Composite Rating. The company operates casinos in the U.S. and Macau. Wynn has been expanding its operations in Macau, building a 1,700-room hotel and casino that's slated to open in 2016. Macau has replaced Las Vegas as the world's top gambling destination as wealthy Chinese flock to the only place in China where gambling is legal. Last month Wynn reported a 24.6% jump in revenue from Macau to $1.12 billion for the fourth quarter. Las Vegas revenue rose only 2.4% to $400 million.

Other casino operators are looking to expand past lagging Las Vegas, using their success in China to springboard into the rest of Asia. Melco Crown, which has a 99 Composite Rating, is a Hong Kong-based casino company. It plans to develop a casino complex in Manila with Philippines-based SM Group's Bell Corp. Melco Crown also plans to enter Japan.
Analysts expect overall casino revenue in Japan could generate $40 billion a year.

Las Vegas Sands, another casino operator, is on the Big Cap list with a 98 Composite Rating. The company also has a large operation in Macau, with revenue from its China division up 28.4% to $2.53 billion in Q4. But it struggled with operations in Singapore. Still, Las Vegas Sands continues its expansion into Asia. Last month, CEO Sheldon Adelson announced plans to spend $10 billion to start developing casinos in Japan.
Related story: Qihoo, Baidu Bets On Mobile Gaming Apps Paying Off

It might still be snowing on the East Coast, but spring is officially here. Palm trees and sandy beaches are calling all Americans — not just students — to take a break from the snow and head to somewhere sunny.
But even those stuck in the latest snowstorm can still take advantage of spring. Here are six spring-break stocks on the Big Cap Leaders Screen of the Day.
Delta Air Lines (DAL) is on the list with the highest possible Composite Rating of 99. Shares soared 3.33% to 34.43 in the stock market Tuesday.
The airline offers flights to numerous warm destinations in the U.S., like Miami, San Diego and Honolulu, as well as to beach spots abroad like the Bahamas.

For those who can't unplug from the office, on Tuesday Delta announced it will have Wi-Fi service on Boeing (BA) 747 flights from Los Angeles and Atlanta to Tokyo. The company plans to add Wi-Fi services on all international flights by the end of next year.

Southwest Airlines (LUV) is also featured on the screen with a 99 rating. The airline will begin international flights to the Bahamas, Aruba and Jamaica starting in July. The airline is expanding its routes at home as well. On Monday, Southwest said it will more than double flights out of Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in the D.C. area. New routes include nonstop flights to Akron-Canton, Ohio; Indianapolis and Dallas. In December, Southwest bought American Airlines' (AAL) takeoff and landing spots at Reagan as part of American's merger deal with U.S. Air.
With the economy on an uptick, more travelers are heading to Las Vegas to try their luck in Sin City.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) has a 99 Composite Rating and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) enjoys a CR of 98.

Earlier this month, Sands applied to Singapore officials for permits to add 1,500 rooms to its Marina Bay Sands casino there. Sands also has operations in Macau, along with MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn.
Wynn shares fell more than 2% to 219.50 on Tuesday and Sands fell nearly 2% to 78.80. Both have fallen below their 50-day moving averages
If you want to look good while hitting the beach in Miami or the tables in Vegas, Michael Kors (KORS) has affordable luxury offerings like handbags and dresses to adorn spring-break revelers.
Kors has a 98 rating. Luxury brands outperformed their mid-market peers during the holiday season as middle-class consumers looked for deep discounts.

Take lots of pictures en route to Vegas or sporting a Kors bag at the beach and put them up on Facebook (FB) or its sister site Instagram. The social media giant has a 99 rating. Late Tuesday it announced plans to buy virtual reality company Oculus VR for $1.9 billion — perhaps you can take a virtual trip to Maui one day. Tech stocks were in the driver's seat again Monday as all three major averages kicked off the week on positive ground.

The Nasdaq gained 0.5% in early afternoon trade; the S&P 500 added 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.1%. Volume on the Nasdaq was tracking 10% higher than Friday's level. NYSE volume fell 10%.

Several days into a new uptrend, major averages continue to show little in the way of selling pressure. The Nasdaq declined three days in a row from May 30 through June 3 but hardly gave up any ground and closed near its high each day.

In the stock market today, Anika Therapeutics (ANIK) cleared a late-stage base with a buy point of 49.47. Shares rose 6% in heavy volume. There was no news to account for the move. Anika makes therapeutics products for tissue protection, healing and repair.

Inside the IBD 50, China-based HollySys Automation Technologies (HOLI) gained nearly 6% as it works on the right side of a late-stage base. Volume has been generally light during its recent rebound. The company's automation and control products are found in industrial, railway, subway and nuclear power industries in China.
Elsewhere, Wabtec (WAB) climbed to the top of an 11-week, first-stage base as it flirted with a breakout. Shares rose 1%. The buy point is 82.52.

KapStone Paper & Packaging (KS) is also near the top of a first-stage base. Shares rose 1%. Paper products firms like KapStone continue to benefit from the rise in online shopping. KapStone and others make the boxes used to ship merchandise.

Meanwhile, Grifols (GRFS), the newest addition to Leaderboard at Investors.com, extended gains after Friday's breakout. Shares rose nearly 2% in fast trade. The maker of plasma derivative products is now 6% above a recent buy point of 43.60.

On the downside, casino operators were under pressure on conflicting reports about business in Macau off of mainland China. The drive to legalize online gambling throughout the U.S. is gaining momentum, but the heads of the world's largest casino companies are divided on what could be an $8 billion market.MGM Resorts International (MGM) CEO Jim Murren and Caesars Entertainment (CZR) CEO Gary Loveman support it."Gamers and casinos — those two industries are converging," Murren told IBD recently."We think that's a good thing. There's a business opportunity if it's regulated pristinely, preferably at the federal level."Caesars also has spun off Caesars Acquisition (CACQ), whose goal is to acquire online gaming sites and technology. Most of the rest of the U.S. casino industry, which generates more than $37 billion in revenue a year, supports legalizing online gambling.But Las Vegas Sands  (LVS) CEO Sheldon Adelson is vehemently against it, and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) CEO Steve Wynn has withdrawn his earlier backing.Possible FrameworkDespite this opposition, Nevada and Delaware recently took what many see as a significant step toward national legal online gambling.Last month they signed a compact — similar to the ones states use to enable multistate lotteries — that lets gamblers in both states play on sites based in each other's state.The agreement is for online poker only, but market tracker Union Gaming noted in a report that it is the first of its kind and "could serve as a framework for future interstate compacts."The two states hope to build on the Justice Department's 2011 decision to allow online gambling, except for sports betting, even though it limits betting to residents within a state playing on sites based in that state.Nevada, New Jersey and Delaware were the first to offer online gaming. Struggling Atlantic City venues are betting online games will drive interest in playing at casinos rather than encourage players to just stay at home.Other states, still licking wounds from the recession and looking to boost tax revenues, are mulling legalization too.They won't get any help from Adelson, who has said online betting will open the door to minors gambling and to unscrupulous sites preying on vulnerable people.In January, he launched the Coalition to Stop Internet Gambling, which is calling on Congress to pass a federal ban on Internet gambling.An opposing group, the Coalition for Consumer and Online Protection, has formed with backing from MGM Resorts, the American Gaming Association and the Poker Players Alliance, among others.MGM's Murren says the industry must be "absolutely vigilant and tireless" in shutting down illegal gambling sites and warns they could damage the overall industry."From our perspective at MGM, the most important dimension of the debate has to be on law enforcement," he said.Adelson may have found an ally in his bid to hold back the online gambling trend.888 Holdings On HoldUntil recently, Steve Wynn was preparing his company for online gaming. In September he agreed to have U.K.-based 888 Holdings develop his resort's online poker offerings.But in a January interview with industry tracker Jon Ralston at RalstonReports.com, Wynn said he now agrees with Adelson.Wynn added later it's possible he could change his mind again."This is not a good entrepreneurial opportunity," he told Ralston. "Where's the business opportunity? The big problem I see is I don't see the government letting us keep the money."Wynn has since put its partnership with 888 Holdings on hold.Meantime, 888 is working with regulators in states considering legalizing online gambling to educate them about safety and security issues.888 CEO Brian Mattingley said in an interview with IBD that based on his conversations with analysts, the online gambling market could reach $5 billion-$8 billion when it matures."The opportunity in the U.S. is going to be enormous," he said.

February Macau gaming revenue jumped 40% annually to $4.8 billion, setting a new record, helped by the Lunar New Year holiday. Stocks put in a downside reversal Thursday ahead of Friday's key jobs report, which is expected to show an increase of 206,000 new jobs during March, according to Econoday.

Hurt by Internet, software and biotech stocks, the Nasdaq tumbled 0.9%. The S&P 500 dipped 0.1%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average, which touched a record high, lost a fraction. All three indexes ended off their session lows, but still fell for the first time in five trading sessions. According to preliminary data, volume ended lower across the board in the stock market today.
Leading stocks were especially hard hit amid the reversal.

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) slumped 8% in heavy trading, putting it back below its 50-day line. It threatened a round trip by nearly falling back to a 65.02 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared back on Feb. 6. It had been up as much as 24%.

Tableau Software (DATA), which reversed lower Wednesday, stumbled 8% in heavy trading. But the stock appeared to have found support at its 200-day moving average. The stock recently erased a 32% gain from a breakout past a 77.84 buy point from a cup base. Intraday Thursday, it fell 8% past the 77.84 entry.
Splunk (SPLK) dropped 7% in fast trade. But it too looked to have found support at its 200-day line.
Elsewhere, other leading stocks such as Biogen Idec (BIIB), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell between 1% and nearly 3%.

On the upside, paint-maker RPM International (RPM) gapped up and gained 5% in fast trade. It cleared a 43.44 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. IGT shareholders will get $18.25 per share, with $13.69 cash plus 0.1819 share in a newly formed holding company based in the U.K.…

Revenue for Macau casinos fell in June, confirming what analysts have been forecasting for months, but casino stocks jumped on hopes that the worst of the recent slowdown may be over. Macau's Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau said Tuesday that gross gaming revenue in June was $3.41 billion, down 3.7% from a year ago. That was the first annual decline…

Las Vegas Sands' (LVS) had its price target cut by two analysts in as many days amid rising concerns about slowing growth in global gambling capital Macau.But shares of the world's largest casino company rose nicely early Wednesday, leading a sector mini-rally, amid general stock market gains and hopes for stronger China economic growth, which should fuel Macau gaming.Analysts have said they're still bullish long-term on Macau casinos. The new price targets may be catching up with months-old news of slowing Macau growth.Casino stocks may also be reacting to prospects in Japan, whose parliament is debating a bill to legalize casinos.Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Tuesday voiced support for the bill, saying he plans to push for a vote in this fall's session, part of his broader plan to improve infrastructure and tourist attractions ahead of the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.FBR Capital analyst Jake Fuller lowered his price target on Sands to 80 from 85, with a market perform (neutral) rating. Fuller noted in a report that FBR downgraded Sands' rating and began shifting away from Macau casinos in January.Many high-roller VIP gamblers are avoiding Macau during a crackdown by Chinese officials on local lenders who provide cash to gamblers to get around limits on how much cash they can bring into Macau. China says some lenders use the system to illegally launder money.On Tuesday, Susquehanna lowered its target for Sands to 89 from 98, with a positive rating. The bank also cut its target for Vegas rival Wynn Resorts (WYNN), which operates large casinos in Macau, to 239 from 268.Morgan Stanley, Zacks and Telsey Advisory Group all earlier lowered price targets on Sands.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said last week that valuations of Macau-centric casinos are bottoming, "but, based on our valuation analysis, we don't believe we're at a short-term bottom."By late afternoon, Sands was trading up 0.8% and Wynn was up 0.9% in the stock market today, Wednesday.Meanwhile, MGM Resorts International (MGM) rose 0.9%.On Tuesday, a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ruled that a ballot measure to repeal the state's expanded casino gambling law can go to voters this fall.The ruling overturned a decision by state Attorney General Martha Coakley, and set up what could be an expensive campaign.The 2011 law said three casino resorts and one slot machine parlor could be built in the state. MGM this month was awarded the state's first casino license. Penn National Gaming (PENN) got the slot parlor license in February.Meanwhile, Wynn and Mohegan Sun, a Connecticut casino company, have issued proposals for a license and are vying to get the nod to build a casino in Boston.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe narrowed the time frame he'd like to see a bill legalizing casino gambling passed in that country, saying Tuesday he's looking for a vote this fall.
U.S. casino giants such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS) have been in Tokyo for months, lobbying for passage of the bill, which could add billions to their coffers.
Some observers had expected a vote on the bill in the spring session. But the Diet failed to act and postponed the vote.
"I hope in my capacity as leader of the LDP (Liberal Democratic Party) that we can aim to pass it in the next extraordinary session of the Diet" this fall, Abe told Bloomberg in an interview.
Sands CEO Sheldon Adelson has said he's ready to invest $10 billion in Japan as soon as casinos are legal there. Sands shares rose 1.3% in the stock market today.
Analysts have said if the bill passes as expected, Japan could quickly vie with China's Macau gambling district, which boasts annual gambling revenue of roughly $50 billion a year.
Abe, now 18 months in office, is pushing for quick passage as part of a package to stimulate Japan's economy and enable casinos to be built ahead of the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.
Sands rival Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown (MPEL) are among casinos jostling to get their foot in the door in Japan.
MGM Resorts International (MGM) Chief Executive Jim Murren told IBD earlier this year his company was in talks with Japanese companies to form partnerships to build casinos.
"Ultimately we hope to be a large, active operation and participate in Japan through the operation of one or more casinos there," he said in March.
MGM shares climbed 2%. Wynn Resorts and Melco Crown were both up about 2%.

The Nasdaq added 0.4%, while the S&P; 500 fell less than 0.1% — a loss too small to be considered distribution. Volume rose sharply as traders started coming back from summer break. Tech stocks outperformed Tuesday and the S&P 500 hit an all-time high on an intraday basis as Wall Street digested dovish comments Monday from Fed Chief Janet Yellen.

The Nasdaq rose 1.1% and reclaimed its 50-day moving average. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each rose 0.4%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking about 12% higher than Monday in the stock market today.
In economic news, one day after a disappointing reading from the Chicago Purchasing Manufacturers index, the ISM Manufacturing index came in mostly in-line with expectations at 53.7.

Among the day's gainers, former leader Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) surged 9% after U.S. regulators approved a new version of its da Vinci robotic surgical system. The stock rose as much as 15% on the news but was near its session low about two hours into the session.

Meanwhile, casino operators with exposure to Macau, China, had a good day on news gaming revenue in the region totaled $4.4 billion in March, up 13% from a year ago and the third-highest on record. Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) rose 5%; Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) gained 2% each.

Several other China-based growth stocks scored gains in heavy volume, including Autohome (ATHM) and BitAuto (BITA). Both operate websites for prospective car buyers in China. Shares of Autohome rose 4% while BitAuto soared 9% .

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) was the best percentage gainer in the IBD 50, rising nearly 5%. The stock plunged below its 50-day moving average last week but has been in rally mode since Friday. It was just above its 50-day moving average early Tuesday.

After Monday's 3% move higher, IBD's biotech group added another 2%. Stocks pared more losses Friday afternoon and were near their best levels of the session.
The Nasdaq shaved a 1.3% deficit to 0.3%. The S&P 500 clipped a 1.2% loss to 0.4%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.7%, hurt by Chevron (CVX) and Visa (V).
Volume was tracking higher on both major exchanges in the the stock market today, especially on the NYSE.
Toymaker Mattel (MAT) gapped down and tumbled 10% on disappointing Q4 results. The company cited weak North American sales. Shares fell to near a 52-week low.
Rival Hasbro (HAS) fell 5%, but was off its session low. It reports Q4 results Feb. 10.

On the upside, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) gapped up and rallied 14% to an all-time high in fast trade. Late Thursday, the restaurant operator matched expectations with a 30% jump in its Q4 earnings. It topped views with a 21% gain in sales. Top-line growth was the best in six quarters. Operating margins widened, in spite of higher food costs. Chipotle gapped above an early 548.24 buy point from a flat base.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) climbed 6% and neared its Jan. 21 record high. After Thursday's close, the casino operator reported a 94% surge in Q4 earnings and an 18% gain in sales. Both topped analysts' expectations. Revenue growth picked up for the third straight quarter and ended three quarters of single-digit growth. Business in Macau grew nearly 25%.
